What I said in 2016:
This is a fun game. The base game is alright. The story missions are alright. The side missions and events get a little repeative with different characters with a different quirk in each district telling you what to do. But all the events and the side missions in the regular world are pretty fast, so whatever. At least you don't have to climb a tower to unlock the map :P 

Besides the normal part of the game there is the Dark Zone. Which is a lot of fun and I recommend going there every 5 levels or so to get better gear. It's fun in groups and solo. The Dark Zone drops are good way to get gear or some pvp, but I recommend exploring the contaminated areas for loot, especially underground. There's also the Survival mode which is awesome solo or in a party! I wish these survival elements were in the base game.

I recently got to Endgame. Wow there is a lot of stuff to do in Endgame! A world tier system comes into play and the Underground expansion opens up. The Underground is extremely team based. Soloing is not recommended. 

Oh, Uplay exists. Yeah I know, that's a deal breaker for some. I've had problems with uplay before, but not recently. I still recommend this game even with uplay. Best to get it on sale like I did with the the Season Pass.

Played this day 1 on Xbox when it came out (when games were actually completed at launch) and it was amazing!  Its still amazing to this day, far surpassing games that were recently released. I've played this game for some years now and it's great to play. The atmosphere with all the sounds and visuals are stunning. The story is alright but I love that there is always something to do and explore. Sometimes you gotta look in the right places to find something to do such as the terminal downstairs in the base of operations. I also recommend zooming into the map and just going to every single little side mission and locked doors. There is always something to explore and randomly find. The game runs very stable and everything is well thought through. The layout, functions etc. Everything you can do in the game is fun. I recommend getting it at any price.

So, the game itself is fantastic. The visual fidelity creates an atmosphere that sucks you in. The only big problem is that someone at Massive doesn't understand what difficulty means. So, don't think this is a tactical shooter. No matter what the PR says, it's not. It's a stat based looter shooter that is all about farming equipment with better stats to minmax your build for PvP. And if you don't have minmaxed builds for PvP, no amount of skill will save you in a gunfight against veteran players who've been at it for hundreds of hours more than you have. This also means that not having a minmaxed build makes it impossible to play missions on the highest difficulty. The NPCs will start having so much effective health and deal so much damage that you'll be unable to progress, full stop.

After a bender of RPGs and survival games, I was looking for something that was more on the lines of a standard shooter that didn't ask more of me than to point and shoot. This game definitely scratches that itch, and playing it now in 2023, it's kind of funny to think that this was originally released before COVID. The level progression is aight for a time killer, missions are recycled but good enough, navigating through the labyrinthine streets and buildings to get to objectives and enemies is actually pretty fun, combat movement is one of my favorite parts, weapons and equipment are fun to collect/build/deconstruct like pokemon for the best stats, world aesthetic is definitely the biggest plus, character customization options are rugged in gray or rugged in brownish gray.

Overall, it's not the most mind-blowing game I've played, but I got it for like $5 during the winter sale, and got what I was looking for, so I'll give it a rec.

Edit: After trying more of the game modes and more difficult areas, I'd say that the freedom to choose your play style is pretty well available. You can choose to stick to the more relaxed single-player action or with friends, or you can go into the PvP areas which are accessible to mid-levels which is reasonable. Definitely takes a bit of playtime to really see some of the more subtle triumphs of this game. Considering calling it a steal for $5 even having to go through the Ubi launcher and a somewhat basic story line. Plenty of dialogue from the recording Easter egg hunt which is neat.

Played this game  on console when it first released and haven't played it since after its first DLC release. Gotta say, it's a whole different game now and feels great. Very unique and interesting concept of a game/story. When it comes to character customization, there is not much for your character model but for cosmetics, there is so damn much, Which for me is a huge plus since I really enjoy choosing different pieces of gear to put on and make the character feel like my own masterpiece. It's really easy to understand how to play and whats going on with not a lot happening on your screen with the HUD being minimal as possible while not sacrificing vital information. In terms of gameplay, my only complaint is that there is a delay from when you fire you weapon and hit an enemy, to it actually having an effect on them. I would hit the enemies with a killing blow and their hit animation won't go through for about a whole second. It's not game breaking but it does feel weird. The Dark Zone, the games PVP arena is such an amazing and unique concept that transforms the game into an extraction shooter with NPCs also trying to hunt you down while you try to secure High Tier loot. It's so intense and terrifying with the thought of being eliminated and losing all your found gear by anyone. I've played it solo both times having a great time in each run but it does become more fun with at least one extra friend

problem with this game is the very poor game design in the rouge system- basically any player in the dark zone can initiate rouge status instantly and it makes for poor game play= the system basically makes it pointless to play in the dark zone and why ubisoft as a company is a failure  - its because the game design is soo poorly half baked its like they dont play their own games.... for instance. a other player can walk right up to u as friendly in the dark zone - so you cant shoot or kill them - and then they initiate rouge - instantly with only a warning until after they are already killing and shooting you- how is that a good pvp experience? its really poor  game design - such a simple solution would be - you can only go into the dark zone at the start as a rouge or as friendly but pass that initial walking into the dark zone- you should not be able to go rouge anymore - and then run away for like  30 sec & nobody can kill a rouge anymore- its the dumbest game design - makes the game super cheese - i never get into a shoot out anymore - its just random guy goes rouge and its always on the rouge players terms - they never go rouge unless they already stalked you and lined them selves up &  when they are friendly and you cant shoot other players - then pop the {rouge} kill you with spamming all their supers and ur dead instantly - a simple fix would be a 5min timer and an alert to the other players that in 5 min or 35 sec this player is going to be going rouge & then when you do its a 5min timer until it comes off } also you cant go rouge within a certain distance from other players as friendly - the punishment for going rouge and the pvp game play designed around it fail  =  -10 game design out of 10 - ubisofts who ever designs ur games is why you fail as a company really should consider hiring someone with common sense & actually plays the game for longer then 2 sec....

The gameplay mechanics feel good. New York looks good. But after a few story missions the enemies become bullet sponges. You also have to empty countless mags of ammo into enemies heads before they go down. After nearly 30 hours (just campaign, 2p co-op), this just became tedious.
As is the case with every high-profile AAA release, production value is very high: environmental detail is very high, guns feel good to use, controls are nice and responsive... so what gives? Bottom line answer: not my cup of tea. It's not like looter-shooters can't be good (Borderlands 1-3 were quite nice with friends), but somehow this just became uninteresting as time progressed. Incremental improvement by loot was too slow for a filthy casual to enjoy, but also there was a strange disconnect between some realism aspects of the game, almost as if it couldn't decide if hoodies are armor or not.

Tom Clancy's The Division is an amazing game. It's been really fun to level up and enjoy the game with my peers, explore the map and become stronger! I used to play on console a few years ago and recently bought it on PC hoping for a better experience (as playing on console was near impossible), however the servers have turned out to be horrible, and I've been removed from countless missions in very important moments. In the Underground, which I may add is a PAID DLC, on countless occasions I was disconnected and respawned at the very beginning, meaning running through all the empty rooms to reach where I was fighting, only to be kicked and have to repeat the process again. Amazing winter atmosphere of New York City during a mid-crisis event. The attention to detail is outstanding. There really isn't anything like it. The RPG-style game-play is fantastic when it comes to PVE and PVP (both co-op and single player). As someone who doesn't usually play RPGs, I can say that The Division is one of my favorite games of all times.

The only thing I wish was better is the story. While you can piece together a story by exploring the world, collecting artifacts, and doing side-missions, etc., the story telling itself definitely takes a backseat in regards to the overall experience of the game. With all the different factions and enemies you face during the game, the storytelling feels like a huge missed opportunity.
Great game, very atmospheric, and real world locations are always fun.

Many look down on The Division as a mid tier, or even a bad game. But I am here to give another view. I think this game is actually pretty great. Me and all my friends bought the game when it was on sale and... Well... All 
 refunded it before they even got past the starting missions. I was different though, I let it cook. The day I bought the game I grinded it for 9 hours and got some pretty good loot. The one very cool part of the game that I was looking forward too when I bought it was the Dark Zone. It's an extraction-based PvPvE (Player vs Player vs Enemy) area where you can team up with other players. There is also different NPC factions that roam the area that, when spot each other, begin to engage in a battle. Now one of my only gripes with the Dark Zone is that, even with good loot, I can't fight any of the enemies. All of the enemy NPCs are either INSANE bullet sponges or just kill me in one or 2 shots. I can't see how I would fight these people. All in all, Tom Clancy's The Division is a great game.
The game is still worth the time and $ even today. Will be for some time given how smooth and unique the game was and still is.

Other than the way armor works in the sequel (which is much better than the bullet sponge enemies here), this is a better game in almost every respect. You can tell that the level designers spent significant amounts of time making sure all the spaces looked really lived in, instead of the generic post-apocalyptic, mostly empty, city of the sequel, populated with a lot of building-shaped blocks you can't go in. Every safe house hub in this game has its own theme and a contact who assigns you missions with his or her own developed personality. Contrast this with the sequel, where the safe houses are abandoned and empty and largely pointless. There is a real sense of survival and desperation as you trudge through the heavy snow, surrounded by ordinary citizens just trying to survive, which is completely missing from 2. 

The sequel was a disappointing cash grab with additional pointless gimmicks duct taped on to obscure the lack of effort. Buy this one instead. Just stay away from the darkzone, since Ubisoft basically gave up trying to police people cheating in pvp around month 4.

I decided to try this out because I REALLY like Division 2, but I can't recommend this. Not even judging it against the Division 2, I personally almost refunded less than an hour in because for whatever reason it will ONLY play in Windowed Mode and if I try to make it any version of fullscreen it freezes in the menu and you have to force quit the application.

Character creator is kind of sad. You can technically play as a girl but you can only have one of 4 very short haircuts. Long hair doesn't exist in post apocalyptic New York. Not even a bun or a ponytail to be allowed.

Gameplay is decent. The traversal is actually still better than Ghost Recon Breakpoint which is hilarious. It feels fluid and smooth. The gunplay also is fairly solid and fun, especially once you get some mods for some of the less accurate firearms. It feels punchy even on stronger enemies. 

Here's the big problem though, sometimes the "Use Ability" and the "Heal" buttons just don't function so be prepared to die if you think you can just heal when you're injured. Either it doesn't always function for some reason. Or the delay is so profound that I'm dying before the animation can play, but I doubt it, when it works it's fast, and it feels good. The heal button not working occassionaly is honestly the biggest problem here. You can really only solo this game now because people have moved on and not being able to heal 100% of the time on command is NOT okay for a AAA game.

Can't really recommend it, Division 2 is out and better in all respects. Hopefully Division 3 will allow more customization, or finally allow us to have red hair.

Ubisoft recently announced they were ending support and taking all of the servers offline for "The Crew." This game was advertised as having single player content. But it requires you to connect to their servers even if you are not playing online. 

What does this have to do with this game? Well it means that all of their games moving forward are potentially just long term rentals that are not advertised as such. This is a very anti-consumer practice. And I cannot in good conscience recommend any games from this publisher when that has the potential to happen to any buyer. Ubisoft could patch these games to remove the online requirement. But they're choosing not to. So that makes their products a very poor value proposition in my opinion.

The Division had been in my library for while (probably bought during one of those sales), so I thought I would finally give it a go.  I'd read some good things about it when it came out in 2016 and really enjoyed my 30+ hours with the game. No playing for a few year, and then come back, it become random crashing simulator, launch the game crash, connecting to server crash, at the character selection background crash, successfully enter the game run for a while crash, shoot and try to get out corner crash, all this crash happen once there are sudden stutter or drop in fps, it look like the game cannot handle  fps drop, once fps drop it immediately freeze and exit to desktop, not any error but a useless Ubisoft bug report that not not function. Overall, use to play the game pretty stable but not longer playable in 2023, not sure what happened, may be window 11, nvidia driver or etc.

Edit:
Update on how i solve the issue, i just revert back to my initial driver installed on my laptop from the time i bought, and it just run so good that when the stutter or fps drop happen it will not crash the game, in fact it will back to responsive again after a few millisecond, so from here what i can said is if you still using pascal gpu or maybe a laptop version gpu, avoid any driver update, as it may not work well with your laptop hardware that bring more issue to you if you use other version driver that is not initially installed on your laptop.

I am a 49 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I first played this game on Xbox when the beta first released, and had quickly found that I was playing in non-stop post full release. While the story wasn't entirely engaging it was still a fun time to be had whenever I had another to jump into the Dark Zone with, and that was before Incursion's had even released. Since getting on PC I've found that The Last Stand released and so too had Global Events arrived. 

The only issue I have with this game truly stems from the fact that I don't enjoy MMORPG (even shooter types) without having someone to tag along, and quickly get bored roaming Manhattan without at least one other person to talk to as I came across random enemy factions. That said, this by no means dictates that the game is boring, and upon re-purchasing very quickly sank about 60-70 hours in the first week (give or take). I still plan to continue playing the game even with the knowledge of the Division 2 having been released, and likely will make the move the closer I get to "100 percent-ing" the game.

One of the best third person game in my experience.
Advantages:
1. Festive city atmosphere. The festive atmosphere of Christmas, which did not take place, the winter landscape of New York. It feels as if time has stopped at the most interesting moment and you are trying to find a continuation by exploring the world around you. Also, the plot of the game is also well developed.
2. Mechanics. Convenient character control, enjoyable shooting, a huge selection of weapons and items, the ability to create different sets (builds).
3. Additional content (DLC). There are three DLCs for this game - the "Survival" mode (similar to the Hunger Games there you need to Survive in the NY in Storm), the Underground (an additional underground world of New York) and the Last Stand (additional invasions, new equipment and a new PVP mode are given).
4. Global events. These events occur approximately once a month and during the events you can collect rare builds for yourself.
Disadvantages:
1. Without proper support. The project was abandoned by the developers after the release of Division 2, although the possibility of creating Division 2 as an part of DLC to Division 1 was possible.
2. There is no new content. After support ended, the developers stopped creating new content for this game.
3. Audience. The total audience size is much smaller than it was before. On average, judging by Steam online statistics, up to 1000 thousand people play. It happens more, but it’s relatively rare, about once a month, when, for example, Global Events take place or there are discounts on the game. Also, there are cases of cheating on the part of players.

Overall, I recommend this game.

One of my favourite games of all time. The sequel is an even better game, but the atmosphere of a cold Winter in New York cannot be beaten. The visuals still easily stand with the very best best on the PC, which shows how far ahIead of its time the Snowdrop engine was, way back in 2016. Maxed out at 4K, on an OLED, with Auto-HDR is a thing of beauty. The audio is also worth a mention because it really helps put you right in the game.

It can be quite a challenging game when played solo. You need to take your time and make sure you are suitably levelled up, otherwise named elite enemies will make mincemeat of you. The game does a good job of introducing you to the various mechanics and it is highly addictive. I would recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of shooters.

Despite being an old game, it will still make even a good PC sweat on the highest settings, but it is very well optimised and I haven't had a single crash in all my time playing it. I have tried both the DX11 & DX12 modes, and both are absolutely reliable and perform well.
The game had many problems at release but most of them became irrelevant or resolved over time. And now this is a great project with an incredible atmosphere.

A Riveting Dive into Post-Pandemic Chaos

Tom Clancy's The Division, developed by Ubisoft Massive and released in 2016, thrusts players into a meticulously crafted vision of a post-pandemic New York City. As a member of the Strategic Homeland Division (SHD), your mission is to restore order and investigate the source of the catastrophic outbreak that has decimated the city. The game combines elements of third-person shooting, RPG mechanics, and a dynamic multiplayer experience to create a compelling and immersive online action game.

The most striking aspect of The Division is its meticulously recreated open-world environment. The snow-covered streets of New York City serve as a hauntingly beautiful backdrop to the chaos that ensues. From the dilapidated buildings to the eerily abandoned streets, the level of detail in the game's environment is nothing short of impressive. Dynamic weather conditions and day-night cycles add an extra layer of realism, creating an immersive atmosphere that keeps players engaged throughout their journey.

Gameplay in The Division revolves around a blend of cover-based shooting and RPG elements. The cover system is intuitive and crucial for survival, encouraging tactical thinking and strategic positioning during firefights. The RPG mechanics allow players to customize their character's skills, abilities, and equipment, providing a sense of progression and personalization. The loot system is robust, rewarding players with a constant stream of gear upgrades and weapons to enhance their agent's effectiveness in the field.

The multiplayer aspect of The Division is a key component of its appeal. The game seamlessly integrates both cooperative and competitive multiplayer modes. In the PvE "Dark Zone," players can collaborate to tackle challenging AI enemies and acquire high-level loot, but the risk of betrayal from other players adds an element of tension and unpredictability. This dynamic creates a sense of camaraderie and distrust, enhancing the overall multiplayer experience.

In conclusion, Tom Clancy's The Division is a standout title in the online action genre. Its immersive open-world design, engaging gameplay mechanics, and dynamic multiplayer experiences create a captivating and evolving gaming landscape. Despite a few initial shortcomings, ongoing support from the developers has ensured that The Division remains a compelling and ever-expanding journey into the heart of a post-pandemic urban battleground. Whether playing solo or teaming up with friends, The Division offers an unforgettable and thrilling experience in a world on the brink of collapse.

Well, what can I say? I came to the game very late in it's life...do I hate it? Meh? No!

It IS a PURE grind, by design. There's very little co-op here now in 2023...everyone is playing solo, and that's fine. It's generally how I prefer to play games these days.

Being an older game, the big bonus is, you can max everything on graphics etc. 

Bottom line. It's not a Far Cry or Ghost Recon style game...if that's what your after. BUT, it is very playable, IF you are prepared to be, or are, a grinder. I've got about 30+ hours invested already, and win or lose, I'm going to "grind" on until I get to the level 30 "god" point. So, maybe another 30-40 hours play-time. That in it's self is enough to justify the "on-sale" price in terms of hours of play per buck.

Just....don't expect to run amok from the beginning. And, definitely, don't stray outside your level looking for glory, or quick rewards.

"The Division" is a third-person shooter that throws you into the heart of a post-pandemic New York City, and Ubisoft has really nailed the immersive and visually striking gaming experience.

The depiction of the virus-stricken city is jaw-dropping. The level of detail in the urban landscape, from the snow-covered streets to the crumbling buildings, creates a hauntingly beautiful setting. The dynamic weather and day-night cycle add an extra layer of realism that pulls you into the atmosphere.

Now, let's talk about the multiplayer – it's the heart and soul of "The Division." Team up with fellow agents to tackle tough missions, engage in intense firefights, and navigate through the chaos of a city in crisis. The focus on teamwork and strategy makes for a dynamic and immersive multiplayer adventure.

The RPG elements, like character customization and skill trees, are a sweet spot. Completing missions and grabbing loot allows you to fine-tune your agent's abilities and gear to fit your playstyle. The variety of weapons and equipment keeps the gameplay deep and constantly engaging.

The Dark Zone is where the adrenaline really kicks in. A PvP area with high-stakes rewards, it's a thrilling mix of risk and reward. The uncertainty of encountering other players who might be allies or enemies creates unforgettable moments of tension and excitement.

The narrative, while not groundbreaking, keeps you invested. The unraveling mystery of the pandemic and the power struggles in the city add a layer of intrigue to the overall story.

Okay, on the downside, the endgame content at the game's launch felt a bit lacking. But credit where it's due, subsequent updates and expansions have tackled this issue head-on, introducing new activities and challenges for us seasoned players.

In a nutshell, "The Division" delivers an immersive cocktail of storytelling, cooperative multiplayer action, and satisfying RPG progression. The visually stunning depiction of a pandemic-ridden New York City, combined with engaging gameplay, makes it a must-try for fans of third-person shooters and cooperative multiplayer adventures.

Just a unique setting with a great story, fantastic even. 
Atmosphere is awesome, especially if you play with limited UI or turn it completely off, You need to setup to get most out of it. Turn on neutral lighting setting, the night time will be more accurate otherwise it is too bright.
This game has great attention to details, Very asset heavy game, majority of the world was hand crafted with attention to details.
Story feels heavy, daunting and it should capture your attention if you are looking for a really well fleshed out fiction and fictional world to explore. The Division will reward your never ending desire to explore very well. 
Original score for the game is sublime, Characters, voice acting, sound effects, weather effects, the day night/cycle, all these are very well done and they help to create just absolutely awesome atmosphere.

Oh yeah, and the first one is better than the second one when it comes to single player. There is no competition here really, second one is kind of trash.

Okay so, the UI is mostly fine when you play the story. Once that is done and you start properly gear up for the "end game", the UI is a complete trash, just garbage, one of the worst UI implementations ever. It is a nightmare to handle large amounts of weapons and pieces of gear you can loot in this game. The UI is this console bound nightmare of the modern gaming, mostly just trash. 

I think that at some point in the development they decided to add "loot" and "RPG" elements in to the game, This is not an RPG nor a "looter game", whatever that is. The UI and the gameplay mechanics do not accommodate these aspects well at all. Looting and RPG elements are tact on rather than being part of the game. This game is a third person shooter first and foremost.

The end game really begins when you have all the weapons and pieces of gear. At that point you can start playing Legendary missions however you like it. These missions are incredibly fun, they are very intense and just a blast to complete. The problem is however that the gearing up process takes forever and is incredibly boring, because this is just a third person shooter and not a Diablo, the gameplay is completely different. It is easier now to gear up than it was before, because ability to buy Classified Cache was added. It takes way too long to gear up, if you spend 20 to 50 hours on story it might take up to 800 hours or more to start playing highest available difficulties with all builds and weapons available.

Obviously 99% of the loot is absolute trash so you need to manage that and the UI is not made for that, it does not display well a lot of different information.
This is one of those "looter this and that" games that in the end have no space to store all available pieces of equipment. Even three additional characters is not enough and you only get four in total.

There are many other issues and problems with this game, but I don't have time for them.

Fun so Far
Good game

[b]The world is so detailed, the graphics breathtaking, the characters (visually and voice over) are convincing and not over the top, and the gameplay is engaging and simply put just fun :)

(Gameplay has improved quite a bit since its rocky launch almost three years earlier. I have been told so by veteran players who started playing in beta stage then left a year in then came back after new content was added; by new content, I mean the game was overhauled).[/b]

[b]Things I like about it:[/b]
[i]- The feel of running around NYC is amazing. The ambiance is like no other game I've played. Super immersive and fun.
- This is the best PC RPG multiplayer experience I've had. Great coop as long as you commit to staying equal level. I've levelled multiple characters with friends after playing through the game on my own first and it's still a blast to try and shoot our way through the story missions.
- Combat is strategic and the AI is smart enough. Enemies at early levels are pretty dumb and the later enemies will use cover/stun grenades/rocket launchers to make your life hell. For me the challenge is perfect. I've not felt safe OR overpowered at equal level (short of endgame set gear anyway...)[/i]

[b]Couple gripes:[/b]
[i]- Menus were made for console and they SUCK for PC. Laggy, sometimes buggy, and you can only see ~5 things at a time on the screen. Really needs a bag mod from an MMO or something.
- Gear-splosion is really overwhelming at first. Stick it out! It gets better when you recognize what you need, but it's a rough learning curve and you'll spend a lot of time inside those (abysmally designed) menus.
- The inventory system is annoying. You can carry up to 120 items in your backpack and another 150 in your stash box (that's for a fully leveled-up character). But here's the thing, the amount of loot in this game is insane, of course you select and deconstruct/sell all that you don't and won't need but still it's such a hassle. You won't understand until you play yourself and see how you keep those precious Classified Gear pieces that drop and they fill your pack :) The game lets you play and level up four characters, so do the numbers and you'll see it's not so bad as long as you level up at least two characters. I did that and now I'm on my third character, taking it very slow and enjoying the game through the lense of a somewhat vet player :)
- The server sometimes gives you an error called Delta blablabla. It gets annoying but the redeeming aspect here is that my game is always saved automatically and that when I log back in I'm at almost the exact spot.[/i]

[b]Overall, I'm really enjoying the game! I hope they can keep the content coming. There are tons of possibilities with this game.[/b]

[h2]My Favorite Game to Never Play[/h2]

By its premise, The Division ponders the question of what happens to society when the human condition regresses and begins to prioritize the self over the many. As far as elevator pitches go, it’s not exactly ground-breaking content, but despite that it’s still one that I think many developers are hesitant to try to work with. It is, after all, very easy to write misery, and pain, and suffering; to kick something while it’s down. Covid gave us a mere taste of the fear and anguish that a pandemic can wreak, and to simply relay that to the player is trivial. On the other hand, to use that grief and then transform it into something evocative and exalting is the more daunting task, but it is a challenge that [i]everything[/i] in The Division was so well setup to handle. I think that’s what burns me the most about this game.

Unlike most games in the genre, The Division is not a post-apocalyptic game. Rather, it exists somewhere in the twilight between the beginning and the end, peering into the heart of chaos where mankind has begun to turn upon itself, giving rise to all its demons — but there are still some vestiges of humanity left in the world, and with them lie the last dwindling rays of hope. Massive’s art teams have done incredible work portraying this: In front of my PC at a comfortable 68 degrees, I feel the chill of a snowstorm as it rolls down the street and smothers the block with fog and swirling snow; strings of colored lights twinkle over the blacked-out cityscape; blood and soot stain fluffy white snowdrifts; music lilts from a discarded boombox, at once soft and tender, and then punctuated by staccato cracks of gunfire. These are not mere remnants of a civilization long since decayed, but the gurgling deathbed coughs of their society, desperate to hold on to their humanity in a world that values it less and less with each passing day.

The Division is lauded for the art direction of its setting, and it is well-deserved praise, but I think most reviews miss the target on [i]why[/i] it’s to be commended. The contrast in these scenes is not merely a visual quality leveraged to make an interesting picture. It is not just beauty to be systematically admired and then dismissed, and nor was the setting some arbitrary choice because “winter looks cool”. Rather, it is an active part of the narrative that holds up the themes of the game despite all of its mishandling, and it would all come crumbling down in its absence. 

Manhattan as we know it is gone, and what is left teeters on the edge of a knife; it’s not the end of the world, but you can see it from 7th ave. This winter is a bitter and isolating cold, rebuffed only by the fleeting warmth of memory — of the love of our people and the communal joy drawn out by the holidays, be they family, friends, or a passing stranger. It's a tantalizing reminder of what was lost and must be taken back, and an anchor to which we can tie ourselves in order to weather the storm — or, perhaps we will drown with it in our sorrow. The question the game wants to pose is, will you save it, or plunge the knife deeper? The Dark Zone, a PvP area where you compete for loot, is a functional embodiment of this theme, and it is what the game seems to have been developed to set up: The prevailing struggle of life even in the looming face of its almost certain doom, and how brave one must be to hold fast to hope. Rage, rage against the dying of the light, all ye good men.

It is environmental storytelling at its finest, and it is wasted on Ubisoft.

[h3]Spoilers Ahead[/h3]

In what is possibly the biggest fumble of its decade, Ubisoft saw all of the incredible potential that the setting offered.. and instead opted for the safest route straight down the middle, taking great pains to avoid shaking things up to any degree. The result is a sterilized story bereft of any intrigue and devoid of any ups or downs, though certainly not for lack of talent, mind. In fact, there’s tons of interesting story in the game!.. Just, not the story that you actually get to play. Instead, all of The Division’s interesting bits are portrayed through any of various collectibles: audio diaries, call logs, and ECHOs (a novel way of digitally reconstructing a scene) being the primary sources. One of my favorite audio logs is a first-person recounting from a college-aged man left on his brother’s voicemail. The first entry is carefree, telling his brother about a woman he had met, and asking his brother to spin a tale to their mother about how busy he is at college — typical student stuff. The next six voicemails detail his life throughout the pandemic: the spread of the sickness, his girlfriend’s symptoms and subsequent passing, scavenging the city and mugging an old man for supplies. By the end of it, he’s desperately warning his brother to get out of town, so as to avoid people like him. These (and the environment itself) are what carried the game for me, but they are too short and easily missed to be leveraged as a vehicle for any truly complex story.

Instead, what you get is just shy of twenty nondescript missions (sole standout being the Russian consulate, which happened to have nice-looking gold crown moldings), where you are tasked with holding the F key on any of a number of control panels before taking on an equally unmemorable boss — and since the bosses are just regular humans (sometimes wearing hockey pads, sometimes not) with an unusual appetite for bullets, the ludonarrative dissonance hits you like a freight train. At the end of the mission, one of your mission handlers calls you on the radio to say “Hey good job, that did something,” and off you go to the next glowing icon on the map. You know that archetype of a terrible DnD player who doesn’t understand how to roleplay and just casts fireball at everything? That’s The Division, except replace fireball with any of a plethora of functionally identical guns. The water pumps are out and the food is all gone, and the civilians are dying of exposure? Damn, that sucks, you should shoot random looters about it.

Arguably, this isn’t so far off what many other games do if you boil it down a bit — after all, there’s only so many ways a player can realistically interact with a game before the scope creep becomes unrealistic — but the issue for The Division is that all of these things happen in a vacuum. As an example: One of the missions tasks you with retaking a power plant so that the lights in the city stay on, and you are told this is a very big issue and people could suffer if you don’t. Mind, you have to be told this because otherwise you would never know, as the lights all seem to be doing okay and nobody is complaining about losing power. While you’re fighting at the power plant, the bad guys threaten to blow up the facility if they’re not allowed to keep hold on it — and you may have missed this if you weren’t listening, because it plays over a fairly quiet intercom and you’re busy spraying thousands of bullets in a building full of sensitive equipment — and what’s more, they even succeed in doing some damage! Fortunately, it is all fixed up by the time you leave the power plant thirty seconds later, and the civilian populace is none the wiser for your efforts. At the end of the mission, you get a data dump that one of your friends on the radio has somehow already decrypted and put together a Powerpoint on, and you are treated to about fifteen seconds of action movie footage of stuff you probably already know just by existing in the world. Suffice it to say that I actually don’t need to be told via video clip that the people who are wandering Manhattan with flamethrowers and burning people alive are, in fact, [i]bad people[/i] who wander Manhattan with flamethrowers and burn people alive. This is self-evident.

You know, for a game that is now almost a decade, TC The Division is actually a fun shooter-looters game. First time playing it in PS4 back in 2017, at first this game has a lot of potential. That is after I saw the mediocre review about this game, such as unbalanced gameplay, unpromising graphics detail, rock-solid AI that was OP at launch, always online and many more complaints.

So, I bought this game on PC for a bit of nostalgia, and actually, it is not as disappointing as back then. The snowy background of NYC was just mesmerizing with a combinations of chaos and modern dystopia of what it looks like when the city almost completely deserted because of a pandemic (somehow ring a bell?). Loot system is also been vitalized nicely, a good set of character customization (even though it was a loot-box type.) and a very aggressive AI that still looks like a tank, but capable to break. The Dark Zone, however, is still hardcore and difficult as I've remember. Good thing I did not stumble upon an OP and toxic player somehow, as the DZ is rarely show anyone playing these old games.

Truthfully, I'm an avid Division player, but not in a competitive way. I'm still playing this game up to Division 2 on both PS4 and PC just to loot something worth to calibrate to the best form possible. It's not flawless as what Ubisoft really wants to show like in their demo trailers, but there's a certain charm that make this game feels good to play. One thing for sure that "hype" is sometime leads to an utter disappointment and this game is one of the example. Sure, they perfected most of the first game aspects to Division 2, but there's a lot of good thing about this game that can be perfected instead of being abandoned completely. But this is just some of the few aspirations of the hundreds of thousand types of gamer and their traits of this game. I felt if somehow a developers can be able to give it a proper touches to this game to a total perfection, the story could be different somehow...

[b]Disclaimer:[/b] I already played and finished this game on Uplay back in 2016-2017. [url=https://i.imgur.com/Qu5Hde3.png]Screesnhot of my Uplay stats[/url] if you want proof.

[h3]Only after rebuying and replaying it so many years later, I realize how utterly bad it really is.[/h3]

[b]1. One of the worst control systems ever engineered for a third-person shooter.[/b]
The utter clusterf**k of controls in Division 1 is a pain to endure for the entirety of the experience. Despite key rebinding options, it won't get any better. Especially in combat, every action feels clunky and slow, particularly those related to movement and skills usage. Overly-long animations and bizarre hard-binds, such as double-tapping the cover button to dodge-roll instead of having a dedicated key for dodging, add even more misery to your journey. In the heat of battle, don't be surprised if you'll mistakenly vault a cover instead of using it, or perform one of the bizarre, useless, time-wasting "tacticool" cover-to-cover moves that will only get you killed, due to their ridiculously long execution times. You won't 'get used' to it, you will only suffer. Devs, this is not a tactical shooter, this isn't Ready Or Not and it's not paced appropriately to be one - yet, the actions pacing - yours at least, while enemies act as fast as a greased-up Irishman at times - seems to be set for that standard.

[b]2. There never is a true sense of build progression or specialization. That's because of how terribly designed progression is as a whole.[/b]
The Division wanted to do something new, by forsaking the standard class archetypes of regular "Looter Shooters" (terrible term, by the way) / Action RPGs and instead, allowing players to mix and match active and passive skills, alongside armor and weapon traits, to create their custom builds. On paper it sounds great, but at the end of the day this system has one big issue: it takes away the identity of single, specialized classes in favor of blander, shallower builds that, as specialized on some aspects they may become thanks to sets and specific Exotic weapons, will never feel like standalone classes with their own identity on the field. Don't even get me started on the amount of grinding for those exotics, either. 

Basically the designers thought that giving more freedom, by diluting and bloating the total available skill / trait pool would, in the end, result in more diversity for the end user, without the need to commit to a specific build and sticking to it (like in most other RPGs, where you choose a class / a hero and that's it). Well, that ended up backfiring, making everything shallower with very little upsides. During your journey from level 1 to 30, you won't feel like you have passed milestones that further define your playstyle, you won't feel like you have been doing some real progress; it will be the same weapons and skills you'll unlock relatively soon, only upscaled due to higher level stats.

[b]3. PvP (Dark Zone) is a terrible, flawed, issue-ridden experience you will not enjoy.[/b]
Implementing PvP as a main game mechanic / mode in this type of game is pointless enough, given how success is far more gear-dependent / build-dependent than actually skill-dependent, but let's say you're suicidal or naive enough to want and try PvP - don't. Seriously, don't do that. Let me describe you the worst crock of s**t imaginable: the Dark Zone, a large part of the map which is dedicated to a PvPvE (so that means hostile NPCs and players all in the same area) experience. 

Do you like to endlessly roam to find that specific Dark Zone-exclusive named enemy that drops that particular piece of gear  / weapon (MAYBE, drop rates are dogs**t in general for Named / Exotic stuff), only get gang-banged by a group of 3 people while being solo? Do you like people having permanent wallhack because it's one of the actual skills in the game? Do you like horrible netcode that wasn't structured nor programmed with PvP in mind, screwing you over with miserable hit detection and trash polling rate every other fight? If the answer is yes, then you only live to suffer, and I salute you, but you still shouldn't play PvP in this game.

Icing on the cake? Some of the legitimately best gear to have is ONLY dropped in Dark Zone, but it's not worth the pain of this mess. You CAN do without. And you better.

[b]4. Far too much repetition in enemies and mission archetypes, even for this genre.[/b]
The definition of insanity? Doing the same thing over and over again. In addition to all of the above, you'll be facing enemies that much too soon become very repetitive, with even the majority of Named and Boss tier ones being only upscaled archetypes of normal ones, just with a whole lot more health, damage and abilities on steroids. In comparison, Borderlands, to name another "looter shooter" most normies will know, is highly varied in this aspect. That says all, I think. The same goes for missions; there will hardly ever be unique ones, and anything outside of main missions, which do have some more uniqueness from time to time, will be a slog to grind, again, I know this RPG subgenre is meant to be like that to some extent, but Division 1 takes that extent far past what is acceptable.

[b]5. Uninteresting story with anonymous, forgettable characters.[/b]
Granted, story shouldn't be taken as a main expectation from this genre of game, but at least some effort should be made to make it at least tolerable or somewhat pleasant. While the atmosphere regarding level design, and the detail, effort put into building the environments are all highly remarkable, credit where it's due, the story surrounding these evocative locations will never be more than mediocre, or at worst, listless. I didn't remember a single character from my 2016 playthrough - no surprise there. 

So that's all folks. I wanted to focus more on why you shouldn't play this game rather than why you should. Simply because I felt like that for this review. Until next time.

Cons: (1) I was afraid of the grinding component of the game before buying, but it is not bad at all. I can go thorugh the main story missions with almost not needing to do any side mission at all and I don't get stuck. (2) The HUD by default is overly populated for my taste (where to cover, where to jump, everything occupies space on the screen). It is quite configurable on the settings menu, I disabled most features of the HUD and it is a lot more immersive now. (3) With the focus on multiplayer, the main story line (which is the part that I personally am interested on) I was afraid was going to be bland. It is not so bland. It is not great, but it is good enough to really enjoy the game playing alone.

This is a game that is a no-holds-barred, jaw-dropping testament to a world teetering on the brink due to what some may call less-than-stellar presidential leadership. It is an electrifying, edge-of-your-seat, and might I add, uncannily prophetic experience where I am definitely not going to admit that I played any part in the ensuing chaos.

In this nation that is on life support, society is hanging by a thread, and it is akin to watching a political thriller turned up to eleven. I would never acknowledge that my leadership may have had anything to do with the state of affairs.

As players get their boots on the ground, they are taking up the mantle of elite agents who are valiantly trying to clean up the mess – though, between you and me, it is those agents who should take the heat. After all, the commander-in-chief does not shoulder any responsibility for the nation's current predicament.

This game is a stark reminder that leadership, in all its glory, can be a two-way street, and the repercussions of one's actions are like ripples in a pond. I have to be crystal clear – I am not taking the rap for this one. It is everyone else who should be held accountable for the havoc in this playground, and I am  just here to set the record straight!

[h1] Initial Review after buying completely blind [/h1]

Seen a lot of mixed thoughts about this game over the years but never really got an idea of what it was about. The sale on it prompted me to look into it, and after getting a rundown of the general premise it convinced me to buy. Here are my thoughts so far for anyone else who might be considering picking up the title for the first time.

I would best compare the game-play as "Destiny 2 meets The Last of Us". Its sort of a looter shooter where the "multiplayer" aspect is fulfilled by players operating within hubs in the overworld and being able to join you for missions, but they're not populating the city, in the same was as Destiny where you'll be doing series of quests within an overworld. The Last of Us aspect referencing not only the post apocalyptic city setting but also the cover heavy 3rd person shooting.

Here are the main points of interest so far:

[list]
[*] The game graphically still holds up, but it feels rare today that a game has made my eyes feel so spoiled for choice when it comes to overworld detailing. There is so much environmental storytelling to appreciate, its all really good

[*] The premise of the story hooked me in immediately, especially after the pandemic it hits pretty hard. New York always looks good in the winter IMO, this game is no exception

[*] So far, the combat seems very easy, but only under the conditions of cover. I've played few games in recent memory that emphasized playing strategically with your environment this well besides maybe XCOM 2

[*] The UI, while admittedly very overcrowded, deserves to be praised for how well it communicate information tactfully while keeping it very "high tech". Maybe a little too high tech for 2018, but fuck it. Its fantasy, it looks good
[/list]

I know it sounds like Im sucking Ubisoft's dick with this review, but I'm honestly very impressed by this game. It seems a lot of people feel it didn't live up to what was demo'd or just hate Ubisoft (fair), but for the new player I can definitely appreciate it for what it is.

TL;DR: 9/10 (so far) Absolutely pick it up on sale, if not then buy it if you like a Destiny style grind.

Played this game at launch and remember how much of a blast it was. The setting and play style of the game is better than I remember thanks to a couple of updates i wasnt around for. As for the gameplay, the gun play is still great from what I remember. Lots of different blueprints for weapons and mods can be found in the massive world and modified to fit your play style. As for the campaign before you reach level 30, it can be kinda repetitive at times. Luckily the different guns you collect and new abilities you unlock keep it fresh trying to figure out what works good for you. I remember this game being very difficult for solo players at launch, but playing through the game a second time has taught me that while some of the enemies you come across will just absorb bullets its not as hard on a solo player as I remember. Survival is still one of the best game modes in any  Tom Clancy game even tho there is very little luck finding a game with other players. DZ seems to still be very popular among the very dedicated D1 players. still very fun. Havent tried queing for raids but I'll try that soon.  Overall, 7 years later this game still offers so much and its on sale a lot

Honestly, I would recommend buying this game on a sale. But other than that, this isn't a good waste of 30$.

The pros:

 +Graphics are stunning, and it runs very well on low end pcs [30-45fps]
 
 +Players in DZ are mostly very friendly [I guess its mainly because they're either new and don't want trouble or just prefer to be passive]

 +Hard mode is actually hard, a little bit unfair at times but overall I'm somewhat of a masochist. Play  at your own sanity with enemies that takes 10 trillion bullets to shred through armor. You'll need your gadget, trust me.

The cons:

  -Connection takes a very long time. Seriously, I had to wait 10 minutes to load in the character screen sometimes. That is, if it doesn't hit me with a BS error because Ubi has shitty servers.
I can assure you 1/3th of my playtime stems from the loading simulator this game sometimes puts me through.
 
  -Loading times for some area takes a whopping 1 minute to load sometimes, you can't run nor hide in the loading area in the meantime. This can be absolutely detrimental in DZ as you'll need a sniper to deal some form of damage while you're stuck walking or jogging in the meantime to the preloaded area. I highly recommend going with a team so they can deal main damage while you support and wait for the area to load. 

 -You best bet you don't accidentally walk inside of an object while its loading, else you're stuck. That's it, you're stuck. Better nade yourself to sleep.

Can be an enjoyable, but it comes with its fair share of repetitive tasks and narrative shortcomings. The game primarily revolves around running the same missions repeatedly and collecting a whopping 331 different types of collectibles, with dialogue that fails hard to add meaningful depth to the story. I even stumbled upon a Easter egg that referenced a summoning to Cthulhu while pursuing phones, which was surprisingly more captivating than going after collectibles.

The story attempt to make you care about characters without providing sufficient reasons to invest in their fates. You're expected to empathize with their losses and hardships, but it's challenging when you haven't had the chance to truly get to know them and their personal stories. SPOILER: [spoiler]The Division agents are introduced without any prior context or connection, you just know they exist and have their families, making it difficult to feel emotionally invested in their betrayal. You can even argue that they had valid reasons for their actions, further blurring the lines of loyalty and motivation.[/spoiler]

Enemies can get glitched inside buildings which lead to mission failures. While using incendiary grenades can sometimes solve this issue, it shouldn't be a recurring problem.

In conclusion, it offers moments of fun, but it's marred by repetitive tasks, a lackluster storyline, and occasional technical hiccups. If you can overlook these flaws, there's still enjoyment to be had.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

This loot grinder disguised as a tactical third person shooter takes place in Man Had 'n Nieuwe Jurk. A city with a legendary past, such as there being buildings with people living in them, doing such on-top-of-the-world things as talking to each other, buying groceries, trading company shares and taking taxi rides. Yes, Nieuwe Jurk is the place to be for shooting games, as you move from one straight angled street corner to the next, where everything looks exactly the same as 5 minutes earlier. This game is slow and boring, like a song about moving to a city that never sleeps, because everyone is on cocaine to compensate for feelings of insecurity and intense boredom instilled by the surrounding city architecture. At least until the cops (or your wife) show up, or when there's a camera around, then you pretend to be innocent.

I really didn't expect to like this so much. A colleague at work suggested I check it out given I like games like Gears, and Syphon Filter (back in the day). 

Surprisingly, this is rock solid. I evidently slept on this as its a very tight, well formed, and well levelled game. Normal difficulty is challenging, but not absurdly so. Enemies are noticably better than you that are above your level (as they should be). Tactics can work around it, but its challenging. Graphics are solid. 

This is a 9/10 for me. No one is playing online nowadays it seems, so this is based off the single player. That said, it plays so well. My colleague showed me little things about 'the Dark Zone', which seemed pretty cool. Lots of mods for the weapons to keep things interesting. So much custom tuning in this...I'm quite impressed. 

I really do recommend this if you get a chance. Played brilliantly on both the Steamdeck on my 4070ti. Highly recommended.

The game still works with it's service. Altough tends to lack or even stopping to work for a few minutes. Suprisingly enough i find that the Division feels better and more grounded than the Division 2. I just hope they eventually just reboot their little genre as there is still a growing community, hungry for such games. 

Something the Division 2 kinda screwed up.

The Division 2 isn't as simple as it's predecessor. I played the Division 2 and enjoyed it but it always was crazy how i felt bombarded with contnet and didn't know what to do next (that happened after i finished with the campaign and the warlords of New York DLC). It is simply too complicated and made the RPG elements uncomfortably compley and in-depth. Especially the optimization stations. The Grind is painful. (not even Destiny 2 is that grindy).

Division 2's multiuplayer issue.

Sure it's a good looking game with lots of things to do. But mostly... you'll just see yourself playing through it all alone. I played their new rouge-like mode and barley had any filled sessions. Because there is too much for such a small playerbase and you cannot expect every activity to be brim-filled with matchmaking people. It is fair to say that atleast 73% of your playtime will be solo and the rest wil be random matchmaking with 1 guy or a full squad.
Something the Divison Did right was that while the content was lackluster, people always managed to get into a session. Even nowadays. You will almost always find a squad to play through daily challenges or global events because it's not a grind-fest with multiple different daily objectives and battlepass tasks like the Division 2 has.

not to mention the only grind modes in the division are underground, survival and resistance aswell as the raids like falcon lost. Those are 4 different modes which is quite frankly enough in my opinion.

About the Division

The reason i like the Division more than the Division two is mostly that micro-transactions are held to a minimum aswell as the atmosphere and lore being pretty stated and rooted overall. You are an agent who is trying to put law and order back into manhattan. You get to kill some crazy factions that have different believes in how to take care of the virus or taking care of themselves. You also have like only 2 factions that are thinking of taking over manhattan which is the LMB and Rikers.

The Divison 2 lore is basically. You are manhunting gang leaders of like countless factions that wanna take over Washington D.C for themselves, like.... Hello??? The virus is barley mentioned so the military could probably take over already like god dayum. But thats probably just me idk. Game is basically "take this new fancy gun and do a crime". You are now just playing search and destroy with a floaty story.

LOOT

The Division had the following in terms of rarity

Worn (The most common and lowest)
Standard (you are getting somewhere)
Specialized ( you have some decent weapons now)
Superior (now you are really getting into it)
High-End (the stuff you would run with in the dark zone)
Classified (Armor pieces for dedicated certain builds)
Exotic (guns with certain minor abilities and unique designs)

The only true gamechanging ones being Classified and Exotic (hell maybe not even exotic lol) which keeps the game simple and enjoyable as you don't have to read damn paragraphs to understand what is better than the other.

Well Division 2 Community i hear you. You guys got the same set-up in the division two but i am being quite frankly. You guys put way too much info into just a simple vest at times.

Division is like "here is a classified armor set that gives your shield ability a huge increase in survivability aswell as giving yourself and your teammates high resistance. We call it the D3-FNC"

Division 2 is like " here is a high end. It has various crazy talents and perks already which you can grind for a few hours to min-max out for something you will eventually remove for something else to rinse and repeat. Yeah sure your storage will be clustered up but you wanna keep them dont you?"

GAMEPLAY

It's pretty much the same aside the fact that body armor is now your new major health and not just basic health. So Your Armor is the only stat to influence your survivability and not your stamina from divison one that was influencing your healing amount, health, and other things while armor was just a flat-out % resistance buff.

there is not much else to say really lol. (atleast from my point of view)

OVERVIEW

I recommend people to still buy the division during a sale as it's story feels a lot more better with the amosphere and scenario you are thrown into. No crazy cyber-hyper tech guy trying to take over DC. Just a Bio-Weapon wiping out Manahttan and NYC. Gameplay feels alright even with the copy and paste encounters and it's a game you can just play shutting your brain off.

Okay let's get started:
This game is exactly the matching description of the iceberg theory. It has a floating surface which is something everybody can enjoy and the "body" hidden under water. You all know everything about builds, bugs etc... so let's move forward. 

PROS:
- unique gameplay and nice ambience. 

CONS:
- there is no control from ubisoft over those who cheat
- there's not a customer service where you can report such people.
- the only valuable content is the content with massive problems (DZ)
- there is no balancing in builds leading to monotonous gameplay.
- there are not any tiers related to skills: farmers stand no chance (even if they are 8v1) against a pro player.
- the game survives on the camel's back of nostalgia and players that are "competitive" (can we really call it competitive if there are not any competitions at all?)
- few servers and fewer people
- toxic behaviour (you can write literally whatever comes to your mind) and still no consequences. 
- useless items/builds
- some activities are just unplayable if you haven't got any friends to play with (don't rely on mm).

These are just "some" of the things which makes this game a shame and a nono. They may sound minor issues (not really) but this is the only game I've ever played that has MORE CHEATERS THAN LEGIT PLAYERS. That's FACTS and It's not debatable. So if you are thinking about getting this game (if ever) just don't bc it's a waste of money and time whichever the price will turn out to be. Have a good day and keep scrolling.

It can get pretty repetitive, but there's enough variety in Skills (and later gear sets) that it doesn't get boring. The atmosphere is great, and the endgame activities like Survival and Underground are great too. The Dark Zone is also an excellent time waster. Just as a tip though, don't do the world tier 5 incursions on challenging if you don't have at least one other person with you. 
Oh, and don't touch PvP. 

Overall, 8/10 game, get gold edition when it goes on sale.

Well, it's been a while since I touched this game. I came back recently to play with a friend and I'd like to say that... its still really good upon a second look! I figured out some AI quirks that make things easier (like how they don't know where you are if they didn't see you leave cover), and the multiplayer progression system is practically seamless! A minor criticism is that it's sort of hard to friend people through Ubisoft, but that isn't a problem with the game.

On a second look, 9/10 game, still a little overpriced for its age, but really great with friends!

I have to say, this is one of the best open-world RPG games I have ever played. The game's atmosphere is simply amazing, and the Dark Zone adds an extra level of excitement to the gameplay. While there are a few hackers in PVP, they are not a major issue due to the size of the Dark Zone. Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys playing open-world RPGs.

[h1][b]Played one mission, played 'em all. [/b][/h1]

[*][b]Very grind heavy:[/b] Looting guns that deal 1% more damage than your current gun or have 1% more accuracy. WoW, how very [strike]exciting[/strike] boring!

[*][b]Very repetitive missions:[/b] If you do one mission, consider that you've already seen all the others: "Find X. Kill Y. Destroy Z." 100+ missions.

[*][b]Enemies are bullet sponges:[/b] To shoot a whole M16 mag just to kill one enemy is stupid. In PvP mode, it can even be multiple mags for a single NPC enemy.

[*][b]Autoleveling enemies:[/b] It doesn't matter how much time you spend grinding the best guns and gear; the enemies will progress to a higher level and continue to be tough-to-kill bullet sponges.

[*][b]Awful safe house locations:[/b] It is very time-consuming to run through multiple rooms and corridors, climbing stairs, just to exit the safe house.

[*][b]Respawning enemies:[/b] It's better to avoid combat; otherwise, you will waste your time, nerves, grenades, ammo, health, and energy packs, all for the sake that the game will respawn the enemies in a few minutes.

[*][b]Bad stimulus for playing the game:[/b] The gameplay feels like an unsatisfying but necessary side job barrier for the sake of the main part: grinding the player's progression and collecting lootboxes.

[*][b]Technical issues:[/b] Long loading times, even on a top 2023 PC; clunky system of entering and exiting the multiplayer mode.

"Tom Clancy's The Division: A Post-Pandemic Playground of Chaos and Strategy"

"Tom Clancy's The Division," developed by Massive Entertainment and published by Ubisoft, is a third-person shooter that thrusts players into a chaotic, virus-ravaged New York City. With its gripping storyline, tactical combat, and expansive open world, this game offers a compelling blend of action and strategy.

Gripping Post-Pandemic Narrative (4/5):
The game's premise revolves around a devastating smallpox pandemic that has plunged New York City into chaos. As an elite sleeper agent of The Division, your mission is to restore order, investigate the source of the virus, and confront hostile factions. The narrative is engaging, with well-executed lore and a sense of urgency that keeps players invested in the unfolding story.

Expansive Open World (4/5):
New York City in "The Division" is a sprawling, open-world playground. The level of detail in recreating the city is impressive, from iconic landmarks to eerily deserted streets. The dynamic day-night cycle and changing weather add depth to the atmosphere. The open world encourages exploration and offers a wealth of side missions and activities.

Tactical Combat (4/5):
Tactical combat is at the core of "The Division." Firefights require strategy, cover usage, and teamwork, especially in the game's challenging PvE and PvP modes. The variety of weapons, skills, and gear available allows for diverse playstyles, making encounters both intense and rewarding.

Dynamic Loot System (4/5):
The game features a loot system that keeps players engaged and constantly searching for better gear. Finding and customizing weapons and equipment is addictive, and the game continually offers opportunities to upgrade and fine-tune your character's abilities.

Multiplayer and Co-op (4/5):
"The Division" provides a robust multiplayer experience. Players can team up with friends or join random squads to tackle missions, challenges, and the Dark Zone—a tense, PvPvE area where high-value loot is at stake. Coordinating with teammates is essential, and the multiplayer component adds depth to the game's replayability.

Technical Performance and Polish (3/5):
While "The Division" excels in many areas, it has faced some technical issues and bugs, particularly at its launch. However, Ubisoft has continued to support and improve the game through patches and updates, which have addressed many of the early problems.

Conclusion:
"Tom Clancy's The Division" offers an engaging and chaotic post-pandemic experience, combining a gripping narrative, tactical combat, and a vast open world. It's a game that rewards teamwork, strategy, and exploration. While it had some initial technical hiccups, ongoing support from the developers has improved the overall experience. If you're a fan of tactical shooters, online multiplayer, or post-apocalyptic settings, "The Division" offers a thrilling and immersive adventure through the decaying streets of New York City.

Title: An Urban Battlefield Unveiled

Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5)

Review:

🏙️ In the heart of a crisis-stricken New York City, The Division emerges as a gritty and immersive third-person shooter that thrusts players into the chaos of a society on the brink of collapse. 🏙️

🌆 The setting is the game's shining star: a meticulously detailed, virus-ridden Manhattan where familiar landmarks now stand as haunting reminders of a world turned upside down. The graphics paint a desolate yet captivating environment, from snow-covered streets to abandoned offices. The game captures the tension and unease of an urban battlefield with remarkable accuracy. 🌨️

🔫 Combat is a blend of tactical gunplay and RPG elements that gives weight to every bullet fired. The cover-based system keeps you engaged in intense firefights, requiring you to strategize and adapt to enemy movements. The cooperative gameplay, whether with AI-controlled teammates or fellow agents, elevates the experience as you work together to outwit enemies and complete objectives. 💥

🗺️ The open-world design offers a sense of freedom as you navigate through both the main missions and dynamic encounters that pepper the landscape. Exploration yields valuable resources, and the dark zones—a lawless no man's land—add a unique twist by encouraging a blend of cooperation and treachery.

💼 The loot and gear system introduces a sense of progression and customization. Equipping gear that suits your preferred playstyle becomes a satisfying endeavor, and the wide range of weapons and equipment options ensures diversity in tactics.

🚫 While the setting is rich, the narrative might not fully live up to its potential, often feeling like a backdrop rather than a driving force. Some mission design can become repetitive, and the endgame content might leave some players wanting more variety.

💻 Technical issues, especially at launch, did hinder the overall experience for many players. However, Ubisoft's commitment to updates and patches gradually improved the game's stability and performance.

In conclusion, The Division offers a gritty and atmospheric experience that immerses you in a crisis-ridden urban jungle. While it might have its flaws and a narrative that falls short in places, the game's world-building, tactical gameplay, and cooperative elements make it a memorable journey through a pandemic-ravaged New York City. As you gear up, fight to restore order, and navigate the challenges of the urban battlefield, the promise of camaraderie and thrilling gunplay awaits around every corner. 🏙️
