I know this one by reputation, a bland Ubisoft game to add to the pile. Never played it when it came out because there were far more exciting games to play but recently I’ve been appreciating doing something mindless to unwind so I gave it a try.

The Division, it seems, are a bunch of government sleeper agents embedded in New York ready to shoot the locals if they misbehave. Someone’s created a particularly virile strain of Smallpox and infected the population with it, causing chaos in the city and leading to the government to quarantine the entire area. The locals who survived have gone a bit feral and you’ve been activated to whack their noses with a rolled up newspaper.

I’m really not sure I’m on board with the premise of this game. The only reason you would put sleeper agents into your own population is to silence people who don’t agree with you and instil fear in the others making them all fall in line. It’s got a bit of an air of fascism about it. We appear to be playing an SS officer in a post-apocalyptic New York.

First thing I noticed is the user interface clutter is everywhere and it’s difficult to make out what’s going on. It’s ridiculous. The world is actually quite pretty but it’s hard for me to appreciate it because there’s floating text boxes and numbers all over my screen. I’d expect something like this from an MMO where the numbers are arguably more important than whatever’s going on in game but for a third-person shooter, you need to be able to spot the enemy far off in the distance or creeping up from the side without all these distracting interface elements clouding vision. You can turn these off in the options but perhaps it should have been a choice to turn it on.

You’re part of the second wave of sleeper agents being flown into New York to secure the city and work out what happened to the first wave, but first there’s a bit of a bandit problem in Boston to sort out. There is a brief moment where you see a looter execute an innocent but after that it’s just “you should shoot all these guys because we say they’re bad”. I see no characterisation here. Like, why what seems like half of New York decided that looting and murdering everything in sight is the best response to being locked in the quarantine zone with little law enforcement baffles me. There are plenty of unfazed civilians just hanging about on the streets so presumably there are supplies being sent into the city. Their actions strike me as the actions of an organised crime syndicate taking advantage of the situation but it’s never suggested that they’re working together. I find it hard to believe that half of New York simultaneously decided that they were better off taking matters into their own hands.

The rest of the game is based around doing missions for the three wings of your operations base: security who are trying to regain control of the city; medical who are searching for a cure and tech who are restoring the city’s essential utilities to working order. You can build new facilities for each, unlocking new skills and abilities which aid combat ranging from kinda neat to complete waste of time.

It’s a cover-based shooter and I generally find those a bit frustrating. Running about and shooting things is how I like to play but in this it’s a great way to be riddled with holes so plunking yourself in front of a wall is the only way to survive the more spongey enemies, and it’s extremely unforgiving in this aspect. Then I shoot out with my incredibly inaccurate gun with an infuriatingly long reload time and hit the lovingly detailed environment around whatever psycho I’m trying to kill. And I’m sure there’s some objects that the AI can shoot through but might as well be Kevlar when I try to return fire.

Each district has a recommended level and a safe house that acts as a regional hub, each run by a quest-giver with a maximum of one quirky trait that they will crowbar into every dialogue line. They’re supposed to be funny, I guess, but every time I finished a side quest to grind my level up for the next mission I would wonder if the looters are looking for an extra member. It’s supposed to lend the game some comic relief but the game is so grindingly gritty in both tone and gameplay that it comes across as desperate and annoying.

It’s a sandbox world that’s got a remarkable level of detail but it doesn’t feel very alive. There’s the occasional unreactive civilian blissfully wandering about a warzone and the groups of street thugs but most of the time is spent sprinting down boring straight roads to get to the next load of people to shoot. It could have done with some faster method of getting around. Maybe not a car as the clutter on the road would make reaching any sort of speed impossible but a motorbike would have worked well. Hell, I’d have taken a fucking moped.

That MMO comment earlier maybe more justified than first thought. The game itself identifies as a co-op shooter but everything’s quantified. Enemies have visible levels and health bars, randomly spawning side activities scatter the world and there’re other players milling about safe houses you can group up with. It’s like Destiny with even less of a soul. Gear you pick up have three stats which increase your overall damage, health and ability strength, the idea being you can equip different kinds of items depending on how you want to build your character.

The entire base of operations world hub is even more cluttered than the world and it’s quite hard to work out which NPCs are for what, or where they are. I eventually stumbled into the loot box room, which figures for an MMO. They offer cosmetics but they’re all variations of winter, hunting and hiking gear. Running about murdering civilians in a large purple hat might have been fun but this game is far too boring for that. You can collect key fragments from dead elite enemies, ten of which are required to have a go on the slot machine, or you can just buy them but, like I’ve said, it’s not worth it.

I wouldn’t say I enjoyed the game. It passed the time and scratched an itch but there are better games that would have achieved the same thing and that wouldn’t have made me feel like a Nazi in an insane asylum, and once that itch had been scratched, it was too vacuous an experience to muddle through.

A gorgeous experience from the snow falling down onto decrepit streets to the beautifully somber electronic soundtrack composed by Ola Strandh. Packed with solo PvE content, any player interested in delving into a loot-filled, post-apocalypse New York City will have fun at some point in their adventure. Experiments heavily in diegetic user interface elements and has a beautiful amount of analysis and thought put into crafting the user experience, all the way down to the usage of in-world UI framework. This reminds me of a stunning, snowy, and electronic tech demo that was expanded upon for a matter of years. If you are ready, take the chance and venture through the somber, snowy streets of Manhattan and feel the snowdrops.

Update | Coming back to this game constantly, with endless Survival DLC runs and solo legendary missions. This game could scratch an itch you never knew you had. The atmosphere alone is enough of a comforting getaway.

For an explorer-type player this game is absolutely worth picking up in 2023, even knowing it will no longer be added to or improved.

I played The Division 2 first, and that game feels smoother in some ways, but The Division 1 feels inspired in a way D2 doesn't. The world of D1 is alive: you help citizens who approach you and often thank you with items, they lean out windows to react to your fights, you can explore apartments throughout New York and actually find clothes in dressers rather than random boxes in back alleys. With the outbreak more present it feels like there's urgency to what's going on. Even upgrading your New York base of operations feels more obviously important and interesting than the White House in DC. I never felt like going back to the White House, it was disconnected from me and I didn't see how what I did in game affected it. In D1, that route is made clear, and the NPCs you bring to the base have personalities. Even the dogs in D1 have more personality, and interact with each other and you in different ways, instead of always running away.

They're both fun, but in D2 I felt like I'd arrived too late and was mopping up someone else's mess with half the story already told. D1 feels like the game that was intended to be made.

I never normally leave reviews but I had to for this!
Don't hesitate to get this game. It's fantastic and so underrated. 

After purchasing the second one for about £3.50 (because it kept crashing) I could see the potential and thoroughly enjoyed what I could play of it despite the crashing. Then when the first came on offer for £3.89 and didn't have the crashing problem I got it, and trust me, at that price it's an absolute bargain. 

I agree with a lot of other reviewers: the first one is better than the second. It's very tactical, the story's amazing, I love the realism unlike any other survival game you'll play, the arsenal's phenomenal and boy is it fun. When it seems a bit samey, it's time to do another mission, and play out the rest of the story of the game. But don't settle for going solo all the time. I always play single player myself but when this game paired me up with the matchmaking missions, that is when I had the most fun. Do a bit of matchmaking Co-op play now and then even if you prefer lone wolf because it's great and you won't regret it. 

Surprisingly, I have added this to my list of favourite PC games of all time! It's not in the Best of the Best folder, but it's in the Best! I would even go as far as to rate this higher than a lot of the Far Cry games. Yeah, definitely. It deserves 88%, not 70% Eh?  It doesn't quite get 90% because it will still crash when you try to select Fullscreen in video options. But this is resolved by selecting Windowed Fullscreen, which is actually Fullscreen so you don't need to worry. Weird. And the fact that very occasionally guys will spawn out of thin air because the game doesn't realise you already killed them earlier and have just returned. It's nothing major. I wouldn't downgrade it much just for that so I'm giving it 88%, no less than 85%. Yeah, definitely get this game. It's epic, with a fun rating of 10/10 especially when matchmaking.

I've always been late to the party when it comes to video games. In other words, whatever my friends were playing 5 years ago is what I'm playing today. So it goes with The Division. I stumbled across this game the other day and I can't even rightly recall what intrigued me about it but I nonetheless pulled the trigger and bought the base game/DLC bundle on deep discount. At the time of writing this review I'm over 64-hours into the game. I've "100%-ed" the base game, I've been working my way up the ranks in both the Dark Zone and the Underground, and am loving every single minute of it. This game (especially in a post-COVID world) has struck a very fine and resounding chord with me. The dark and visceral atmosphere; the widespread hopelessness and desperation; the brutal battle between the enforcers of law and order and those who seek to dismantle the entire system and burn it down. It's all incredibly immersive, and we haven't even touched upon the gameplay itself. Your agent movement is excellent; the gunplay is really fun; the cover & move tactics are intuitive and fluid; the loot system feels very balanced; and all of the different game modes are just icing on top of an already delicious cake. This game is easily a Top 5 for me now, and though I've yet to play The Division 2 I am at least glad the series is enjoying a new sense of vitality with the advent of The Division Heartland and, to a lesser extent, The Division Resurgence on the mobile platform. This is a fantastic fictional universe and I hope it continues getting the attention it deserves.

As an avid gamer, I must say that Tom Clancy's The Division left me profoundly underwhelmed and utterly disappointed. From the moment I started playing, it became apparent that this game was riddled with issues that hindered any potential for enjoyable gameplay.

First and foremost, the storyline in The Division is utterly forgettable and cliché-ridden. A generic virus outbreak scenario in a post-apocalyptic setting is nothing new, and the game does little to add any originality or depth to the narrative. The lackluster storytelling made it hard for me to connect with the characters or care about the world I was meant to save.

The gameplay mechanics were equally as frustrating as the storyline. The combat system felt clunky and unpolished, making gunfights more of a chore than an enjoyable challenge. The AI of both enemies and allies was laughably inept, with enemies often behaving in absurdly predictable patterns, while friendly NPCs regularly got stuck in objects or ignored the player's commands altogether.

Furthermore, the game suffered from a severe lack of content. The open-world map was vast, but it was mostly filled with copy-paste buildings and repetitive side missions that quickly became a tedious grind. The promise of a dynamic multiplayer experience was not fully realized, as the multiplayer modes felt half-baked and failed to deliver on the excitement of a shared online world.

To add insult to injury, the game was plagued with numerous bugs and technical glitches. Frame rate drops, connection issues, and crashes were all too common, turning what should have been an immersive experience into a frustrating exercise in patience.

Even the graphics and visual design, which were initially praised during the game's marketing, failed to live up to expectations. The environments lacked the level of detail and realism one would expect from a modern AAA title, and character models often looked awkward and lifeless.

Finally, the game's microtransactions and pay-to-win elements were an obvious cash grab, leaving a sour taste in the mouth of players who were expecting a fair and balanced gaming experience.

Overall, Tom Clancy's The Division fell far short of its promises and potential. Its lackluster storyline, clunky gameplay, technical issues, and exploitative monetization make it a regrettable addition to any gamer's collection. Save your time and money for a more polished and enjoyable gaming experience elsewhere.

I imagine that New York is like this in real life. 10/10 game.

It's a third person cover-based shooter with an emphasis on loot acquisition and combat optimization. While there is player-vs-player gameplay, mostly it's player-vs-environment (AI).

While the shoot-and-loot gameplay is nothing special (Borderlands does it better) what really sets the game apart is the atmosphere and setting.

The plotline involves a devastating bioweapon attack on New York City that causes a collapse of law and order. You are a part of the titular "Division", a secretive government agency that is activated after all else has failed. You've certainly got your work cut out for you, as the city has been overrun by escaped convicts, looters, and a group of insane sanitation workers ("Cleaners") that are determined to burn the virus out by killing all potential hosts.

And really, this is the best post-apocalyptic depiction of NYC, or any city for that matter, that I've ever seen. You've got ransacked police stations, looters in the streets, civilians scavenging for food, an impressive dichotomy of normal city life juxtaposed with signs of societal collapse...

Graphically the game is stunning. The Snowdrop game engine has some excellent weather effects. I never thought I would say that snow in a video game could be beautiful, but in The Division it is! There are furious blizzards, lighter snow flurries, high-resolution footprints in the snow, and even a light dusting of snow on your character's shoulders after they've been outside for awhile. But it's not just snow that looks good. Skyscrapers reflect light, glass shatters realistically when shot, the barrel of your machine gun will turn red and steam after prolonged fire, there's just so many little touches that make for a great presentation.

Unlike many Tom Clancy games, the Division does NOT have realistic combat. There is no "one bullet kills" type of realism, and no emphasis on bullet ballistics. Both the player and enemies have a large health pool. Most bosses can take a full magazine of bullets to the face and keep fighting as though nothing's the matter. While some people will complain about these "bullet sponge" enemies, I felt that overall combat in this game is fun. If you're looking for more realism in your Tom Clancy games, try Wildlands.

Combat mostly involves small arms firefights against groups of enemy infantry. While most of the enemies are just guys with assault rifles, a few of them will be specialists that present additional challenges. For example one specialist is a shotgunner that will deal major damage if allowed to get up close. Another specialist is a guy who hides behind a shield which protects him from your bullets, but he is vulnerable to flanking attacks. Many of these bad guy specialists have weak points; hitting the weak point will stun/damage the enemy.

The cover-based shooting makes good use of a cover-to-cover movement mechanic. There is also a blind fire attack mechanic which gives reduced accuracy but leaves you less vulnerable to return fire.

A big part of the game is unlocking skills. As you progress through the storyline you earn Medical, Security, and Technical skill points which can be spent to upgrade your base of operations. An upgraded base of operations gives you permanent buffs as well as more options for combat optimization. Extra shopkeepers can be unlocked, free loot can be gotten, and most importantly you can invest in your character's skill trees. You can have up to three skills available at a time, and which ones you choose will have a huge impact on how you play. For example, one skill is a "seeker grenade" that, once thrown will actively hunt down the enemy and explode. Another skill is a "support station" that provides constant healing as long as you remain within the area of effect. Skills can be easily switched out; there is no such thing as messing up your character build and having to re-spec your character.

Your base of operations starts out as a dilapidated post office, but as you gradually build it up it eventually becomes a high tech base teeming with trained personnel. Awesome!

This game has been described as an "RPG" but the storyline is linear with no plot choices to make. The character development of your NPC quest-givers also leaves much to be desired. Your Division boss (Lau) and the Medical supervisor (Kandal) were I guess supposed to be written as assertive leader-types, but instead they just came across as being arrogant jerks. The other two main NPCs in your base (Benitez, Rhodes) have better dialogue but are still mostly forgettable. The game's main antagonist (Keener) is poorly fleshed out and absent for most of the game. It is never adequately explained why Keener's lackeys (the LMB) are actually fighting you. On the plus side, there is a large amount of backstory flavor in the form of audio diaries (cell phones), written situation reports, survival guides, ect.

As your character completes missions they earn experience points which lead to level ups with better stats. Each mission you take on will have a recommended level, and I strongly advise that you respect it! Completing a level 20 mission when you are only level 19 is going to be tough. Completing that same mission at level 18 may be outright impossible. But overall for most of the game experience points are plentiful, side quests give good rewards, and there's little incentive to go grinding for XP.

Once you've made it to the maximum level (30) and beaten all the main missions you'd probably think the game is over, right? Wrong! The Division is actually only just starting because a slew of end-game content gets unlocked at that point! Completing the main campaign (with side quests) will probably take about 20 hours, but the end-game content can easily occupy you for HUNDREDS of hours of fun!

In the end game, since there are no more experience levels, you instead will be looking for classified gear sets and exotic items. These are rare loot drops, and indeed your character progression will slow down considerably. I do feel Borderlands handled late-game character progression better, because you could still level up and put points into your large skill tree, while in the Division by level 30 you've already maxed out your skill trees and levels -- better loot is all there is left to optimize your character with.

A brief synopsis of end-game content:

*High value targets, which are basically randomized open world quests of variable difficulty.
*West Side Piers, a new area that opens up with its own quests.
*Underground (paid DLC), a randomized quest line with its own level-up system and unique combat modifiers.
*Survival (paid DLC), you're stripped of all gear and must survive both the weather and your enemies.
*Last Stand (paid DLC), team-based PvP games.
*Daily and Weekly Challenges, replay the main missions under specific conditions for extra rewards.
*Incursions, the hardest PvE missions in the game, they must be completed with a group.
*Resistance, survive as long as possible against progressively harder waves of bad guys.
*Dark Zone, the main PvP area in the game, you can be killed by other players (rogues) but there is also PvE content. You can actually enter the DZ before level 30 but it's probably better to wait until the end game.

The Division also contains a crafting system, a weapon recalibration system, and unlockable cosmetics and emotes. There's a bewildering variety of currencies, probably more than any other game I've played (it should've been simplified).

The game music is high quality and helps to set the mood. Fighting criminal gangs in a neon-lit Times Square as a blizzard rages and the "Times Square" soundtrack plays is an incredible experience!

The Division can be played solo, but I strongly recommend playing it with friends. Up to 4 players can join up together for some great co-op fun!

If you're looking for a shoot-and-loot game with great atmosphere and fun co-op, try out The Division!

[h1]Real Good Tactical and Duck & Cover Mechanics![/h1]

{{ Disregard Time Played! I have have this game on Ubi Connect for ages and have Gold Edition and played the heck out of it! Only got it here to connect my game to Steam! }} 

I love this Game and its Mechanics. I think the Duck and Cover mechanic is hands down done so good in the Division games. The game has good story and good gun play with a fair amount of customization for you and your weapons and skills. I love the openness of this game, how big it is in scope of the New York backdrop. The graphics are real good as well. 

I love how they even added hit areas on the mobs that if you shoot it, it will have an effect on them as in hitting a ammo bag or a med pouch will cause them to freak out or take damage and even explode ! Also you can use the environment as well as in hitting gas cans or tanks to help attack your enemies by lighting them on fire or dousing them in chemicals to make them freak out and then take them down. 

I also love the RPG aspects of the game as well. You can lvl up your gear and weapons and your character via skills and perks. Weapons can also be modded to give you extra stats and fire power. 

I know this game has been out for a good while now but it's still a very good game to play today Solo or with Friends! I mostly play Solo and still enjoy the heck out of it. I also have no issues with missions on Solo play. 

So if you like a bit of a Tactical RPG in 3rd person, I say add this one to your cart! More so if you have never played a Division game!

Ubisoft seems to be great at creating video game levels, but god awful at creating video games.

The game starts out fairly strong, but as the RPG elements come more and more to forefront it gets kind of ridiculous and boring. Bosses that take 20 head shots from high calibre rifles to kill? And this is a Tom Clancy game?

[b]"The Division" is an RPG shooter that concentrates all these characteristics that made modern Ubisoft games famous and that's both good and bad. Undeniably, the highlight here is the gorgeous city of New York represented in full detail and offering so many places to explore. Also on the positive side the battles have great pace and require clever tactics, the coop experience is well implemented and there is a vast selection of equipment, weapons, skills and customization. On the other hand the developers are stuck to the logic "quantity over quality". The main story is shallow, the missions are repetitive and unrewarding and the game lacks purpose. You will spend most of your time on the menus rearranging equipment or mechanically traveling from one spot of the map to another killing thugs without exactly knowing why or just pursuing more loot. It is a decent game when experienced in co-op but don't expect anything groundbreaking and certainly don't play it alone.


Manometer: 6/10[/b]
 

The good
- Awesome visuals. High quality graphics with detailed models and realistic dirty, warn out textures. Atmospheric lighting with good day/night system and a bunch of great optical effects like fog, flares and volume lights. Weather system is also nice with convincing snowfall and storms.
- Fantastically designed world. Its New York is one of the most impressive and detailed cities you can find in any game out there. Each neighborhood has its own identity and unique characteristics visually. Except of the ground zero roads the city has multiple layers to move on, from terraces to sewers and there are many gorgeous interiors to explore. Most of them are designed with real care and attention to detail. They have even replicated existing New York's landmarks.
- Except of one or two things the gameplay mechanics are smooth and well implemented. Characters' movement, changing direction and climbing are fluid enough. More complex actions like reloading, changing weapons or deploying skills are also very responsive.
- Well implemented battles with great pace. Although they are not as fast as other shooters you can feel the tension and survival agony. Multiple battle events (from explosions to snipping) and elements (from turrets to supporting stations) happening simultaneously offer a strong experience.
- It is deep enough. It offers a huge amount of weapons, updates, modifications, skills, clothes, abilities and lot more that give you the opportunity not only to upgrade your character gradually but also personalize her/him according to your taste.
- Seamless coop experience. Easy paring and team creation. Some of the difficult missions require strategy and good communication between the team members in order to beat them, which gives the coop mode an extra plus.
- Although there is a small variation of enemies they are well designed and convincing as thugs or gang members.
- Decent enemies' AI. They have a wide repertoire of movements and they use them cleverly. Depending on the battle's state they will follow different tactics deciding each time if it's appropriate to shoot, run towards you or take cover. Yet, there are some moments that they seem to not give a single fuck.
- Animations are realistic and smooth and they overall feel convincing enough (except when it comes on taking damage or express pain).
- Well built menus. Although the developers had to deal with a ton of information, skills and weapons they managed to arrange them pretty well inside a very functional menus' structure. You will need some time to get used of them though.
- Great sound design. Environmental sounds feel realistic, voice acting performances are decent and battles' sounds are satisfying.
- There are some parts with awesome rock music that enhances the atmosphere and manages to give you some strong survival/battle vibes.
-  Although the core story is weak and barely exists there are many points of interest scattered inside the world. Recorded messages, distress calls, visions, memories and hidden easter eggs will give you a fairly good idea of the city before and during the pandemic and will encourage you explore more.
- There are regions that offer a PvP option against other teams, although due to its age the online part of the game is pretty dead.
- All these similarities with the Covid pandemic are impressive and kind of creepy.
- It can offer a lot of hours of playtime and it is cheap when it goes on sales.

The bad
- The main story is shallow and unfortunately all these clues you collect from echoes or recordings seem to be too fragmented and unimportant. They don't really contribute each other in order to form a bigger story. Moreover the game's own structure manages to convince you that there are more important things to bother than the lore. It is supposed that you try to retrieve the city from some bad guys, but it does not give you the reason to do so. You will end up travelling from one spot on the map to another and just shoot guys in an endless pursuit of xp and cash without even having time to stop for a while to hear your radio or watch an echo beacon. And it is not the players' fault, but a designers' choice to hook you on looting.
- I would like a bigger variation of enemies and some more missions' scenarios. You experience them all during the first dozens of hours and after that they are almost the same again and again. The only thing that changes is the place. Side missions could be more rewarding too. They end up giving you just xp or some weapon or a silly index instead of a real conversation with an NPC or a cut scene video or an important event. Ubisoft just wants to fill the map with content without wandering whether it deserves your time or is repetitive.
- This dynamic leveling up system seems once more to be in vain. As you gain more money the weapons you can buy get more expensive. As you gain more firepower the enemies you face get stronger. Yeah, you can always have some easy kills facing a level 10 gang when you are at level 30. But the actual battle experience against enemies of the same level as yours never changes. Similarly the overall game difficulty on acquiring better equipment never really changes.
- You have to spend tons of hours on your inventory rearranging things and cleaning up a never ending mess from the continuous looting. Most of the gear you gather are expendable. Before realizing how awesome your new weapon is you have already found a new, even stronger one. Nothing has real value and you can never attach emotionally to your equipment (if such a thing exists).
- Weak atmosphere that feels a bit generic. The city is too crowded and active for a pandemic/quarantine situation. You literally cannot find a city block without its local gang, wandering couple or beggar. It should be more dark and lonely out there. It's a pity for the fantastic 3d model and the great lighting/weather effects.
- Gameplay mechanics are good but without  jump and crouch commands sometimes your character feels heavy and restricted. Also a lot of times the cover action can be sticky or irresponsive with a result of some annoying deaths.
- Enemies often don't react to the bullets they receive, while some pain or death animations are unconvincing. There is no blood too. Let's say that satisfaction through kills is not game's strongest asset.
- The city could be more destructible. Only few selected things get affected or destroyed during the battles. This also affects the feeling of satisfaction during the battle.
- Some minor bugs here and there. Some menus tend to glitch or give false information. Few disconnects and desktop crashes. Bad optimization at some critical points like battle respawning. After a death you will often respawn in the middle of the pit with a result of instantaneously dying again. Annoying.

This (In my opinion) is the better of the two Division games.

This game holds a much more sinister and realistic tone to it, focusing the story on more being about the People in New York who fell to Corbin-98, The Dollar Flu I mean.

The map for this game is 1000x better than Division 2's due to it feeling more alive with the citizens roaming around. In a two hour game session for this that I have done recently, I have watched 4 citizens die due to starvation and fall infront of me. I have rescued countless JTF soldiers, quelled apocalyptic gangs and restored some functionality to the Post office. (Still in the process of fixing everything up on my new run through the game)

Division 2 however, is much more of your Hollywood style Apocalypse scenario, less focused on the people and more focused on Agents and Dissent amongst them. In Division 2, you are working through the capital of the US and while its a cool area, they neutered the New York that you know from Division 1.

Division 1 has been a constant for me, because while I hate the combat system being cover-to-cover and catering heavily to consoles and controllers ( I use M&KB and play on PC clearly), it still feels like I have at least a decent bit of control over my character's movement. I've heard about them  making a New Division game named Heartland which is supposedly going to play a lot like Tarkov and all those games, and I will not be joining in on those.  The reasoning is simple, I don't like those style of games, but for those of you looking into getting a Co-op(potentially.. May want to bring friends in) RPG Story that has a very serious and tragic atmosphere, Definitely get this game.

this game it's a gem, or could it had been if Ubishit didn't make The Division 2 Crash Simulator and keeps pdating this game that lost his light.

I played it for a few hours and uninstalled. Just so you know, I was interested in solo and a bit less co-op. PvP was not important at all.

- Character customization is very limited. Not that I expected a huge list of faces and hairstyles, but GR:W has a lot better customization.

- Weapon tiers. You will get the same weapon many times, but with better stats. I hate this kind of system in non-MMO games. Level up character, find/buy same weapon but with higher tier and better stats.

- Consumables. Hardly useful system. This game is not about survival.

- Arcade damage system. You need to use many bullets before your enemy will die. There is a system similar to weapon tiers. Same NPC, but stronger. More bullets to waste.

- Difficulty. As a solo player, I have to say that some missions had too strong enemies for one player, Maybe because I had weak weapons (doubt it). Few players sometimes spawned, but some of them were not very careful and made fatal mistakes.

I don't know what else to say. MMORPG-Action. Installed GR: Wildlands shortly after my last launch and it's a lot better game.

Side note: Ubisoft has a serious tendency of making almost identical games. AC/FC had towers and crafting using animal ingredients. When they changed AC with AC: Origins, they added a different/more deep crafting system, weapon levels and looting. Looting and weapon level system appeared in The Division. I don't know about FC5 and GR:B. I heard that Ghost Recon: Breakpoint adopted few things from Division, and many players don't like it. Will latest Watch Dogs use something from Ghost Recon? Will Far Cry become Assassin's Creed in first person?

Tom Clancy's The Division is a post-apocalyptic third-person shooter set in a stunningly detailed version of New York City.
The game's graphics and sound design are top-notch, creating an immersive and engaging experience that draws you into the game's world.

The gameplay is challenging and rewarding, with a deep progression system that allows you to customize your character's abilities and gear as you gain experience.

The game features a seamless integration of single-player and multiplayer modes, with co-op play and PvP modes that keep the gameplay fresh and engaging.

The sprawling open-world map is full of secrets to uncover and enemies to defeat, with a variety of mission types that keep the gameplay varied and exciting.

The game's story is well-written and engaging, with interesting characters and a rich backstory that adds depth and meaning to the game's world.

The Division is a game that rewards exploration and experimentation, with a variety of playstyles and approaches that allow you to tackle challenges in your own unique way.

Overall, Tom Clancy's The Division is a fantastic game that offers a thrilling and immersive experience for fans of action games and post-apocalyptic fiction. With its impressive graphics, engaging gameplay, and deep progression system, it's a must-play for any gamer looking for a challenging and rewarding experience.

there are many other aspects of the game that make it enjoyable. The game's online features, including co-op missions and the Dark Zone, are well-designed and provide an engaging multiplayer experience. Additionally, the game's RPG elements allow for a lot of character customization and progression, making it fun to experiment with different builds and playstyles.

Before I give you the proper review of why I think this game is worth picking up, here is a story of how I played this game 3 separate times, if you are not interested, feel free to scroll down and get to the actual review. When I was a kid I got a brand new Xbox One, in the package this game was included via activation code. I played the game and didn't get very far and one day I lost the account with the actual game itself. This year I remembered that this game exists and bought a physical copy so I could play and finish it. I wasn't playing it regularly though I made it pretty far when my Xbox One ( yes the same one I was gifted a while ago ) finally broke ( problem with the battery brick, easy replacement though I couldn't find anyone selling the damn thing ). Out of desperation and sheer determination to beat the game I bought it on Steam while on sale. Having been exhausted from playing this game almost the third time, I still managed to push on.

The review starts here - I recommend picking this game up at a a sale, also during the winter due to the immersion. I'm not going to spoil the story even though this game is pretty old, but I'd say it is solid and kept my attention through the whole playthrough. 

This game is a looter-shooter, you are greatly encouraged to explore and by doing that you can find some amazing loot including weapons, modifications, gear and cosmetics for your Division Agent.

What I really like about this game is the gunplay. The game is played like a cover-shooter. Essentially, you are going to get killed EXTREMELY quickly if you are in the open ( duh ), so finding cover is essential to your survival. When in cover you can blind-fire or peek-fire also you can move around or vault the cover that you are hiding behind. Pretty straight forward. 

The missions are exciting, the main missions act like dungeons. You'd start with one area and push through enemies and obstacles until you reach a boss that you need to defeat in order to complete the mission in order to earn your well deserved loot and XP.  The side missions are...well...repetitive to say the least. The side missions are separated into 4 types of side missions. The regular ones which give you XP, loot, blueprints and so on, the Medical Wing, the Security Wing and Tech Wing side missions which each give you, aside from the XP, points for its corresponding mission type in order to upgrade your Wings at the Base of Operations. 

Base of Operations acts as your main...well...base. There you can upgrade the Security, Medical and Tech wing each of which give you upgrades,perks, talents and new abilities that you can equip. This encourages a lot of mixing and matching in order to find your perfect and preferred playstyle. Like healing people and staying healthy yourself? Try the Medical abilities! How about becoming a tanky, unstoppable killing machine? The Security abilities are for you! Do you wish to be a mastermind of gadgets and other smart devices? The Tech abilities have got you covered.

There are PvP and PvE elements in this game. The PvP aspect is found in Dark Zones-they are very dangerous places which reward you greatly, there you can meet the toughest of enemies, rogue agents and even other people all of which fight in order to get the best of loot. I haven't played much of the Dark Zone but from what I've gathered it's pretty fun if you are interested in PvPvE.

This review vaguely and barely covers the actual content this game has to offer, it's best you see a professional review or take a look at some Youtubers playing the game in order to see if you like it. Overall I'd give this game a praise for being so immersive and atmospheric, trust me, even exploring this beautiful city, which is New York by the way just never gets boring. I strongly recommend getting it on sale, especially, as I've previously mentioned during the winter so you can grab yourself a cup of hot cocoa, wrap yourself in a blanket and enjoy the sullen and atmospheric ambiance of the, now, infection overtaken New York.

For many years I believed that Ubisoft, the "French" "game" "development" "studio", was only capable of making good games like "Assassin's Creed Odyssey" (2018) or "Alone in the dark" (2008), or introspective games that are very innovative like the titular title "I am alive" (2012). I was sorely wrong, Ubisoft can actually make epics games *pun intended* like the "Division 1" (2016). I imagine Mr. Tomas Clancy wrote a story about Seattle on a normal day but I think Ubisoft forced him to make it about New York during a dastardly pandemic (Covid Virus).  First off, the garphics in this game are almost as good as Call of Duty Advanced Warfare (GOAT cod Imo), Seattle is modeled very well and you almost feel like a homeless man will stab you at any moment, just like real life Seattle. Secondly, the factions are very interesting, they have the poor people faction, the italians, the faction based on a race of people that I cannot point out, and the call of duty faction. All the factions have "unique" "gameplay" "features" that add a fun challenge (dark souls) to the game. Another aspect of the game that is really neat (interesting) is the dark zone, in the dark zone you get the fight homeless people who collected social security and you also get to fight other players. You can take your enemies EBT cards and extract them to progress. Overall the game is very enjoyable and makes me have a good feeling. If you want to play a "videogame" developed by the creators of the "Division 2" (2018) I think this is the game for your. 8/10- ilovespreadingmisinformation

This Review is only possible for me in comparison to TD2, because I played that one first. I only got back to TD1 out of interest. I played it back in 2016 but never finished it. That way my entry was relatively fresh but biased by the strong impression of TD2.  TD2 makes very obvious, where the game has aged well and where not. But even with that comparison it is very much still worth playing. Since I may sound a little negative during the rest of the review, due to its comparitive nature. let's put it that way: if TD2 wouldn't feel better than TD1, sth. would be wrong with TD2, not with TD1. The comparision doesn't make TD1 a bad game. It provided strong roots for what TD2 became to be and it is worth getting back to it even after 8 years and the release of its successor.

Worldbuilding, graphics and Level design: I don't think that either TD1 or TD2 is better or worse. But the snow in New York gives TD1 a special touch, which is hard to compete with. The graphics are certainly not up to date. But I was surprised, by how well the game still looks. At this point It is aging, certainly, but holy moly: these are still very impressive graphics. I enjoyed the in-mission-levl-design in TD2 way more, though. Right after finishing the game I have trouble memorizing, more than two mission settings. There were just fewer moment, in which I was taking a break , because I liked the lvl so much, as I still do in TD2 after 120h playtime.

Game Systems and overall gameplay: while TD2 is a real rpg-LOOTER-shooter, TD1 is way more a rpg-shooter in which the looting aspect is tuned down quite a bit. The advantage being, that you don't have to open a box every five meters, but it leads to the problem that you very weak for a long time at the beginning. This gets resolved towatds the end, before you hit the lvl cap. But until then it can be frustrating at times. It became even more prevelant in the endgame:. The progression system changes with lvl 30 into a gear value system which is bound to a world tier system. The higher the gear value, the higher wiorld tier you can access up until tier 5. it took me less than an hour to get there, So for the moment I feel very much overpowered in comparison to the main campaign. In TD2 it took me 10 h.

Mission design: the mission design while more fleshed out in TD2 are very similar in both games. The side missions are a different story. though. There are ideas in TD1 I'd like to see more of in TD2. This concerns i.e. mace like puzzles under time pressure. While I the time pressure didn't make a lot of sense to me, I liked the missions themselves. The maze like aspecct is still very present in TD2, but not as a core element in a mission. Other missions were less favorable. But I liked the pool of experimentation I could feel within the game and in parts I wish they would have evolved them in other ways, than they did in TD2.

Moment to moment gameplay: the gameplay in TD1 feels more unpolished than in TD2. There is a certain stiffness to how it feels and a certain dryness to how it sounds. While not being bad, it felt unpolished to a degree, where it was not game breaking at all, but I was never able to shake it off, which certainly broke the immersion. I don't know how it would have been, if I hadn't played TD2 before. But since shooters evolved a lot since 2015, I guess I would have had the same feeling. This gets better in the end, when you can upgrade the weapons. But it remains to be a feeling I can't shake off.

The fights also came very much down to a gamble: there are always time slots in TD2 in which I know, I can deal damage without being damaged myself and there are ways to make that part of your strategy. In TD1 it was very much how much damage can I deal, before the enemy kills me and I have to have to get back in to cover, because we are always shooting at eachother at the same time. There seems to be no reaction to the damage I inflict and it made the fight for me more stale than in TD2.

End game and dlc policy. It is in the end game, where opinions are split within the TD community. The systems are a lot more fleshed ot in TD2 of course. TD2 has the same core. But defining your gear works different and the specializations are not present in TD1. TD1 has none the less a compelling and interesting gear system in the endgame. I may like TD2 more in that regard, but I don't think anything is missing in TD1. It is a very good system with a lot of variety to choose from. 

TD1 does however have more end game activities to choose from than TD2. All of them are fun and provide a variety of challenges. TD2 falls short in that comparison and it is one of the reason TD1 is still played in 2023. You may not find players in the main campaign, but you certainly find a solid enough player base in the end game. Some game modes are split, due to the dlc, but it is not as bad as in TD2, where players are split in two different progression and gear systems. Still bad practice, but not as bad as in TD2.

There is a lot more to say. But all the details I could mention. would only lead to one conclusion: having played TD2, it was obvious to me that the ideas in TD1 are very much the base for what TD2 became, and it is strong base. I prefer TD2 at this point. But TD1 is a game very much worth playing in 2023. It is very imppressive, how well it held up and I highly recommend it 8 years later. And even though it is not supported anymore, there is still a relieable player base to play the end game content with. I wouldn't pay full price. But it is on sale often enough and definetly worth going for.

The Division is a third-person shooter video game that has been around for several years, and it still holds up remarkably well in 2023. The game is set in a post-apocalyptic New York City, where players take on the role of a Division agent tasked with restoring order after a viral outbreak.

One of the best things about The Division is how seamlessly it allows players to play through the story missions with friends. The game offers a fantastic co-op experience, and it's easy to jump in and out of games with friends. The game is designed to be played with others, and it's a lot of fun to team up and take on the game's challenging missions together.

The gunplay in The Division is top-notch, and it's one of the game's standout features. The game offers a wide range of weapons, each with its own unique feel and handling. The game's cover-based mechanics also add to the tactical nature of the gameplay, making for a rewarding experience.

Graphically, The Division still looks fantastic in 2023. The game's attention to detail is remarkable, and it's clear that a lot of effort went into creating the game's immersive world. From the snowy streets of New York City to the dark and eerie underground tunnels, the game's environments are both beautiful and haunting.

PVP in The Division is also intense and rewarding. The game's Dark Zone offers a unique and challenging experience that is sure to keep players engaged for hours on end. The game offers a wide range of rewards for successfully extracting loot from the Dark Zone, making it an incredibly satisfying experience.

Overall, The Division is an amazing game that still holds up incredibly well in 2023. The game's co-op experience is fantastic, the gunplay is amazing, and the graphics are still impressive. The game's PVP is also intense and rewarding, making it a must-play for fans of the third-person shooter genre.

It pains me to give this game a negative review because it does several key things well, and I've found quite a bit of enjoyment out of it (see the 107 hours played as of this review.)  The cover-based shooting mechanics work really well, and the gunplay of The Division feels great at times.  However, the enemy design is just lazy.  There are too many copy/paste enemies, and too many bullet sponge enemies (especially the bosses.)  All the factions feel very similar, so the majority of combat encounters are very similar.  Lastly, the story and characters are bland.  I don't remember the names of any character, nor the motivations of anyone besides a few faction leaders.  It is really sad that such a great setting for a game was wasted like this.

Great game. I have over 50 days of playtime on Xbox before I switched to PC. In my opinion, it's superior to The Division 2 in every single way. They dumbed down the PvP in Division 2 way too much, making it rely too heavily on what gear you're wearing rather than your skill. The only real knock against this game is the hackers/cheaters that you'll occasionally encounter, and you will encounter them in PvP because Ubisoft doesn't care about banning them, no matter how many times they are reported even with video evidence. Highly recommend also getting the Survival DLC. Game is also great for solo players as 99% of it can be played by yourself. It's a looter shooter, so be prepared to grind the same enemies, missions, etc over and over for loot. It plays well with a controller, but you will be at a disadvantage because a lot of the guns in this game have some considerable recoil, which is very difficult to control with a controller. The game is also really well optimized and it doesn't require a super computer to run, which is surprising because it still looks incredible for how old it is now.

This game is ubisoft's masterpiece... which is sad because it only reached its maturity after most people wrote it off as a messy p.o.s.

You can tell this game had an extremely passionate team designing the map. It's absolutely phenomenal. There is no corner of the map that seems bland or plain. It really feels like a world. If there was no dialogue in the game at all I would still understand what is happening perfectly, as the map is so well designed I don't NEED anything else. 

The gameplay may be lost in translation to some, as fps players (which make up the majority of the market these days) may have a hard time understanding the concept of shooting a guy in the head more than once without killing him, let alone hundreds of times. I totally agree, it seems strange, and I was once the guy who said something along the lines of "why not just make them more heavily armored than have them be so bullet spongey?" But now that we have the division 2, we see that the first one probably was the better of 2 evils. 

The game design outside of the immediate third person looter shooter experience is very well executed. The upgrading the base with materials gained from accomplishing encounters in the open world is pure genius, and it feels so good. It feels so rewarding to unlock different abilities with each upgrade, and it the changes to the base of operations gives us a visual representation of the change we are responsible for in the game world. 

Speaking of rewarding, the incursions may have fallen a bit short, as they became the only way to gain actual gear without having to deal with pvp, which at the game's peak was full of tryhard groups of 4 with the absolute most up to date meta gear you could hope to get. Playing solo against them, well let's just say nomad gearset bonuses weren't cutting it. 

But DLC came to the rescue, survival was the dlc of a lifetime, the grandaddy of all extraction shooters, it was perfect. Not a single bad thing to say about this experience, besides the fact that it was before its time, so people again failed to grasp the concept, which is sad now because it seems extraction shooters are all the rage with EFT, Hunt:showdown, cycle frontier, etc etc. being so popular. Makes me wonder why ubisoft won't re-release an anniversary edition of a standalone version of Survival.

I'm feeling especially nostalgic about this game as I'm having a hard time coming to terms with the fact that it's no longer popular, and hasn't been for years. The second game is an insult to this one.

Tom Clancy's The Division is a disappointing entry into the third-person shooter genre. While the game has some solid gameplay mechanics and an interesting premise, it ultimately falls short in many key areas.

One major issue is its lackluster story. Despite being set in a post-apocalyptic New York City, the game fails to create a compelling narrative that engages the player. The characters are forgettable, the dialogue is uninspired, and the overall plot is predictable.

Another major flaw is the game's repetitive gameplay. While the cover-based shooting is serviceable, the missions all feel the same after a while. The lack of variety in enemy types and objectives makes for a tedious experience that wears thin quickly.

Additionally, the game's online-focused nature can be frustrating. The always-online requirement and forced multiplayer elements can be a hindrance for those who prefer to play alone or without an internet connection. The game's matchmaking system is also hit-or-miss, leading to unbalanced matches and frustrating experiences.

Overall, the game is a disappointing title that fails to live up to its potential. While it has some good ideas and solid mechanics, its lackluster story, repetitive gameplay, and frustrating online elements make it a hard game to recommend. And let us not forget the borderline scam advertising this game did before release.

I was a bit harsh in the original review 7.3/10

It's a "loot and shoot" style game with bad loot and bad shoot

First and foremost, the game requires a constant internet connection which introduces delay and weird hit reg due to internet shenanigans

LOOT:

Most items you get from enemies are incredibly weak, assuming you get anything. Most enemies either drop nothing or cosmetics/crafting supplies

Fighting bosses is no exception, with the mission completion rewarding usually being more substantial than any loot dropped from enemies during the mission. For most of the time I played, my weapons were either crafted or bought, as dropped weapons are just so terrible.

SHOOT:

Gunplay feels bad; weapons have no impact, enemies are bullet sponges, and cover controls are terrible, especially compared to other games (Splinter Cell Conviction, Gears of War, etc.). Due to the aforementioned loot problems, there is this jarring cycle of "weak enemies" --> "overpowered enemies" --> "weak enemies" as your loot becomes weak and is then replaced. This same effect occurs in other games (EX: Borderlands 2) but is not as jarring, with a good legendary being able to be used for multiple levels without ever being necessarily overpowered.

OTHER:
There are 3 mission types: Encounters (fight enemies and defend an objective), side missions (run around and interact with some objects while fighting some enemies), and main missions (fight through this building and shoot enemies). Main Missions are the only ones that are actually fun, but they're recommended levels are so spread apart that you have the grind unfun missions to even stand a chance. In addition, the game's narrative is incredibly weak despite an interesting premise, so you aren't particularly compelled to play through the missions to see the story through.

TLDR: Play Borderlands instead

Simply one of the BEST game I have played ever.
Yet ALSO one of the biggest DISAPPOINTMENT after playing for 4,000+ hours.
I LOVE this game, and ALSO HATE it for the same time.
Let me explain.
This game is truly wonderful. The graphics, the story, the dialogues, the lighting, the atmosphere are gorgeous!!
The mission, the gears, the weapons are so good too.
Everything in this game is so good until I started to play seriously in the Dark Zone.
One of the reason I keep grinding and keep playing is that so I can improve my gears and weapons.
With better gears and weapons and right mods, I can improve my chance of winning against other players.
Yess Of course I also need skills.
Yet in the Dark Zone, I found out so many people are cheating. After thousands of hours of playing in the Darck Zone, I finally understand that there are many different types of cheaters. One with absurd one shot kills and teleporting, others with aimbot, others with RPM, and no recoil cheats, and anothers are so good in cheating subtly to stay under the radar. They are so good in using cheat and they pretend to be just like any normal players. Some are well mannered, most are total bullies. Those are the ones that cheated and stay so proud of it.
All of these are happening every day and so little things the developer can do. People say the game is dead, the developer does not put enough time here any longer. Yet I believe it is not because of their lack of time, but it is their ability limit to solve this cheating problem. So most people who play in the dark zone have mentalities "no cheat no games"
To close my review:
This is a truly wonderful games, but also with so many cheaters destroying the Dark Zone.
DO NOT ever buy this game if you want to play against other players in the Dark Zone. Save some time and avoid huge heartaches.

I gotta say, apart from the lack of player base The Division has at the present, I am enjoying the game even though I only purchased this a few weeks ago, approx. June 25th 2020. A ton of micro intel to find in the way of people's phone's, laptops and signals etc. Then there's the story missions to complete. After that's all said and done if you you like risking getting annihilated you can step into the "Dark Zone" which is PvEvP (person vs environment vs other players) if another player or team of players go Rogue they can take you down while you're trying to have you precious loot "Extracted" to your Chest i.e your Storage. Because you can't just walk into the Dark zone and leave the Dark zone with items you have looted from chests / storages in game. You have to fight the NPC's and other player's potentially to extract it out of the area. A nice little addition. Seldom have I encountered another player that has gone rogue and if some one did on several occasions other players will hear the "Extraction announcement" I'm certain, if they are in the Dark zone and have come to help or at the very least see what the commotion "Shooting / fire fights ) is all about.

Once you have hit level 30 you wont level any further but you will access more of the sleeper / sub content in the game that becomes available only to the player once they've hit Level 30. Then you attain a new level system. Your items you collect have a level system of their own as well Mods which give strengths, weaknesses, buffs etc you can make your weapon stronger through attachments which have mods as well as you armour (Gloves, vest, jacket, pants, holster) those also have slots to which you can also ad mods.

The environment is very immersive, some of the buildings you can explore for intel items or while on missions. Snow covered streets, fog and snow combination some times painful on the eyes. in saying that I usually fast travel to another area. Some of the NPC's throughout the city you can interact with and you gain a tiny bit of xp. Well i think I blabbed on enough.

I purchased the game for less AUS $15 so Overall and so far I have thoroughly enjoyed my experience and the gameplay.

alright,
i'm not a big fan of most rpgs, because i'm very picky when it comes to 'what do i spend my money on', and, especially with the launch of cyberpunk, i'm not a fan of broken-on-release games from dev teams with tight schedules. that being said, i also hate pay-to-win. i know, shocking to be asked of from rpgs.
the division is a pretty good game, bar pvp elements. i remember playing this with gamepass on console and it was an experience like no other: it wasn't call of duty in terms of being a shooter game; or call of duty in terms of paid guns; or call of duty in terms of... yeah you get the point, i played a lot of call of duty back in those days, and, hell, i used to be a god-tier sweat on a controller. but going from 'competitive first person shooter with children' to 'casual third person shooter with ai' was like transitioning from being a coal miner to a blacksmith. just felt like i could do waay more stuff and not get team killed for sucking, because i'm the only one on the team. :)
i'll tell you this for free though: [spoiler] sub-level 30 missions can be extremely difficult if you don't take the time to grind for gear before completing them. i say that as a person who nailed a level 28 mission at like level 26 or 27 because [/spoiler] i'm just too good.
other than that, thank fuck this doesn't have a battle royale mode. ish.

The Division is one of the best games of the last decade. What started off as an overly ambitious 'next-gen' project for Ubisoft turned into a semi-disastrous launch and a game that seemed to peter out and die with many problems affecting players' enjoyment of a game with such amazing potential. And to Ubisoft's credit, they brought the game back from the brink and turned it into something resembling the masterpiece it was meant to be. I have played through this game into the endgame on two different platforms eight different times - I always maintain 4 endgame characters to maximise weeklies/loot in general. 

By version 1.8, The Division became a hidden gem that only the most dedicated fans recognised. A lot of people wrote the series off and never touched it again, but now if you talk to anyone about this game, the applicable phrase is "if you know, you know". The expansions and major updates offer incredible game modes like survival, legendary missions, incursions, PvP, wave mode, underground (procedurally generated sewer crawler with hidden surprises). 

The builds you can make with the gear and weapons in the game are so effective and rewarding to put together and use, and the game is perfectly designed for you to work on your main build and improve it using resources. 

I will play this game again in the future. I always come back to it. It's legit. JUST TRY THIS GAME RIGHT NOW. JUST DO IT.

Ubisoft launcher BS!!! Stay clear!

The biggest problem I have with Ubisoft is ... Ubisoft themselves.

I got lured in on the Steam store with a discounted sale and grabbed this game years back. Install, start ... wait no!
"This is a Ubisoft game. You need to register an Ubisoft account" ... done (The only reason I have an account with Ubisoft at all and also the reason why I NEVER BUY anything on their store with a passion of 100 burning suns), now let's finally game  ... NO "This is a Ubisoft game, you need to run the uPlay launcher" (that's what it was called before they renamed it "Connect"). So I closed Steam, started uPlay, logged into my Ubisoft account and now gaming at last .... NO "you bought this game on Steam, you need to run Steam client". Oh, and you need a permanent Internet connection too. On BOTH launchers ...
Ok, it is an multiplayer co-op game. But there is also a Singleplayer story part. But guess what? Same BS applies for entirely Singleplayer Ubisoft games too - e.g. all the Assassin's Creed games, etc.
So you need to run both uPlay-launcher AND Steam client to be able to run this game and you need a live internet connection. No playing offline or on a train or a flight. 

Double-DRM \o/  - Why suffer through one when you can have more?

So, now they start re-offering games on the Steam store again, after years, when they learned painfully that their hubris of being big and untouchable allowing them to stand completely on their own, disconnected from the world  in their own little walled garden was completely unfounded.
So they are back. You can buy Ubisoft games again on Steam and get lured into their launcher and account BS ... again...

Oh, and did I mention this game is mostly dead nowadays? Lucky to find someone in the game to co-op with you. Maybe you can convince a friend, but still you need both launchers, an account and permanent internet. Plus you are lucky if Ubisoft doesn't close down the servers and support soon, as they do for their games. 

No gaming for YOU! Thank you for your "purchase".

As for the game? Good. Fun. Interesting story and decent difficulty to not spoon-feed you. But as others have mentioned: stay away from Dark-Zone and PvP. Rogue bullies and cheaters are taking the fun out.
But story playthrough with a friend in co-op or some nice random party members is enjoyable for a while.

Would I still pay 30 € / $ ...whatever ...? Heck no! Why is it fashionable nowadays to ask full price on AAA games or similar, even after years (e.g. Far Cry Primal, Far Cry 5, Watch Dogs 2, Assassins Creed down the line of Black Flag even, Ghost Recon, etc. same story - insane pricing for sometimes 10 year old single player games).
Get it on sale if you really really want to.

First of all, game looks great and runs so dang well. I appreciate that, but the mechanics are so inconsistently balanced. You can play this in single player, but its really really hard. The game almost forces you to play with others because of the insane difficulty. Grinding is a chore, you get/earn very little resources from 90% of missions. its not very rewarding, many times did i find myself struggling and discouraged. The cover system is very well made but the game forces you to use that system 75% of the time because of the massive damage buffer on most enemies. Sometimes i found myself "cover camping" because some of these enemies can one-shot me if i poke out. Also you do not heal to full health in combat so I am forced to used the limited medkits i have and that i can only replenish at a safe house or base. I want to play something i can enjoy by myself and not rely on others to complete missions with me. Im sorry, this game is not for me.

3k hours edit (2023):
"An unfortunate downfall to one of my life's most memorable moment" 

To my best teammates: Kai, Jimbox, BillySheldon, BK, KCStoner, LilFish, Manzymzk, Jagxsta, KimboR91, and many more...

This is where it all started, meeting all walks of life in the extraction zone next to DZ1 West Entrance. By gone the countless times chased down by the whole lobby as a battle squadron of 4-men unstoppable team with dedicated fragger, IGL, healer, and support. The sweat the scream and shit talking all happened in-between the screeching noise made by EMP flashbang, shock turrets, and seeker mines. By gone the time when everyone runs around in circle and your heals have to be a green puddle or else be ready to be flame by your team. By gone the time when people of different nations team up to fight the hackers. We lived through the 1.3 time when 1 shot sentry build dominated the scenery, that's when the whole world think I'm a hacker and y'll stick by my side. We proved them wrong. Patch 1.5 the most balanced patch with countless drama happening, but we stick together, but this is when some of us decided to take hiatus, we thought it's only for a short time.. We were wrong. Last Stand and everything else is story for another day, perhaps when the memories come back I will add more. We showed them how good team work and dedication can achieve. We've achieved the unthinkable, pulling down those insane 4v16 in the DZ, getting more than 100 rogue kills regularly everyday. You guys even helped me made it to RANK 1 in the WORLD for rogue kills (Friz) for 2 weeks or so. We were having so much fun without knowing it to be the last time. 

Thank you guys for the experience and no matter where you guys are I hope you guys thrive, just like how we did in-game.

UPDATE: This game doesn't work on Windows 7 despite the system requirements stating it can. Ubisoft has retroactively disabled Windows 7 support for their launcher, Ubisoft Connect.
This hasn't affected The Division as much as other titles, but there are some titles that are completely unplayable now because they don't work on new Operating Systems but can't launch them on old ones that can actually run it. And this restriction of Windows 7 isn't for any reason other than cutting costs, the launcher itself still WORKS on Windows 7 if you copy an old version of the .exe file into the game, as Ubisoft Support themselves recommends.

SUPPORT THE OS YOU RELEASED THE GAME ON OR DONT SELL THE GAME.






After hitting level 30 I finally feel like I've experienced everything there is to do in this game. That is to say that I've done all the story missions and the same 3 side missions over and over until I hit level 30.

So far I'm feeling like there's absolutely no end game content at this point and there's nothing to do for level 30's except get killed by hackers in the dark zone. Yes, this game is FULL of hackers at level 30. The user's weapon stats are all saved client side and there's no check in place to make sure the files are unmodified so people can edit their stats to have damage be 1,000,000 (literally) and their armor stat be over 5,000 and they run around the darkzone just killing people for fun. (Edit:) I've looked into this issue more on the steam forums, and from my investigation, people are using CheatEngine. The simplest and most widely known file modification program around. I simply can't believe that Ubisoft didn't foresee this issue before the game launched since there was 'hacking' in the beta as well. Actually I can, it's Ubisoft. I've had this happen many times after reaching level 30.

The characters feel bland and uninteresting after you talk to them the first few times. Each safezone vendor has their own "personality", I put personality in quotation marks because they're simply different stereotypes that always stick to the same stereotypical archetype without fault. That is to say, one of them has allergies. No other character traits, literally just blathering on and on about the histamines and pollen in every single conversation. Then you have the stereotypical PTA homeowners association mother who's excuse for you doing her missions is that they're lowering the value of the neighborhood. There's the typical New York tough guy who threatens to 'crack ya head in' every chance he gets and so on. They're very boring, very repetitive and provide nothing to the story other than a different voice actor for the same 5 side missions over and over. They also seem to go out of their way to make note of the characters that are homosexual. Sure, that's all well and good but it's simply out of nowhere and just pandering for more attention. Sure Dr Kandal, I'll do a mission for you. Oh, you had a wife? Oh, and EX wife. Do you want me to save her? No? What's that? She's not even in the game? Why bother telling me then. 

At this point, absolutely DO NOT spend more than 25 dollars on this wreck of a game, maybe once they finally add some content or fix the "hackers" if you can even call them that.

Update: Incursions are out! I've never played them because of a bug when you attempt to join an Incursion in progress, you get stuck at a loading screen loop until you close out of the game and reopen it. But don't let that fool you, Ubisoft is patching the game. They've nerfed every farming method players have found so far. The Incursion update added a bug where each challenge mode boss would drop 4 high-end gear items. This was fixed in a hotpatch the day after Incursions were launched. Meanwhile; players are still falling through the ground for no explainable reason, getting booted off Ubisoft's god awful servers, getting CTD's hourly and, since the Incursion update, some players are even reporting their characters deleted with no word if they'll be recovered at all. All the while Ubisoft is busy patching all the bugs that don't affect players or the game in a negative way.

From all of these "new" experiences with the game, I would absolutely recommend you to STAY AWAY from this game completely, ignore it even if it goes on sale. The game had potential but Ubisoft simply killed it with their typical business practices and only seem to be making it worse each update.
I will gladly change my review to recommended when/if it ever becomes playable or enjoyable because it really truly did have a lot of potential and my hype for the game pre-launch was through the roof.

If you asked me what i would think would be the most "just okay" game was, it would be The Division. Sometimes simple is better. For me this game did just enough to hold my interest. Obviously. 

it has just enough character/gear customizing to hold interest. Especially considering anything drops anywhere (with rare exceptions). Which means you will fall into a diablo like mentality with gear hunting. With that gear hunting also comes lore item hunting as well. So plenty of things to run around and do. 
I spent most of my hours solo. Only grouping for content that was not doable/practical solo. top tier difficult things. You would run out of resources before completing it solo. 
BUT you can  gear out by your self, i did. Grouping will get you there 20x faster though lol.


Its weird writing a review on a game that already has a sequel to itself. 

IS this game worth playing now? for a new player, id say no and yes lol. Indecisive and unhelpful answer. 
The population isn't there. and the people who are on are so far ahead of you with gear and content, it'd take you forever to get close enough to them to be invited to things. Doable, yes, but probably not fun. your choice though. 

Would i recommend? yes. If you are like me and get addicted to gear chasing at times and are EXTREMELY patient.

I bought this game during Steam winter sale.  For a game which is nearly 7 years old, the graphics surely held up to this date.  The game-play is fun and fast-paced, although there are repetitive tasks in the game, it did not undermine the game for me.  

This game hit close to home for me with the reminder of the COVID pandemic that we have been living the past 3 years which increase the believably of the game with the possible consequence of living this world in real life.  

The main story is a bit short and incomplete for my taste as there were some storylines that were left unexplained when you play the end game (which at that time I fought it was just another mission) and I found myself hitting a DLC pay wall thereafter.

The P v P v Bot game-play at the Dark Zone is alive and well as you still encounter people who are still enjoying what this world has for all of us.  I have since trying to max out my gears and weapons which help to progress my gaming time in this world longer.

Overall, I recommend this game who wants see this world for themselves as I did when I bought the game during the Steam sale.

one of the best games i have played. Like actually. 
Ill lost the things i liked and disliked in that order
things i enjoyed
The setting is great, the gun-play is balanced, recoil is realistic, movement is smooth like gliding butter through a hot pan, the map is great, (so far) no crashes, the animations are nice, the vanity loot box opening animation especially, the dlcs (so far I've played underground only but it is a ball). 
now the things i dislike
the character customization is rather limited, the player is more squishy at the start of the game, when enemies are stunned(i.e. blinded or set on fire) they will start to slide in a random direction with no animations, sniper [press tab] to zoom in kinda sucks and does not allow those insane quick scope plays, DZ is kinda toxic so be weary and turn of public voice chat, majority of pvp players are metamancers so just get ready to be wrecked if u have a sub-par build, a huge learning curve for pvp (certain talents are essential and there are a few movement tech and healing tech that need to be practiced and take a while to master).
And that is it
