What can I say, this game is just the best. I've just gone back to it although i'm now playing on PC as opposed to XBOX so i've had to start again :( 
I've had fun doing so though, going through the story missions, getting into the dark zone again and gearing up at end game. The builds are great, the content is great (if you have gold edition/DLC's) and best of all, as of 2023 there is still a good player base!!
PVP isnt really for me but still seeing manhunts active in the  darkzone at WT5 and got straight into 3 last stand maps.
Survival is one of the best versions of that game type i've ever played. Thoroughly enjoy spending an hour getting to the dark zone, killing a hunter and extracting.
Underground, I absolutely rinsed this on the xbox with my friends - got my level in there, all the upgrades - just had a blast with it. My friends have all moved on from TD1 so just me rocking up solo in there at the mo
Resistance game modes - by far my favourite part of endgame. just love the endless waves type game modes. You can literally jump straight into a game - the matchmaking is pretty much instant for me (i play weekends & evenings).
Incursions aren't really played anymore although the discord is stil active, so check for groups there. Theres only really 1 legendary mission that you can matchmake for - amhursts apartment.
Global Events are still active and there is a schedule for the remainder of 2023 so come join in! 
(Still a bit expensive in steam though...)

There's a game in here somewhere that someone will enjoy. Not me.

The gameplay is decent, the gunplay is okay, and the story seems interesting, and the game overall is [u]fine.[/u] It's not bad, but it's not [i]good[/i], it's [u]fine.[/u]

The story doesn't really have a good hook, so I find it hard to get invested. COVID aside, the story feels like it treads old ground that others have done better. I haven't read the book(s), but the game makes me feel like the book is just a bad retread of a book or movie that someone else did better. Not very engaging. The characters that are presented in the cinematics are similarly bland; I can't really [i]feel[/i] interested in them, so I don't really care if they live or die. They're set dressing, nothing more, and it cheapens them.

The gameplay is [i]fine.[/i] I think if the developers actually spent some time working on the single-player experience, I might enjoy it more, but the game is clearly tailored around a half-assed "online service" concept that tries, and fails, to be a co-op MMO, because it's the store that really matters ... to someone. Not me.

Meh. There's something there to enjoy, I just can't find it. I know it's there, but not anywhere I looked.

Overall, I highly recommend The Division to any fans of RPG and shooter games. The atmosphere and gameplay are top-notch, and there is plenty of content to keep you coming back for more.

This is a solid game with excellent graphics, rich backstory, tactical combat requiring cover and strategy, changing environment (weather, day/night), random encounters, immersive setting, challenging bosses (but not Souls-like), easy to follow leveling and progression as well as gear upgrading and crafting.

Overall of the better shooter looter options out there and I find this more cerebral and entertaining. Looking forward to trying this with friends as it is cable of grouping for multiplayer.

Gather your friends, Gear up and Git R Dun.  Worth every penny.

If you abandon the premise that a game should be fun it's a great game. If you enjoy being regularly disconnected from the server and losing an hours mission progress its a cracking game. If your the sort of gamer that enjoys a exp level based game where exp level means absolutely diddly squat resulting in NPCs a fraction of your level wiping you out with a hand gun you'll love this. If your into free roam games you'll positively get a hard on for the completely restrictive street level 'run to a mission down a street that looks just like the last one' game play (sarcasm). However you might not enjoy the fact your character frequently does not respond to commands until you're so full of lead you cant lift your pinkie finger or when they fail to move at all when stuck between suprisingly robust bin bags. Accuracy is more of a phiisophical concept as far as the weapons are concerned but when all's said is the least worrying thing when NPC headshot you through cars, from behind solid concrete planters or even better straight through civilians that you yourself cant shoot through. Un explained frame rate drops accompanied with the frustrating deaths that goes with that. You'll also suffer from the fact that the med-kit button (V) is right next to the inventory button (B) that causes you to frequently get slaughtered by opening the real time menu while in combat (cant change this key binding which is complete effing BS). Weapons that look good from their stats but do in fact do less damage than a super soaker. Flame throwers that can penetrate solid barriers but weabons with 7.62 AP rounds that cant penetrate a hoodie. 'Armor' is more for show than protection because no matter what you wear your base level rookie with a pistol will kill you dead. Oh and the multiple deaths of 'Alex' the fkin rioter who is contantly being mourned by his fellow AI literally every other bloody kill.  Aside from all that the ABSOLUTE most gut wrenchingly frustrating, teeth grinding, soul crushing thing is that it could have been an incredible game. The atmosphere is good, the background sound is good, the story line is cracking and the actual graphics are still standing up now but as Ubisoft usually does (apart form with farcry) they produced a half baked game. It bugs the hell out of me. I deeply want them to have put the extra work in because this had all the hall marks of a great game format but just produced something underwhelming. I'm going to complete this game anyway but not for fun, more because I have more issues with not getting closure than Sheldon Cooper.

Great cover-based looter game. Had a fun time playing this to completion, including most of the DLCs. There are still plenty of people playing so the multiplayer holds up well, especially once you reach end game. The guns feel punchy and movement is slick for the most part, even though I'm not a fan of only being able to do a scripted climb/vault instead of free jumping on and off things.

World atmosphere and artwork are great and fit the setting. Base building is fun and feels relevant as it makes complete sense in the game world. Not so good is the repetitive missions, they can get exhausting after a while (same thing copy pasted over and over on a huge map in the typical Ubisoft fashion). Narrative is cool but it's mostly found in the collectables.

Darkzone wasn't for me, it feels unbalanced in a way that's unfun to me. I would say the game has plenty to offer without DZ though, so this didn't draw from the experience. 

Overall 8/10

The Division review, where too start!

I apologise for this very long read, but if you are going to write a review then you go into depth and explain aspects of the game! Writing "it's a good game and should buy it" is not a review and not helpful at all and should be removed from the page!

Yes the game is just released but I played this far back in Gamescom 2015 and then the closed beta and now release, so my review is very clear! Also not much of the game has changed since then so I have a very valid point!

Let's get into the liars that are Ubisoft!

Graphics: We all remember the first announcement of this game, walking through the streets and we all looked in aw... Then most of us came back to reality because we remembered this is Ubisoft! 

So the graphics are not what you all expect and they are massively changed and toned down compare to what we seen! 

When playing this game at Gamescom 2015 I thought the graphics where terrible, I mentioned to the Devs and they said it's not a final build, so I thought okay that is fair... Yet the game I am playing right now looks exactly the same as what I played. 
The graphics are fairly decent to play but nothing extreme to what we all are expecting!

Here, this video better explains it: http://youtu.be/fW6kehLgXdY

Audio: The gameplay audio is basic run gun, shooting tooting sounds. There is not even any atmosphere aspect of the game, when walking around the sounds are basic and offering no depth to the game! So to me, it's just a basic sound game and no real draw in!
Also the guns sound like toy guns for some unknown reason! Makes no sense why it sounds weird.

Controls: The controls are simple to get used too, nothing special and can be changed to the way you like them. They are easy to manage and get used too but the character can handle odd at times!

Gameplay: The gameplay is an open world aspect, which more or less feels like an arena closed off to everything else.  You gather missions, kill people, rank up and find special drops but that is it! Nice aspect is you can sneak and surprise enemies! 

The game is best played with your friends, small group of 4 and if anymore then make another group and meet up to do 'certain' tasks together but that's it. Unless in the dark zone which is the PVP aspect of the game. (Which is where it feels Ubisoft is trying to push 90% of the time is that section of the game, even though it's boring)

Each mission you complete and handle gains you character recognition to build up the area you are in. You can bring back the society with each mission, that is how it feels but not how it looks! Even the social areas that are ranked up and it's blossoming in life (the more you go) but you leave that and some how there are enemies wondering extremely close to the base, which becomes confusing on what and why you are doing what you are doing. 

There is not really much to explore, find and search for the loot aspect. The map is small and confined to the streets basically with some inside sections but from what I can tell, only accessible when on the mission, otherwise closed off. We cannot enter buildings or houses to search for stuff, SOME and I mean some buildings are accessible, but it is so limited you would not believe... It's not that type of game! You are clamped down into long streets, some ladders to climb to a small area, longer streets and lots of running back and fore, you would not believe how basic and bland this map really is compared too what they hyped and lied about the map actually being!

Nice feature of the game is the customisation! Even the HUD on the game is semi customisable... Resizing, arranging around where you want it and so on!

Also forgot DayZ Walking Simulator! This is by far the biggest walking/ running simulator around! (DayZ now added vehicles to remove the walking sim) but anyway, this is walk or run, depends how you feel... bad some bad guys, shoot shoot, cover, shoot, heal, shoot, run some more, run some more, ooo, find a nice loot box with green items in, then continue to run, run, run and then a friend says "You can fast travel to certain places" Thus then saving some time, but when out it is even more running! Running! There are vehicles in the game... but they are obstacles to climb or go around, that is it! 

(You cannot jump off a vehicle or walk off, he stands on the edge and you must press a key to get off, otherwise the invisible wall holds you there no matter what you are ontop off)

There is barely any missions to actually do for the story driven part! - The game is designed for you to grind the same missions over and over and over and over and over and over (You get the point so I will stop there) on a harder difficulty to get some better loot... That is pretty much the system of the game, otherwise it is dark zones but even there it becomes tiring and boring after a set period of time.  Clearly Ubisoft did not care about the story of the game considering it is EXTREMELY short!

There is hardly anything to do in the game, seriously! The main focus of the game feels like and looks like a small red part of the map (Dark Zone) where they want players to fight and kill, that is it.  REALLY that is IT!

Ubisoft here has focused on multiplayer ONLY 14 main story missions, which can be done in about 5hours

The game is based around loot which makes your character better, basically like Diablo 3 style! Almost identical to the game with the gear to make you a certain way and better etc!

They have tried to make an MMORPG, but this does not feel like an MMO at all... It feels like a small confined semi tactical shooter, with minimal loot aspects and straight approaches to things... That is my opinion!

Now everything else after above!

Ubisoft are more like a console developer with a PC porter! If you google then you will find that they are the new early access games... Not really finished games, also a huge bunch of liars, thieves and no good for nothing company, but continue to make games and charging insane prices and not being sued!?!? This should change!

I would say it started with Watch Dogs! We all remember seeing and then getting a game was totally different to what we seen, but had certain aspects of the original game we seen, then assassins creed (A game that did not work completely) and so much more games after where they shown one thing, but released another... 
Even Rainbow Six Siege was betrayed as one but we got another!

When The Division was announced, they said that the PC will contain a far superior game and be the better platform to play, yet when you do some Googling.. You will find a statement from Ubisoft saying "They had to keep the PC version in check with the console because we do not want the PC to get to far away from them, making it unfair" Which is Ubisoft for you... A console developer, PC Porter and will say one thing, show one thing but make another!

We seen The Division a few years back, we where promised so much and yet we got this game with missing so much! They brushed up on many things like a drone with players joining via tablets, that was removed, they said about a huge map and even openly promoted this (there is a YouTube video that even explains this) and yet they completely lied and less a false information to support the hype of the game in false promotion. Plus so much more. Google/ YouTube has a ton of this information so do not just take my word for it!

I am trying so hard to like this game, I had so much hype I cannot explain to anyone but Ubisoft have ruined it all for me and I am trying to enjoy this game with friends but I am finding it very hard!

Would I recommend this game? I want to say yes I really do, based on the company behind it and what they have done lately! I am going to say no, 70% of it, there are some positives but not much and lots has changed since what we was promised and got!

Welcome to our Black Friday Specials!

You most likely have heard about The Division 2 or have even played it before thumbing through these reviews, so you're probably here asking, "should or play this one? Or should I skip ahead/stick with the sequel?"

You should play this one. Maybe you don't need to assemble a team of friends to fill a practically archaic lobby, but what you need to do is set aside some time to run through the campaign on single player and *experience* one of the most stunning games worlds you'll ever immerse yourself in. Really take it in, because I doubt we'll have another division title quite like it and I worry support for it will very soon drop off.

The story isn't anything particularly moving, but it's leagues ahead of the sequel in terms of believability, attention to detail, and motivation. The sequel severely lacks real motivation to complete the tasks they set out for you, whereas the first title not only gives you a distinct plan from beginning to end how you are going to take the city back, but implements it in your progression as it is divided into the three areas of military, technology, and medical. These upgrades are both statistical and seen in gameplay/RPG character builds, but also in the story and world. The multiple factions are relatable enough to be interested in their inception, and although the encounters/events (side quests) are often painful, soulless duplicates of each other, the characters feeding you info over comms from each of the safehouse are each unique and personable, a golden piece of writing in an otherwise dull storyline.

One could argue this is also a part of the explanation on story, but the world itself is immensely gorgeous, but detailed down to the fucking minute pieces, as you traverse 12-foot tall piles of trash, collapsed subways, and abandoned safe areas, detail and creativity with apocalyptic elements I've yet to see in games other than this series and The Last of Us. Beyond the visual appeal, it is also one of the most immersive experiences I've ever had, especially from a third-person view where I've always preferred first person for immersion. Most notable are the missions underground and simply wandering the snow looking for countless audio entries and hidden supplies.

All.in all, what really sets this game apart from playing what most people call a superior sequel is the immersive single player experience. I played this game entirely solo, completed every event, and still find things to enjoy doing just so I have an excuse to return to this beautifully mastercrafted city left devastated by collapse. The sequel does a lot of things better, and is still quite well detailed and depicted, but nothing quite captures the single-strap backpack, beanie-wearing agent creeping between ruined skyscrapers in the cold snow you can feel through the screen.

Although somewhat of a downgrade to what was originally envisioned and promoted, The Division still remains a really impressive game that showcased some rare ambition from Ubisoft and a remarkably detailed world. 

Set in a scaled down New York and build upon the Snowdrop Engine, this game looks and feels fantastic. The attention to detail in the world is simply astonishing with so many streets, interiors and landmarks all littered with stuff. The snowy backdrop and eerie silence of the streets just oozes a very unique atmosphere. 

Coming up to 7 years old, it's still worth playing even just to finish the story missions. The narrative is quite poor and the missions aren't hugely varied but exploring the city, building your character and the combat is great fun throughout. At worst, you'll definitely get a good 25 hours out of it and even more with friends. 

It's a real pity Ubisoft play their games so safe these days. This was actually a really original and promising concept that even with a sequel, they failed to expand upon. This is definitely the better of the two titles.

Enjoyed the exploration and the level design. Didn't enjoyed the crap constant leveling and quick uselessness of the weaponry and the constant need for upgrading against an ever stronger enemy.  There is probably a game design argument for it,  but its annoying nonetheless. This constant need to spend game money to get better weaponry and armor. Even more difficult with a vendor system that only nets 10 percent for a sold weapon. There should be a perk or skill for better prices and bartering. That ties into the over powered stupidity of the boss battles. Gold level bosses need 20-30 headshots with a purple weapon to go down.  After a while this redundant repetition in each of the zones just got boring.  Sure I'm laying this solo,  and the game is probably balanced for 4 person coop,  but I gamed up to level 21, and I'm uninstalling this piece of inadequate frustration.  
I will the say voice acting work is exceptionally good.  Very New Yorker authentic. And the structural design of the rebuilding in the face of utter destruction has a well thought out purpose and common sense to it.   So there's good in here as well.  And it did hold my interest for 38 hours,  so there's that too.
[edit]
So re installed,  and kept going for the story,  which is always the driving force in good games. I'm at level 29 now,  and just cleared the grand central station assault. Again,  stick with this for the story and the world created. 
[edit]
The game play changes drastically when you hit level 30,  allowing for better weapons and gear and the entire game experience is exponentially better. With unlocked gold weapons a lot of the earlier frustration evaporates,  allowing for better immersion.  Lots of purple and gold items drop and these can be sold to get what you need to challenge the end game scenario and Camp Clinton.  Make sure to stash and store gear mods and weapon attachments.  They come in useful through  out the game.  Having  level 1 scope with 15x magnification,is better than a 4x level 30.

This game had a horrible start. From the downgrade that "Ubisoft" made and keeps making, since the released day, were we had already countless bugs and connecting issues, and it seemed to be unfixable. But that, for a new "AAA" title, is just a disaster. Don't forget also the year were the Division released we had also some very good "AAA" titles were they looked very good and promising. And that for the Division makes it more difficult. That's the reason why it lost that many players.

Almost two years past since the game is up and running. And Ubisoft with Massive Entertainment spend resources and money to fix it as much as better they could. With every patch they fixed something but also they brought and something new. Now on 2018 the player base went larger than before and also we have 3 different expansions were they are very entertaining to spend some time with your friends, or of course, solo if you're a lone wolf on games.

In conclusion the game was keep getting better and better but of course some little things weren't fixed because it was just too late, anyway, they've done a realy good work and that was noticed to us. My personal opinion is that, they realy made a come back to the gaming community and for what they are capable of doing. I hope they learned a lesson from this and just keep making great games that our time is worth giving.

Sincerely,

This is an amazing co-op experience. It got a lot of trash talk because on launch, a lot of players couldn't get on, me included (back on PS4). And a lot of promised features (such as playing from a tablet) were cut. But looking at it now, it's solid. Story is forget able but still okay enough to understand why YOU are there.

Up to 4 players can drop in and drop out on the host's map, meaning they can progress their main objectives with you and replay chunks they themselves have already done. The more the better in this game. There is a lot of replay value here; raising the difficulty, redoing a section simply because you loved it, even if it's a story bit, it never got old to me. However, it got old to most, seeing as the enemies have few skins, are bullet sponges later on, and well, the ''ending'' is a huge letdown. The DLCs in themselves are nothing too noteworthy, however if you enjoy the mechanics, they can be satisfying. The base game tends to have you run around in an empty city where mostly thugs and factions roam the streets, with the occasional civilian that asks for an item and give you a piece of clothing to customise your character (leather jacket, a beanie, a scarf, boots). It can feel like an empty space. Run here, run there, it all looks the same. It's all the same enemies. But the mechanics! Oh, that's what I enjoyed.

If I'm to sum up what this game is about and why it definitely gets a thumbs up from me is... 
Well it's from the combat; get into cover, move seamlessly about your cover and around corners of said cover, emptying your clip blind or while aiming, use your skills that aren't on cool down.
The customisation of your guns with bonuses to aiming, scopes, bigger mags and more, while all the different armors with buffs to health, armor or cool down reductions, etc...
This is with randomised loot dropped from batches of enemies, chests scattered around in the environment, from rare elites or instances bosses, chests, or in the PvP areas. 
There is even a subtle aggro system which isn't explained enough, but once you get into it is a massive thing to plan your party around.

One of the coolest thing is what's called the Dark Zone. Players can enter it and all that co-op is meddled. You can loot from the usual enemies, which are much tougher, bosses, or chests which require a ''dark zone level'', which goes up with most actions you do in the dark zone, and which can also go down when you die. The equipment you will find there is the best in the game, however you need to call in a chopper to have it extracted and identified upon exit. And here's where it's chaotic; other players can and will kill you. Even those on your team can. When you die, you drop the dark zone equipment you were collecting and trying to extract, and they can then try to extract it themselves. When someone kills you in the dark zone, everyone knows their approximate location, and get rewarded for your their death. Once you've extracted your items, however, they are forever yours to keep. What you come with is yours. What you're trying to acquire... Well, good luck.

So in short, I enjoyed it a lot. because what it DID do right, it did near perfectly. But it is repetitive for most. The second entry is more of this, with more colors and a different stats system.

Great game

A virus has devastated New York City. You and other online gamers must find a way to help the city and its communities to recover. Go just about anywhere in this detailed replication of New York if you have the skill. And the help. Great exploration and loot. Great cover system and gun play. However...

If you expect to play solo, think otherwise. Even small quests involve lots of enemies in multiple levels. Without help you won't get very far. If you die, you go back to a check point. If you don't finish the quest before going off line, you don't go to that check point. You go to the start of the quest. Heaven forbid if you have to go off line because the kids are hungry or the wife frisky. No playing for an hour before going to work. Of course dealing with Ubisoft is as frustrating as ever. 

Still, a great game. Better if you play with friends who have a lot of time on their hands.

After 5,000+ hours The Division deserves a Thanks. 

Thanks for the awesome game that provided some of the best memories my group had. Whether it's running around NY just knocking out patrols, fighting in the Dark Zone or staying alive in an Incursion The Division always provided a great time.

I am really surprised to see a game has this much to offer even after the 6 years! RPG elements are pretty damn good. The weapon and gear customization is pretty in-depth and extremely satisfying. Honestly this game opens-up after the level 30.
Team play is better than Divison 2. Main story was decent but this game shines in the multiplayer department.

I love The Division!

The gameplay is nice, playing with someone is better, but playing alone is cool too. I played the whole story twice, once on the PS4, and once again on the PC. I was arrogant enough to play all of the missions on hard, and it is quite hard. The enemies are bullet sponges, so if you don't like that kind of game, this isn't for you. 

The best part, IMO, is the setting. A snowy, dark, foggy New York City delivers an amazing atmosphere. And the graphics are fantastic! Even now, 6 years after launch, this game will tank my RTX 3060 when playing at 4k with everything maxed out. But the result is excellent! This game is insanely beautiful!

The other thing that I enjoyed a lot from this game world, is just how dense it is. The streets of NY are one thing, but it is actually possible to get a little lost in this game because a lot of buildings have detailed interiors with mulitple rooms and multiple floors. There are sewers that connect to metro stations. You can find a little shortcut and go through a building, or climb a building entirely. The exploration is just superb!

The base game delivers so much that even the DLC may seem a bit pointless. I have played over 100 hours on two platforms, and I feel like I am just playing it superficially. There is so much more than I haven't done. There is PVP, the underground, the dark zone, survival mode, and just the overworld after you finish the story. One of the most fun gaming sessions I've had was playing the Survival mode from the DLC. I spent like 4 hours exploring a dark, gloomy NY trying to scavenge whatever I could find, and trying not to engage the very hostile enemies. It is just so much fun!

I highly recommend it!

[b]Just read the score at the bottom, I've re-rated this game due to the Dark Zone PvP Hell but did not change the rest of the review.[/b]


[b]The Game:[/b] Tom Clancy's The Division (just "the Division" for the remainder of this review) is a great little online RPG game by Ubisoft! I'm amazed too that Ubisoft was able to pull of making an entirely new franchise and not have it completely suck like many other Ubisoft games (Watch_Dogs for example).

[b]Gameplay:[/b] The Division plays great, in my opinion anyways, and I am playing it on the PC (Windows 64-bit). The controls (keyboard and mouse in my case) feel natural and "correct". The game does not feel "choppy" or "blocky" like most multi-platform TPS (Third Person Shooters). Most of the time the camera just feels all wrong when using the mouse, but not the Division so kudos to Ubisoft for making the game feel great on PC when using PC controls.

In addition to "feeling" correct while playing on PC, the game actually plays correctly too. The only bugs I've ever really had were just latency bugs (I'd kill two enemies but the game wouldn't "kill" them until suddenly all at once - this has only happened 4-5 times total and the "lag" lasts no longer than 2 seconds tops).

[b]Game Performance (PC):[/b] The Division runs great on PC (in my case, right now an Alienware 18" laptop with SLI). I'm not running it at maximum settings on this laptop (though it does run at max settings on my desktop); either way however The Division looks great - regardless of the computer I'm on. The game doesn't seem to suffer from lagging and other performance issues like Console Games on PC (aka shit ports like GTA IV and even GTA V).


[b]The Play "Feel":[/b] The way this game feels is pretty much covered in the above paragraph; however I may as mention it in specific detail here. The Division feels like an online RPG Third-Person-Shooter and on PC it feels like it was made for PC, again stuff I've already stated. As far as the way runs/feels/etc. though I will give it a seperate score for this. For being a decent game or even port (if it is) it doesn't feel bad so it gets [b]4 out of 5[/b] stars for the "Feel".


[b]Manhatten (PvE):[/b] All of your non-PvP quests for leveling your standard level and whatnot takes place outside the "Dark Zone" in the middle of the game's map. In this area you simply do PvE quests against NPCs, you don't end up fighting any actual players (PvP) until you are in the Dark Zone - which has its own leveling system versus the PvE leveling system (you level differently and they have no influence on each other).

[b]The Dark Zone (PVP):[/b] The Dark Zone is The Division's PvP Zone. Here player Agents can go "rogue" and kill you; they usually do this while you are waiting for your extraction for 90 seconds after launching your flare. Not all agents have to go Rogue however; if you choose not to you instead, will be killing these rogue agents. My knowledge on The Division's Dark Zone isn't the most complete; however I am aware that once you shoot off your flare, there is an intense wait for gear/player extraction. Other players can see your flare shoot off and will come for you for the loot you're extracting; so be careful and if you can - go to the Dark Zone with friends (up to 4 people per group).


[b]Overall:[/b] Tom Clancy's The Division is a great Online (MMOish) Third-Person Tactical Shooter. In the non-Dark Zone areas it's a PvE game and once in the Dark Zone it's PvE with PvP thrown in as well. I must caution to watch out for higher "Dark Zone" level players while you're a low level. They tend to kill you just because they can - half the time they don't even bother taking loot; or they'll steal all your loot but let you live - so be aware of that too. Otherwise I highly recommend The Division to anyone who is into the Tom Clancy series of games, or is into games with a realistic story, or just into online games (or third-person shooters). I should add that the maximum amount of players per "Dark Zone" instance, I believe, is 24 players (including you and your teammates if you're with any). Either way, while that 90 seconds may be intense - it sure is fun waiting with your buddies to see just how much shit is going to go down!

[b]Other Thoughts:[/b] Other than what I've previously mentioned; I don't have much else to add to this review. I hope it was sufficient enough to help anyone out with making the decision of weather to get The Division or not. I'd say yes it's worth it - but me and all my buddies think it is. For those of you who aren't my buddies or me - just make up your own mind because nobody is better at giving you an opinion than yourself! ;)


[b]Overall Score:[/b] 3/5 - [b]UPDATE - 2017[/b] This game's Dark Zone has become a living hell - I don't feel like rewriting the whole review on the Dark Zone and such; but yeah my recommendation and score are changing; though the review may not make sense now.

This game fills a niche for me like no other game world has. The atmosphere is iconic and the attention to detail is as well. Game-play loop is basic looter-shooter: kill enemies and get the loot. There  are a lot of ways to build your character how you want, and load-outs increase that diversity. There are hundreds of collectible items from cosmetics to lore to unique weapons. 

Further game modes like Survival and Underground make endgame a lot of fun and challenges you in different ways. The game gets dumped on a lot for no real reason. Most are nitpicks, pvp oriented, or because it's Ubisoft and it's cool to hate them. There are legitimate criticisms, but none really make the game unplayable or unable to be enjoyed.
NY Atmosphere alone makes the game fun. With the heavily discounted <$10 going price, it is a steal.

This game gives you mixed feelings, but mostly negative ones.

I'll analyze WHY as a proficient end-game player at gear score 290.

If you play this game for long enough, it will give you three-stage feelings:
1. Frustrating: Before reaching level 30, this game is considered hard, you'll have to do lots of missions and skill stuff to NOT to be killed by a bullet-sponge enemy.
2. Entertaining: After reaching level 30, you'll start getting classified gears and have a feeling that enemies are easier to kill, but still they are huge sponges.
3. Unfulfilling: You want to collect all classified gears, but you'll find out that the RNG in this game is deliberately designed, so that you'll never get a full classified gear by ONLY doing LZ boss farming or Global Events or other things like that. It will keep giving you some specific classified gears and you'll notice lots of duplicates.

In short, the more you want to collect a full set of classified gears, the more frustrating you will be. If you want to play this game, don't be a perfectionist, otherwise you'll waste lots of time.

The only pro of this game is graphics, otherwise I can think of nothing.

Details of RNG in this game: Although the official said the chance of dropping classified gears is 6% atm, they didn't say anything about WHAT kinds of gears to drop. I kept farming LZ bosses and use a sheet to record the drops. I noticed that I hadn't have any new classified gear drops after about 50 times of farming, 50 times! There are 15 bosses, so statistically it should drop about 1 classified gear in one farm. But still nothing new after 50 times. There are always about 2-3 classified gears in any set that I will never have a chance to get.

I can understand why they designed RNG like this, because they want the players to participate in all kinds of activities and keep playing as a proficient player in the team. So skilled players like me or you now can attract more novice players just like you and me in the past and that means sustained income, because they've got servers and developers to feed, of course.
fantastic game would recommend.

While I can't vouch for how the game was on launch, I came in around the last major update.  As of now it's a solid third-person cover-based looter shooter.  You should *not* expect a tactical experience, though, and should be expecting the third-person shooter version of an action-RPG; this includes enemies with tankier health bars.  While the UI for navigating through all the loot you'll begin to horde leaves something to be desired, there is some build variety as you start to earn gear sets (unique gear that gains benefits based on how many pieces of it you have).

While the start of the game can be a bit slow to get rolling there is a decent endgame experience to be had with daily/weekly bounties, Incursions (raids), The Underground (repeatable missions made up of stitched together tilesets), a wave/horde mode, and the Dark Zone if you want to try your luck at some PvEvP

What I think is the stand-out mode, though, is Survival.  While it isn't great for grinding loot, it is a really great mode for the experience every now and then.  Either PvE or PvEvP, you are dumped into a freezing cold New York with survival elements (hypothermia/thirst/hunger/infection) while you power-level through the loot progression to get to the Dark Zone to complete an objective and call in a evac.

Man, I love the lore of Division. Absolutely love it. I was there during beta of D1 and will never forget how broken this game was. Then it turned out to be a beautiful story. I am glad I didn't turn away when I had second doubts. When the DLCs dropped I fell in love even more. It showed me that The Division was here to stay. Never played much of Survival, until recently but underground was my jam. I loved everything about it. I would come home after work every night to jump on with my cousin on Xbox and we could grind between DZ and underground for hours on end. Don't get me wrong. I was young and stupid as fuck, still am. The dark zone was basically a cat and mouse for us and we were the mouse because we didn't understand the idea behind "building" a class. Best moments was when we used every ounce of brain power to try and avoid anyone and everyone in the DZ and strategically start extractions in many areas to throw off other players like the fucking clowns we were/are. Overall, I would continue to recommend D1 and although D2 isn't on steam (sadly) I would recommend to pick that up as well.

It's just pure fun. I mean, the solo campaign is really good. I never was a multi-player gamer but, at least with this game you can find some good folks to team up with and get some nice loot! If you played the Division 2 and you are finally disgusted with 3 years of freezes and CTD's,  then you have the replacement game that started it all right here.   

The Division....does not currently crash as far as I can tell.   Not only that for the past 6 years Ubisoft appears to have maintained this game better than they have the Division 2.  There is still a whole lot of content here even after you max out your level and get that gear score up to 270 or over 280 so you can get to world tier 5.   

There's all kinds of crap to do in this game and it itches that Division 2 scratch quite nicely,  you won't even miss it.

What I did was I picked this game up a few years ago,  maxed out my level,  got a whole bunch of credits and currencies and geared up okay,  nothing spectacular but then I got bored because I played it so often.  I uninstalled it,  forgot about it,  in 2022 I installed it again because I got sick of the freezing and crashing even after patches and hotfixes, updates and what not for Division 2.  

I uninstalled the Division 2. 

I'm back here again because I know that Ubisoft may go one of two ways with Division 2,  they have ignored the freezes and crashes since launch in 2019,  it's 3 years later people have been and still are telling them about the freezing and crashing,  how the game will suddenly stop recognizing Windows in the Event Viewer and just not work anymore.  They're either going to fix it or ignore it forever and let the game die off. 

What's weird is they just patched it and it's a mess.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I played this through and through when the pandemic first happened with a friend of mine. We weren't sure at the time if it was going to become our reality. We both really enjoyed this incredibly detailed world of a post apocalyptic New York City where you could walk into an insignificant building, only to discover a hidden story of an NPC through the environment or a recording picked up. It almost felt as unique in detail and character as a real event might be when over time you learned the horrible events that happened in this city and why. The combat was extremely fun and you could get very creative and strategic with the secondary tech like sticky bomb or turret. The factions of competing groups and bosses were well developed. Unlocking a new video or killing an enemy faction leader just added more depth. It was very hard at times considering you can mag dump all your ammo into some bosses and they still don't die, but it still engaged us to finish the game and keep trying. The gear system and crafting was awesome and it felt like Christmas to pick up a weapon or armor that suddenly gave you an edge over the competition. The community aspect of it was not bad either and you could get another player to help you clear out a boss you were having trouble with. I went on to play the Division 2, but the magic was gone from that game. It lacked something in detail to what this game certainly possessed for us. I'm not sure if I would ever do another play-through and considering what's happened since the pandemic, and I've already forgotten what was so 'unique' about the bosses or factions. I would give it an 7.8/10

This game is a typical example of bad mechanics, rushed development for shareholder and company profits, as well as ideas thrown at a wall to see what sticks. I loved the levels, the atmosphere, the animations of the characters, and how smooth movement seemed up until it kept prompting you to hit A to slam against cover....
But then the rushed development and completely unbalanced and ridiculously hard gameplay occurred...

This is not a matter of "Get Gud" as many noobs would say, this game is straight up unbalanced and broken. 

How you say? Easy...

1.) You will not get any good gear Vs. your actual level, and pickups are next to useless. 
2.) Enemies are aimbot cheaters, some can actually shoot right through cover, they always know EXACTLY were you are, and have unlimited amounts of grenades and ammo at ALL TIMES defeating the purpose of you having limited ammo and grenades as well as using stealth as they will just find you anyways. 
3.) The game will give you pretty easy missions, then random thrust you into a insanely hard mission next to imnpossible, with enemy AI again, always knowing were you are and always throwing endless grenades that somehow can find you no matter were your at. They toss them like professional football players for christ sake! But no, you can't do that too, it has to make sure you wicked limited in range because "Reasons".
4.) Players talk too much sh*t, and randomly you get kicked from groups all the time by control freak morons. Even if you start a group, they can kick YOU. Fun! I love waiting about 10 - 20 mins to get a group together via quick match and then just get kicked mid mission which resets EVERYTHING. 
5.) Your weapons are nerfed AF while enemy combatants have super powered maxed out weaponry that most the time, if not at all, you cant even pick up from the bodies!
6.) This game is grindy AF! It is really really bad, and many times the enemy AI will be far far above your skill level, even if it reads same level, they have abilites far far beyond their level, because "Reasons".
7.) Simply put, the damn game does indeed cheat to favor itself. I've experienced numerous times, and it is unacceptable. I've even seen enemy AI get back up AFTER they are killed, and motionless for about 30 seconds. Not to mention endless spawning of enemies, even if it says your clear at times. That's glitched AF. 
8.) Very very very repetitive missions and goals. Run, shoot, maybe collect something, move on, repeat. You have rescue missions, hostage missions, look for and find missions, but they all end up the same mission as you ALWAYS ensue in a unbalanced gun fight. So really, the missions are all exactly the same unless of course, the computer cheats and endlessly respawns enemies, using unlimited ammo and grenades. always fun to have to deal with. 
9.) Again, stealth is almost useless, and trying to think ahead while being quiet is almost useless most the time as the game throws you right into a group of alerted AI during some missions. When they can shoot right through cover when clearly, they should not be able to, like middle of walls, through entire buildings, through the damn ground, just for a few examples, topped off with aimbot perfect shots and endless ammo and grenades, it is very very frustrating. Makes it pointless to level or get better gear and weapons. Literally, it doesn't matter, the AI will just kill you anyways very quickly in many situations. 
10.) Spawning after dying, oh my god....sure, lets just throw you way way way back, so you can run all the way back for no reason, no extra AI, no items, nothing, while the game remembers you used items before dying and does not replenish it!! Really guys, really?? All while I fight perfect aimbot AI with endless ammo and grenades??

All I can say is, you do not need to play this entire game to get bored with it very quickly and clearly see the rushed development issues and glitches with this game. I do not recommend this game unless you and a few friends like that type of old school arcade style of play were mechanics really don't matter too much. Not to mention the RPG elements are also completely unbalanced, but then again, the devs clearly have never dabbled in a RPG before so it really does show. 

I really wanted to like this game, but the amount of frustration and clear cheating by the AI is too much. I'm here to play a Tom Clancy game, not a stupid impossible Dark Souls wanna be shooter and looter. Idk why, but Ubisoft just takes Clancy;s name and throws it on every tactical game they make, thinking we as the public are stupid enough to believe that because of that, the game will be amazing. Yeah, no, I think the last good game with his name tied to it was Rainbow Six 3, ever since that it has become copies of other franchises and their game mechanics. Ubisoft clearly has become just like Activision, Blizzard, and EA, and the greed as well as the idiots they hire to order around the dev teams and who keep rushing the devs to make a game just to have a product to over hype and sell, is clearly and blatantly showing. Ubisoft is not even trying to hide it anymore and they clearly never learn as long as a few stupid people keep buying their games, it will continue to happen. I cant even imagine how the division 2 is, probably much worse...

This has to be one of my top 10 games of all time. Such great memories going into the dark zone for the first time. Ive always played solo and dont go rogue, sneak around and avoid people etc. Its a Tom Clancy cover shooter with a rich atmosphere and lots of different builds and playstyles to choose from. The pvp is fun but there are some builds that just MELT you. It seems like you either have a PVE build, or a PVP build. If you have a pve build you will get melted in pvp, if you have a pvp build you will get melted by mobs. I wish there was moire of a balance but thats just the way it is, maybe after i get my build 100% optimized with classifieds it will be better. The base game is pretty dead but the Dark Zone is always poppin in my region, which is surprising considering The Division 2 is out. I will not buy Division 2 because the environments look boring and not detailed and they have nowhere near the atmosphere of one. Also I heard some of the mechanics became watered down. Maybe after I unlock everything and 100% everything ill try 2. 1 seems way better and many other people share that view.

There are very few games that on day 1 were undefeated... This is definitely one of them. There is a part in the beginning of the game where you walk though a tunnel-like entrance to the first accessible multiplayer zone where you can finally see other players. I remember vividly waiting until midnight to play this game the split second it released. I quickly created my character and I ran out the tunnel and turned around to see hundreds of other players just like me all pouring out and sprinting out of the tunnel and into the multiplayer zone. It still gives me chills thinking about it. Lack of content on release was a huge issue but the DZ PvP was something unreal. I wonder if The Day Before will really be something like this game, like people say.

Tom Clancy's Muppet Babies™ is a Kyle Rittenhouse wet dream, in which the government *wants* you to come to the big city to shoot looters.

The good
The city is gorgeous.
The guns and equipment are cool.
Main missions are usually good, and provide checkpoints (usually).
I could easily solo the whole game.

The meh
Side missions aren't bad, but there's a bit too much repetition. Not a fan of the water supply and find the virus box type missions.
Some cooler perks would've been nice.
No interest in the multiplayer but now in 2022 it seemed a bit quiet.
Guns are realistic, but you're fighting bullet-sponge style.

The bad
The characters, story and general faux-apolitical flavor of the game are stale and uninspired. The gab from the regional heads of each area was lame, since they were annoying stereotypes and comic relief that didn't fit with the rest of the game. Playing solo is kinda lonely.
The usual Ubisoft BS.

Verdict
I bought this for $10 and at that price it was 50 hours of no-frills solo cover-shooting fun till the end of the main campaign.

A virus that spread during Black Friday has killed off most of New York. Society has collapsed, the immune inmates have overrun the jails, and New York is now a lawless city. So it's up to you to help JTF take back New York. Good setup for a post apocalyptic Batman, bad setup for someone with 3 guns, limited ammo, and a backpack full of junk collected along the way.

The Division is a multi-player co-op loot-farming game and as is the case with loot-farming games, it always plays better with others. As of 2017, the PvE and PvP are still broken. It has had minor graphical downgrades since E3, some changes to the gameplay, and over tens of bug fixes, yet it still has a fair amount of game breaking glitches. Every now and then, you'll end up in a match where the mission won't start because the door/gate won't open. This has been there since Day 1 and seems to have gone unnoticed. "Fun" glitches include fusing yourself to fuse boxes, portable barriers letting you pass through walls, and falling off the map through solid floors - all in the middle of multi-player PvE sessions. The game had a lot of potential, wasted potential. In fact, The Division excels at the things it does outside of the core gameplay loop. For example, its approach to telling a story through holographic projections and audio files, the graphics on display, and the houses left behind by those who passed away is excellent.

I really tried to like The Division because it looked amazing and seemed to have a lot of potential when it was shown at E3 but, as was the case with Watch Dogs, it turned out to be quite mediocre. If you find repetitiveness and enemy waves addictive, you might like this game. Having played this for over 200 hours, I'm just worn out.

Warning: No offline solo. Every time I fire up a Tom Clancy game, I get a warm tingling sensation at thought of the variety of realistically modeled gunshots provided by an armory of fully-customizable arsenal of every type of gun out there. The Division in particular even wows with the futuristic UI not found in Wildlands, which is great as well. Only half of Manhattan is accessible in this game but it seems mostly accurate from when I was a resident there IRL. Having finished Cyberpunk (a superb artistic achievement in Night City), I think they could've finished the entire island at the very least, since there's no creativity involved. The map is not as open-world as Wildlands, with some streets and areas blocked off by design. And the other four boroughs are pretty much off-limits. However, there's some vertical access both underground and in buildings; subways and sewers are interesting enough. Gameplay and story are balanced and polished to the brand's standard, with the tactical aspect being the primary focus instead of stealth. Looting and crafting are key parts of the game as upgrading weapon power is critical to survival. The usual Ubi multiplayer matching system works well enough for co-op with randoms. Just hate getting asked to change my password all the time because of multiple PCs. Ubi needs to fix that since my account is already Steam linked.

I'll put the bad first for people who are honestly looking to buy this.

The Global Events (monthly updates for new content) are terrible. The game developers decide to make events at the END of the month to make a new "update" and give you only a week to complete the challenges. Also good luck trying to finish these events when every single one of them is behind a DLC paywall (even though I have the Season Pass, this is despicable.) These events are usually just filled with cosmetics for your character such as face masks and patches for your jacket. 
(item flexing- not content) 

The whole "online" element of this game is awful, get friends to play this with. If you're lucky enough to find others to play with on public matchmaking (after sitting in queues for 25 minutes) you'll be in a team of either 2-3 idiots that can't listen or do anything that isn't their idea- OR be power-carried by 2 people who have possibly showered twice in their entire life and one normal person with a moderate level as you go through the challenging missions. Global Event matchmaking is the absolute worst, people will screw you over to get the things they need then leave you once they got what they want.

Do not- and I'm serious.. Do NOT go to the Darkzone. For the Division, the developers decided to create a PvP zone in the map which has a higher chance of dropping rare / extremely valuable items and loot. This idea itself isn't bad as it allows for a constant playerbase in their servers, however the developers do not even bother maintaining this anymore, so now it is a scum-filled cesspool of hackers and edgy 14 year olds who are allowed to say- whatever they want.

Drug deal takedown, arms deal takedown, repairing satellites and that's the entire game, just do that x10. 

The character creation is really lacking, giving you only 6 "faces" to choose from with no way to modify specific parts on your face and rather things you can add on your characters face with piercings or neck tattoos.

All and all- it's a game with flaws.
Survival, thats it

What to say... An eight year old game, that has better gameplay then games released in the current and last year. Having played TD2 before this, I was surprised that I did not feel any strain or negativity while playing this game. 

Having alot of similar gameplay as the next part, some things are better in this game. A full darkzone instead of several different smaller zones is one of them. I cannot for sure say how the loot drops compare to 8 years ago, but this is definitely updated to be played by someone alone without having to do the harder content, still get the same loot and enjoy the game to the fullest. 

The story is well written, although here and there I missed a bit of the "Oomf" effect. This is something that does get better in the next part. Alot of references coming in TD2 are being explained in this game. If you are looking for the full lore experience this is definitely worth a try and buy.

This game can be great specially, if you are playing with some friend while setting the difficulty level at hard. Playing in solo imply almost that you have to play at easy which is most of the time easy. Therefore you may not die to much often. So from my point of view it is just a matter of what are you expecting to have in terms of difficulty to kill the ennemies along the game. 

One great feature of this game is the garments which has been really developed and perfected to a point that you will never see someone in that game walking around and dress like you do. 

On the other hand, compared to Ghost Recon Wild Land they did not use a concept that allows you vastly modify your weapon. Nevertheless there is some room for modification of weapons, but I found the mechanic close to what could be an arcade game. Where any weapons or gears are based on which level you are. 

Anyway to conclude my verdict is that if you fell to play a shooting game think about these facts. You can also go to see some people on youtube that have played the game. Also, be aware that there is not a ton of cinematics and most of them are not containing any trilling scenes.

However, beatting the game can be done quite fast (I would say too fast) and then You are left with PVP. Which from my point of view quite suck since that I never play PVP because my system and my connection are somehow S****y.

Its doesn't feel like a zombie survival game at all because there isn't any in it so the player isn't really able to understand whats going on and feels like there not playing it properly.  Id say the action of the combat is anti climatic, it could be a heavier game with the gunplay.  The streets feel empty and graphically its an older game but the graphics are better and I think people are going to sit down and play it.  It really gets you thinking about the possibilities in the dating scene because of how empty it is, it feels like that.

Its one of these games that you play and your shocked at how depressing that period of time would be and you wouldn't enjoy playing it at all, Im not feeling like its fantastic emotionally and I wouldn't say its reasonable the way the people are reacting they seem like they need to calm down.

Im finding the difficulty of the game to be harder than normal, I would say its something that is a representation of how easily you can't complete the scenarios.  Is The Division the best Tom Clancy game made in history? It might not be but the maps are the biggest that ive seen them and thats saying alot.  I can't help but think that im tired of the gameplay, im thinking its the age of gaming and about how I feel about it.  I can honestly say im not excited to do the next mission and the story isn't grasping my interest.

 I can say that it isn't detailed enough to be considered an immersive game and thats where gaming crosses the line into reality and people think IMAX films are better so you could say its the screens and VR experiences that are going to change the way we feel about gaming.  Theres not alot of these titles to play so you don't really think of them as an opening for another studio to make another one.

Im level 14 and im playing it less than the day before not because im tired of playing it but because its repetitive.  I wouldn't think that a studio could develop more content and release it without auto mapping cities and having huge data folders of content and thats kind of where game streaming kind of made more sense, is 50-100gb a big enough game for online content anymore? no its probably along the lines of 1000gb.

The difficulty of the game can get quite challenging and its not really that great to play it.  I can't help but think its one of the most difficult things to do and your totally reliant on the cover system and accuracy, noone is able to do this because of the accuracy limitations.

Im almost finished the game with only another few hours left but I don't really feel like playing it.  I think it isn't great and the map exploration is average. 

There are so many things to finish up after the missions that you can keep playing it for a long time and thats probably what people did, its kind of like one of those games you would play when it was released at full price because of the dwindling player base.  The Dark Zone is trying hard and thats probably where it was meant to be played.

An atmospheric, beautifully rendered cover-shooter that's definitely worth a playthrough if you get it on sale. However, you might stuggle to get a big enough multiplayer co-op squad that's required for the higher level stuff, where the enemy bosses get a bit too ludicrously bullet-spongey anyway.
That aside, you can reach max level (30) without ever having to dip into multiplayer. There's a decent enough game in that content alone, but don't expect UBIsoft to be providing much in the way of support or updates from here on in..It's made quite apparent that the publishers want you moving on to Division 2 by now.

You will never die in a way that seems reasonable, every death seems cheap, the enemies do way more damage and somehow have some of the same gadgets as you, even though theyre just rioters, they have robotic turrets but without a cooldown that are also much stronger than yours. They also have one person doing damage to them and you have 10 doing much more damage to you. The friendly ai could literally not exist and it wouldnt make a difference, im not sure theyre able to do damage even, and if agro the enemy ai will run directly through them straight to your position even when they cant see you. Its definitely not as fun as division 2 but its decent for like an hour at a time, especially if you never played the second one. The level system is probly the least fun aspect, in this universe where you play a highly trained agent, your former garbage man is still able to kill you with a pistol in a couple shots while you unload an AR into him. Grinding to max level is also not very enjoyable, theres like 5 side mission templates that you do over and over and enemies that are only a level or 2 above you are like twice as strong as you. I wouldnt try to do missions above your level, I'd even do missions below so it feels like you're using a real gun and not a bb gun, although even enemies 5 levels below you are still stronger than you hut you have a better chance. Leveling in shooting games is stupid anyways as it just feels like a bad way to restrict areas and missions and to bloat the loot with the same guns and attachments but this is probably the worst I've played in that regard. If there was a way to boost to max level and bypass the pointless grind and pointless low level loot it would be wayyy more fun. Gadgets also seem pretty useless, the first seeker mine barely does any damage and the turret can be broken in like 3 shots. I wrote this review as I was quitting to hook up my old xbox and play division 2, there is so much more to do and is so much more fun, I wish it was on steam. A lot of people claim this one is better, I'm not sure when it gets better but its not in the first 20 hours, maybe pvp is better, idk, I dont play pvp in games like this.

For a game released in 2016 the Division still holds up quite well in 2022. If you enjoy loot shooters like the Borderlands series or Destiny series, I highly recommend this game. I'd also recommend it if you're into the apocalyptic genre and/or political thrillers. I picked this game up on a whim back in 2016 for Xbox and loved it so much that I bought it again for a play through on PC. The world is immersive and the story is fantastic.

The only real con I can think of at this current moment is that the player base is very low these days making the PvPvE areas a tad less action packed.

Game is fun but it's pretty janky.
At current state they fixed *some* of the bullet sponginess of the enemies, and most missions/endgame content are pretty solid, with some balance issues of course.
Also the Dark Zone gives the chills too. Expect it to be like invasions in Souls games where the aggressor will be more prepared/have more resources than the victim.
Recommend because the fun factor beats the jankiness factor.

The Division is a game where you star as a member of society turned 2nd Wave Division Agent, a last stand against total chaos, where you will fight other players, funny janitors with napalm throwers, literal street people, prisoners, tacticool squads, players and people who have an obsession with cutting off your fucking hand because they lovvvveeeeee watches 
Embrace cool music, cool locations, breezy visuals and a sleek UI 
Fight in the sewers, the underground, some watch obsessed wolfpack of watch thieves while high on chocolate bars and loaded with HEAT rounds, oh and a fucking battle copter
Sure there isn't a super bunch of players around these days but it is quite the experience when you aren't getting spanked by some dork with a full optimized shotty build/w nomad set, always be careful in the dark zone
Interestingly there is little blood for the hundreds of bullets you will plug into some man with a baseball bat

Have some challenging missions and some repetitive side missions 
Fun to play with comrades, not as bad as I thought would be

I just shot a booby trap that the Cleaners left laying around town that had a dog laying next to it and now it's smoking and not moving, so I figure this as as good a time as any to write this review.

Pros: the immersion is top notch. I've never been to NYC, but standing under the Brooklyn Bridge looking up instills a sense of awe that many games never elicit. Also, considering this game was released in 2016, the writers either had done excellent research or they were paid to write predictive programming. I'm going with the later, but it's still weird to look back 6 years and see what they were trying to warn/normalize us about. Also, despite the game being 6 years old, there are this people playing it as of this writing, but you'll probably still have to do most of the grind alone as matchmaking for missions takes forever. I think the people still playing are all endgame.

Negatives: Progress is SLOW. Takes forever to level up, and the gear is exceedingly bland. There are no classes. The agents all have access to the same skills so the ARPG elements feel tacked on. I'm a fan of the Rainbow Six Vegas series of cover-based shooters, but if I wasn't I would not recommend this. Also, the female characters are butt-ugly. Feminist game devs likely to blame. The NPCs look fine, so they must've not given the menial tasks to the diversity hires. Typical.

Though you may see reviews of the hacking and the communication of the developers, I urge you to take a moment or two and watch some gameplay. The game truly shines when you have 3 others to form a squad and complete content with a group. That said, the game does not require a group for a majority of the content and there is an abundance of things to explore/complete playing solo. 

Upon reaching maximum level you are presented with daily quests & instances for credits and high end gear. This is eerily similar of the end game of WoW and other mmorpg’s. After looking at other reviews and having experience with end game content in similar games- The Division brings me back for more. For example, you can forgo dailies and prioritize extractions from the Dark Zone, where there is always that uncertainty of betrayal from other agents. 

All in all I would recommend this game. It is something fresh and fun for me. I like the MMO aspects and the story as well as the absolutely beautiful graphics. The major con with The Division is the lack of things to do once you reach the end of the game, and the developers are working to remedy this issue by releasing a steady stream of DLC in only a couple of days. I’m really excited to see what lies in store for the future of this game, as I believe it has a great story & concept, the refreshing new additions to the genre only strengthen this game & I look forward to seeing where the game is after the DLC releases.

Came back to this after about a year and half-away (I got it at launch and played very slowly then got bored and moved to other games). In the end, I found it to be fairly competent looter shooter. The cover mechanics are pretty interesting in that they help you navigate from cover to cover fairly well in most cases, though it can be a little "sticky" at times. I found myself trying to work with them and use them to my advantage this time around and there is something to be said for it.

The bullet-sponge enemies are a problem but nowhere near as bad as when the game first came out. While the game has character classes and defense/support/offense builds it is somewhat hard to make that aspect stand out in single-player, especially since the game's economy is fairly harsh, both in terms of loot and in terms of money and mission rewards. You will be somewhat at the mercy of your best drop in terms of how you play. If you get lucky you get lucky, if not, I can see how normal drops would be upsetting. That said, the game actually does work fairly well when you stop trying to rush the enemies and, instead, focus on fighting enemies from cover, thinning the herd but not rushing it. When you play the game at the Division's speed and don't try and hurry the fight it really does open up a lot and becomes quite engaging. I found myself enjoying the missions, even the side-missions, because, in a way, the shootouts are crafted reasonably well--given that you play it "the way the developers 'intended'" you to play it. The pieces fall into place and it turned out to be quite an enjoyable few hours finishing the game. I thought I'd rush through the last few missions but ended up having a good amount of fun taking on side-missions.
