Pro:
-Everything looks nice and its fun exploring NYC 3 months from now
-Back alleys and roof top climbing. Lots of it, the environment is well done
-Looting and scavenging is fun
-All the feeling of a guerilla and looter shooter that Homefront Revolution only gave a taste of (if you can ignore the grind and bull sh it)
-Sometimes the grind is worth it and you can have a fun time


Cons:
-You can die behind cover because 2 pixels of your hat was showing. 
-If you're playing single player mainly this is much more grueling
-Enemies can 4 shot you but it takes 500 rounds to kill them, and never reload
-GE's like onslaught glitch out so you're ammo types can match and still do no damage
The combat is awful, you're character will decide that instead of running to cover he'll stand or walk around slowly to make it easier to die to, or otherwise run to cover thats where the enemy is who kill you in 2 shots
-ALL THE CONTROLS ARE A SS. YOU CLIMB ONTO COVER AND DIVE INTO GUN FIRE LIKE A RETARD ALL THE FU CKING TIME
-For some reason, and this is how you know there was no actual oversight into the game, they made an apocalypse urban warfare game with a neo bubonic twist, with very few masks, let alone gas masks. It's an item that you don't even see despite being everywhere in the game and really only when you go into contaminated zones and the dark zone which doesn't come till at least level 22
-The most boring faces and clothing, it's NYC and everyone apparently only looted Sports Authority and Holister. Very little clothing options despite again, being an apocalypse game. The bandits and thugs have cooler looks than you
-Your character will purposely jump on top of something just so it can be shot by the boss with low health that you've been fighting for the past hour
-Flame throwers WILL hit you from a mile away, and because FU CK you, they can run and use them at the same time and you can't do jack about it because again, FU CK you
-Any kind of fire at all is a bull sh it insta kill unless it's on your enemies which of course -2 damage at most and that's being kind because you know, how dare you ask for fire or explosives to be effective in a Ubisoft game, what is this a triple A studio or something????
- Manhunt is bs because without a group you're going against medics with endless supply stations, engies with endless turrets, etc 
-Toggle auto vault on at your own risk, whenever your player finds cover or even a fence he'll jump over it, even if it means jumping directly into sniper fire. So many times I try to take cover just for him to randomly decide "fu ck you Im climbing this bit ch" and die
-You'll finish a mission, walk outside the area, and get blasted by an enemy boss out of nowhere. You'll die in a mission, respawn aaaaaall the way back at base, walk outside and the game shows it's appreciation with a nice big F U CK YOU by planting a random a ss boss with the lamest sounding name RIGHT IN FRONT of the exit. Oh you're fighting a street boss? Out of nowhere his minions and health fully respawn because FU CK YOU. Street bosses are a pain in the ass. Oh the enemy is chasing you because they one shot your riot shield away somehow? Here, 3 bandits right in the middle so you're trapped because FU CK you.
-You feel a sense of saving people on main missions sometimes, but you rarely get to actually save people because all the enemies already killed them, or they fled and they're now invincible.  Civies hound you for your meager supplies and will curse you out but they'll give you a beanie for your only medkit
-Random one shot kills on you by an enemy, even if they're way lower than you on levels
-Everybody sucks your dick and acts like you're the hero, and all the people on your side say "we are surprised you weren't a gung ho agent who'd wind up crisped by the cleaners in a week" which really puts things into perspective. Not that it matters, you don't care about anyone in this game it's so shallow
-The radio guy gets stale fast. It's supposed to be a conspiracy nut AJ type with a New Yorker accent but it just comes off as vague conspiratorial ranting that's been diluted with "Ey I'm walkin 'ere" NY attitude and I want to say it comes off well, but he says the same things over and over, it doesn't mix well, like a cheap AJ who's even more scared of naming them. He just becomes more and more annoying each day
-They go through the process of dehumanizing and showing how evil (with cheesy one liners like "I need to gut me a cop") the bad guys are, setting women and children on fire, firing at civies, etc, then after you defeat the group, show them all as desperate, wanting to get out, or willing to do the dirty work to get rid of the plague and stop the chaos. 
-The two skeletons holding hands in half life 2 have a more convincing love struggle than (and I had to check for this) Cecilia and Tony. 
-Single player is pushed into multi player but nobody plays the multi player option except in pvp maybe, nobody takes the agency queues so you don't get to make units like you used to when it came out. No clan or guild system so grouping is even more dead. Also you don't see or help any other players unless you're in a group or in PvP
-Cypher fragments become useless once you have literally every clothing in the game which isn't that many, making them a pointless mass reward
-If you have auto-ctrl on, you're character would rather play shoots and ladders with the rappelling equipment (ropes that let you go up and down quicker to access points), then actually go and do the objective. I can't tell you how many times I'd rappel in to stop looters from destroying the equipment, just to have a fight with the rope system as my character would rather go up and down over and over again.
-Another game where you don't have to buy anything because you can either make it or get it while out in the streets looting or helping people. And you're always swapping out old gear with new gear due to levels and whatnot, so have fun updating all your loadouts everytime you get some new equpment
-You got to play through the Uplay launcher which is one of the worst things about it
-No changing your facial looks so whatever you choose in character maker is it
-The worst spawn locations I have ever since in a game
-NPC allies are FU CKING useless. The enemy will ignore them to kill you and they'll stand around letting you get overrun fighting with only a pistol
-Enemies can spawn randomly behind you during a street battle, it's stupid. You'll see 3 enemies, then 4 more spawn behind you who shoot at you, then as you're running while they chase you with flame throwers, 3 OTHER enemies spawn further ahead and shoot you. It's like the game is purposely taunting you
-Enemy grenades will insta kill you without even exploding, they'll just pass you and you'll die. Your grenades, like all Ubisoft games, are no better than water balloons unless they're way under your level. Enemy grenades also  kill you behind a solid wall. They won't even blow up, 
-Survival is full of problems like Stuvyesant having few barrels and shelters and enemies one shotting you. 
-Incursion is just lazy enemy spam
-Turrets are crap
-Survival is garbage in general, you walk around the corner and there could be three gold tier enemies against you with a pistol
-After awhile it turns into boring cqc 1 v 10 boss fights where enemies spawn behind you constantly.
-LMB is sh it enemy + boss spam.40 guys on every corner and base so you can't move around without fighting them all
-Outbreak is a the worst GE out of them all


tl:dr The worst game I have ever played in my entire life, fu ck you Ubisoft. There's no replay value, let alone even wanting to finish it it shits on you so much. Complete garbage. 

Edit: I write as I see so some of it may be out dated

This "game" is, if anything, a proof of concept. It looks gorgeous but fails to deliver something deeply entertaining, fun and worth investment.

The environnement is immersive and amazing to look at ! But its playground is virtually empty. I really thought that it would be a more organic world with dynamic stuff happening, and scripted npc you could find here and there with their stories and quest lines. Maybe even choices to make... The Division is NOT an RPG, it is really straight forward, mechanical and bland. The activities are repetitive and fall flat real quick (picking up "hidden" collectibles we don't care about, and shooting random squad of scums).
Also you don't get to come across other players while exploring the map. You can only see them in safe headquarters here and there (unless you group up).

The gameplay is just effortless. The game tries so hard to look immersive and realist, but then you engage in a shootout, only to realize enemies are stupid arcade sponges. So out of the place !
And of course AI has aimbot.
There are "abilities", but it feels more like a 2015 developpement checklist than real decisions matching the gamedesign.
It's not even fun to kill enemies. The feedbacks are non existent when you hit.

As for the loot and attachment system, well it's not that bad, but the UI is terrible, which makes it all a pain to appreciate eventually. Too many menus to go through, options to mark, mod or compare equipements, buttons to hold etc. Just a non intuitive mess you only want to exit as soon as possible.

Overall, it's nice to take a round in the game for 5-10 hours with maxed out settings. But that's about it.
At least it has its own identity in the openworld genre. Shame they spent more time on props variety than storytelling, gameplay and quests.

Simple. If you are wanting to just play the game for the story and build up to division 2, either starting here or going back to the beginning from 2, then sure play it. 

Game wise, still well made, fundamentally great, and enjoyable to play. Best with coop but great solo as well. The graphics arent much worse than Division 2 either which is a great plus!
 
DZ is mostly dead, and so far, Ive ran into very few people. Ive ran into more griefers and a couple cheaters already which makes it meh.

Two biggest issues i have found with the game as so far, are the super crappy enemy spawns. They are horrid. You will literally clear an entire road, turn, and have enemies spawn almost touching you a fair amount. This makes a COVER based shooter have a core problem of not having cover. If the enemies spawned on a more flanking pattern that would give a proper reactionary time. 

Second issue is locking standard global stuff behind paywalls. Once you have completed the game what do you do? You do the new stuff, new content, global events, and if purchased, the paid content. 

But when item 1 on the global event list is locked behind paid content, its kind of a middle finger. I wont condone that.

But the graphics? Oh boy they are 110% what makes this game appeal to me, every zone is so incredibly detailed and appealing to the eye you might forget that this is a game with very little playercount and running on 5+ year old hardware. The story is... alright. I dont usually plsy games for the story anyways. 
Concluding this review i will say this: absolutely gorgeous game, 95% of areas will take your breath away. But other than the graphics its a typical pve first person shooter with some pvp. If you like games that look good and have a decently fast pc then this might be the game for you.

Played both titles on console before playing on PC, and I have to say the 1st game is better than the 2nd. Make sure to get the Survival DLC, it's really good.

The reason I won't recommend it is due to the poor performance on PC. No matter what settings I choose, my CPU and GPU turn to lava; and there are also far more cheaters/modders on PC compared to console. Some say the pressure this game puts on your system is due to memory leaks, but at any rate it seems pretty unfixable which is a shame. I tried the various "fixes" like underclocking CPU and deactivating half the CPU cores, but the results are barely noticable. To put it into context, my system reaches higher temps playing Division 1 in low settings than it does playing Red Dead 2 at very high/ultra settings.

Ryzen 5 / RTX 2060.

I would definitely recommend playing this game now and looking forward to this franchise.

This game is an absolute BLAST to play with friends. The campaign is very fun to play through (even multiple times), the locations and atmosphere are used creatively and are beautifully designed, and the open world is pretty accurate to real-world NYC. This game is a looter-shooter, and I think the loot is well worth the grind in many cases. The PVE and PVP aspects of this game are strong and intertwine well in the Dark Zone, which is hands down is my favorite interpretation of a high risk high reward environment; it is what I think carried this game so far, and it adds an extensive amount of replayability value. 

The Dark Zone - this lawless area where no rules are applied to anyone, along with being one of the best ways to farm loot in the game, creates a HEAVY incentive to throw unwritten game ethics aside all in the name for better loot. Although I have played this game for so long the DZ still creates amazing highlights and noteworthy moments solely because of player interactions and the PVP experiences alike. Just yesterday my squad and I only planned to do a quick few runs in the DZ to help one of our friends gear up to World Tier 5, and that turned into a multi-hour long session of grinding loot and killing lots of rogues. Although there are other games with these kind of environments - Escape From Tarkov is an example - none come close to the uniqueness of the Dark Zone. The thrill and fear you get by popping a flare and having to defend your ground from other players for 2 excruciatingly long minutes just so you can get out with that one gear piece or exotic you have been grinding so long for, is simply unmatched. Sure, there are ways to avoid players and obtain gear but its only to an extent; there is NO safe place in the Dark Zone. The PVP and the Dark Zone compliment each other and go hand in hand with one another. Many other games have quick encounters that end with whoever can shoot quicker but the PVP in this game can last a little while and is very unique. Obviously gear is important when trying to take down other players, but skill is even more essential. There are many ways to play PVP and there are a lot of opportunities to outplay enemy players and use new strategies, or you can just try and see who can do more damage in a quick face-off 1v1. Besides the core gameplay of PVP being different from other games, its more-so the circumstances of how the Dark Zone works that makes it feel refreshing and fun. Instead of being pitted from team to team or every man for themselves like most games, the Dark Zone has no end goal for PVP; it is just a matter of how long you can last. In a server full of 24 players, it is quite exhilarating trying to see how many people you can take on with your gear and skill, and having a coordinated group of 4 can lead to a long server-wide manhunt on your heads. Or you can be on the other side of the spectrum, trying to kill some server-terrorizing rogues along with every other player right by your side.

There are some critiques I would give to this game. The build diversity is none-existent in late endgame, where classified gearsets are simply the best use for nearly any situation. Although these gearsets lead to better team-play in many gamemodes and creates a player's ultimate farming goal, once you reach that goal, the PVE side of the game becomes very redundant and unrewarding (to be fair, reaching this point takes quite a while). Besides builds themselves being extremely easy to put together, understanding how gear works can be confusing for many new players. I had to explain and go very in-depth to my friends on how certain mechanics work in the game and how loot works in general which is something I think the sequel to this game, The Division 2, did phenomenally well.

For the nearly 3 years (maybe 4 now? can't remember lol) I have played this game on console and PC, I have played it mostly by myself. But I would HIGHLY RECOMMEND grabbing a group of people to play along side you because this game is definitely made to be played with friends. On sale, I would say this game is a must-buy to any person that likes shooters and it is a one of a kind experience (I didn't even talk about the season pass, but 100% buy it if its on sale as well - underground and survival are insanely cool). If people just want a solid PVE experience out of this game, you'll find it, but I would definitely just recommend just picking up The Division 2 (along with the DLC) instead. Even though I don't play this games as much as I used to I always come back to it some time or another and can confidently say that it is one of the best looter-shooters on the market today.

I have played roughly 750 hours of this game, mostly on console. However, I went full retard and bought a computer. I am playing it through again and the graphics hold up well. The main gameplay loop is repetitive; i.e. go grab this, go help them, go defend this, go fix this, etc. That being said, Ubisoft has done a good job making this gallery/cover-shooter-esque game seem less repetitive with its great looking atmosphere and changing scenery. One minute you're in MSG, then you are in a subway system, and then running down the street, inadvertently shutting car doors and taking bad-boi lives. The game, in my most expert, honest, and truthful opinion, is worth the sale price, including the season pass. 
There is a whole piece of the game that is PvP, but I am only a half-chad gamer and suck at PvP, unless it is CoD:MW2 in the late 2000's, yeeting throwing knives across the map. The multiplayer, from what I hear, went from okay-ish at launch, to a polished and enjoyable treat, unless you go to the Dark Zone solo; that's when you will quickly get corn-holed by 4 min-max brosephs looking to out alpha male your shit. 
Even with the age of the game, and the faults pointed out by more intellectually stable youtuber's, I would still get this game. It has become a Christmas tradition to pop this bad boy on and have a go. Something about the winter time in this game and how Ubisoft depicts a desolate, sparse, cold, beautiful, gun-filled NY makes me want to have a little chug and tug, if you smell what I'm stepping in. And a good day to you and yours.

[h1] My Review for Tom Clancy’s The Division [/h1]

[b] Positives [/b]
[list]
    [*] Gives a nice NYC in Winter during a Virus outbreak with a city in chaos.
    [*] Customization in this game is very good from the guns to even your clothes to make your character unique.
    [*] Single player/Coop to give you the feel of playing as an elite agent.
[/list]

[B] Negatives [/B]
[list]
    [*] The AI in this game is so bad, the enemy shot me through walls and doors at points where I was hiding I would turn the corner they would already be aiming at me shooting.
    [*] You come to NY with the most Useless agent who complains about not being out there the whole time. I expect something more than having an agent that would sit around and complain all the meanwhile saying they did great things. 
    [*] Lastly, this is a personal one I think when you clear a checkpoint in the game it should be taken over by your agents. I cleared one and instantly enemies spawned on top of me *4* of them at that. After being in a long battle than having 4 directly spawn on top of my head its things like that. 


[B]Overall[/B]

[i]This game has alot of [b]Positives[/b] and alot of [b]Negatives[/b] but I love tactical shooters and even though this is not realistic as items can be legendary and such it still feels good the movement and firing mechanics (such as blind firing). I did enjoy the game very much although due to some bugs that did quite frustrate me a bit it was a love hate relationship. Def rate it a 6.5/10[/i]

Buy it and say goodbye to several hundred hours of you time.

As of writing this review I have played about 56 hours of the game and have completed every main and side mission, as well as every encounter in the game.

The main missions are broke up into 3 categories, medical, power, and defense, all of which give you credits to upgrade your home base for the applicable category. The main missions are interesting enough, and they reward you with cool gear and fun bosses to fight, some of them can even be very difficult, but there simply are not enough of them, there are (based on memory) about 12 or 13 of them in the game, and one final mission which is the end of the campaign.

The story is not very interesting, its very simple, and the clear focus is gameplay, which while is good, gets repetitive.

That being said the game does look incredibly, and runs fantastically as well, on a GTX 1080 I was getting over 144 fps on all ultra, and now that I have a 3070 I'm seeing frames in the 300s at times, so this is a very good looking game that is playable on older hardware. The UI of the game is really cool and interesting, I love the hologram look of it all and it is definitely unique to the series.

The side content of the Division is broken up into two categories; side missions, and encounters. Side missions are standard side content, some cool investigations and missing persons, there are some with up to 5 parts so they do give you something to do, however they can be boring at times and can get repetitive in certain instances, however I still found them enjoyable.

Encounters are, in a nutshell, go here, kill these guys, leave. They are incredibly boring, and are basically just to be used to level up, get credits for your base upgrades, and get new gear. I did all of them anyway because I'm a psychopath but if you are playing the game, I would only do these when you want too/ need credits, don't force yourself to play them as they are not that interesting.

Overall, the concept is great but the story is uninteresting, it was fun with friends doing the multiplayer content outside of the story, but I would say if your playing it by yourself, it is best consumed with a good TV show to watch in your second monitor.

fun game

This game reminds me of why I left the PC gaming world in the first place. It is incredibly unstable, and according to Steam I was only able to play it for a total of 3 Hours (not to mention several hours of researching how to make it run).  I am having the same issue many others apparently have had. The game loads in windowed full screen mode, and when you attempt to switch it to full screen, it crashes the next time you run the game. Some say it is an issue with overlays (funny that it has to run through an Ubisoft App to play after being purchased from Steam). Others have posted it is a matter of disabling DX12. I have tried the majority of options online and a few others, and the only thing that worked for one play through was optimizing the game from Geforce Experience. A new message displayed after the last attempt that read, "The Division Services are not available at this time. Please try again later. Delta C-0-1302. Its a bit funny because I was able to play for a mind blowing 3 hours - and then one day it just decided not to work anymore. Unfortunate, for the brief time I played the game it was great. I will be looking into a refund for the purchase, and I urge any person considering buying this game caution - it is garbage and not worth your time even during a Steam sale.

That is like 75 cents an hour you pay just to complete the main story and get leveled up. I didn't do the actual math for you out there to correct me, more of a ish measurement. I recommend if you have never played Division to at least play the missions and all the extra things the game has to offer. Lots of open world stuff to do. I played on xbox before coming to pc and starting over. hours are definitely not accurate.

I had this game for the xbox one. over 600 hours it says on achievements. My friends and I decided to come to the pc world and we discussed how would this game be on pc. We didn't buy it till it was on sale. Today we just finished the main story and leveled up to 30. After not playing the campaign for several years and starting completely over again. This game was worth every penny. Co-op is amazing to die and laugh with your friends. It was just as fun as the first time we played it.  Though matchmaking is dead you may play many games solo unless you have some friends to play with. We are going to do all expansion stuff and make our way back to world tier five. player base is low for pvp stuff but the co-op is more than enough for the price for sure. I wish Division 2 continued on this path, it is also a great game. Here is to hoping for Division 3 and some luck to get my classified gear sets back before the manhunts destroy me every second. If you like shooters and co-op with friends and or strangers this game was fantastic and the  story of a pandemic is kinda in par with what the world is facing today. Hope you buy it and have some fun, then go get Division 2, and hopefully wait on 3. Good luck and have some fun.

Edit (November 19th, 2021) --- I was going through some of my old reviews and found this one. I changed my recommendation from "No" to "Yes", but I left the original text of the old review below.

The Division improved significantly in the years after its release, and became popular enough that I put in several hundred hours and they even made a sequel.


OLD REVIEW (Now Outdated):

It took me a long time, several days of play time, to come to this conclusion. 

The Division is, in no way, a *bad* game. It is, however, aggressively mediocre. It is forgettable, deeply flawed, and a huge missed opportunity.

The first thing I want to get to is the Dark Zone -- it is, in both practice and concept, a horrible experience. The best gear in the game, ostensibly the goal for most people playing an RPG, is gated behind an experience that relishes having other players steal your hard-earned loot. I literally would have zero problem with this IF there were a way to get that kind of gear elsewhere in PvE, but there is not. The stance of the developers and some fans of "well nut up and play the game or go away" on this is simply insulting. Why they would put this DayZ/Rust-style anarchy as the center of endgame is beyond me.

The next big issue: enemy variety. There IS none. I have now played almost 18 hours of this game, and I have encountered FIVE kinds of enemy total: 1) hoodie wearing thug with a pistol, 2) hoodie wearing thug with a baseball bat, 3) cleaner (a faction focused on burning out the infection) with a flamethrower, 4) cleaner with a riot shield, 5) bullet sponge boss. This is absolutely *absurd*, and downright embarassing. EIGHTEEN HOURS in, and I've been killing hundreds of the exact same mob, apparently all named Alex because the line "THEY GOT/KILLED ALEX" is chirped ad nauseum by the braindead AI.

Next: the story. PATHETIC. Your character is mute, and thus far in the game (18 hours of play) I've met four main characters, only one of which has had more than ~1 minute of talking time. A doctor, a security chief, a "quirky" technician, and a fellow Division agent. Where's this story going? Who knows! What's my driving force to continue? Who knows! It's as if the writers threw their hands in the air and said "well nobody is playing this game for the story anyway, right?" -- wrong. For a game that clearly blew so much budget on making a cinematic story experience, it's simply sad how flat on their faces it fell. In all the story missions I've done, there's no exposition except through some radio chatter, you never meet any of the bosses (they all have generic names and tons of HP), etc etc etc

The final nail in the coffin for me is just how mind-numbingly boring it can be to play alone. Matchmaking is only available while in a "safe house" hub, where you are sharded with 5-6 other players (most of which are AFK), and even then matchmaking is only available for story missions. If you wanted to explore and do side quests, you would need to try and matchmake under "Free Roam", which nobody queues for. So you do most of the side content alone, and you NEED to do side content because the story missions are spaced so far apart in level that you couldn't seamlessly go from one to the next.

I think the true issue behind The Division is that you feel unimportant. You are simply a *drone*. The entire First Wave of agents died or went missing (SPOILER for the first 5 minutes of the game, I'm the worst), and you could go missing too and they would just send more. You get so little money for completing missions and for selling the loot you acquire that you feel like you can't buy anything. It's a 40-ish hour slog (if you play comfortably rather than powergame) to the top, and then you just pull your hair out in frustration over the gimmicks of The Dark Zone.

I hate number rating systems because of how they boil down complex opinions into highly subjective numbers, but if I had to rate this I would give it a 6/10. It's a solid concept, much like Destiny was, but the delivery falls flat in a pitiable way. It needs a *lot* of work, and it needs it yesterday. 


Edit: I feel it's important to be honest and amend my initial review with one fact -- the best gear *is* available outside the Dark Zones. The caveat is that the acquisition rate is absurdly lower. It's no different than a cheap mobile game saying "oh you can get all the best characters without buying them", but it's through a 1% drop-rate daily chest. 

Another key distinction: "it's being worked on [optional: insert "you fucker"]" is not a valid defense. I am reviewing the game I paid 60 dollars for, not the one it vaguely promises to be.

The Division has improved significantly since launch and it shows. The game is really engaging, missions are well designed, AI is pretty smart on higher difficulties, and the game is also very rewarding. There are many different ways to grind for valuable loot in the endgame: dark zone, survival, incursions, main missions, free roam, resistance, and much more. The soundtrack and sound design in general is strong. Visuals still hold up today, and the atmosphere of the game is excellent. The main story and characters are not anything special, but The Division universe is held up by great audio logs and environmental storytelling; allowing the player to come to their own conclusions. Unfortunately, the playerbase has dropped significantly, so it's especially difficult to find players for end game activities. If you have a group of 3 other friends who are willing to play through until the end, I would recommend it, since the game is a co-op shooter at its core. Most of my time spent was solo, so it was definitely frustrating to find people to play outside of special timed events. Play solo at your own risk. I wouldn't recommend purchasing The Division for full price, but if it's on sale, I would absolutely recommend it to people who would like a tactical looter shooter. DLCs aren't required, however if you find yourself enjoying The Division's base game, I would highly recommend you pick them up when they're on sale too.

Tom Clancy's The Division is a great game that scratched so many itches you look for in gaming with collectibles, map completion, PvE, PvP, and more. I am still super bummed that the sequel isn't on Steam (yet?) and that I haven't played it but for this original entry to the series I played so many hours and didn't regret any of it.

Regardless, this game is worth a buy in 2021 and hopefully we get the sequel at some point.

It's simply not fun.

Before I begin, I want to say that the gunplay in this game is exceptional. Guns feel good to shoot. Because it's an RPG shooter hybrid, you obviously not going to be able to kill enemies in 1 or 2 hits. It's the tactical elements though that make this RPG shooter more than just a numbers game.  You have to take cover to avoid taking enemy gunfire, you're encouraged to maneuver around covers to flank the enemies, you have to know when your position is exposed and pull back when needed be, et cetera. It works suprisingly well and it almost makes me forget that this is still an RPG at its core, with loot drops and stat changes. 

And yet, even though it's designed to be played as a tactical cover shooter, more often than not, you encounter enemies that don't play by the same rules as you do. You will die over and over because enemies spawn from behind you, one-shotting you in the process. Enemies frequently spam grenades at your position, without any cooldown. The "elite" enemies are probably the most BS elements about this game. They're massive bullet sponges, they have infinite ammo, and they are all equipped with cool shiny weapons like a flamethrower or a minigun. You don't get to use these weapons. These enemies also seem have to some sense of self-awareness. It's like they know they're bullet sponges. They don't take cover, they don't flinch when they get shot at, they know their weapons are extremely effective at close range so they will instantly rush your position as soon as they see you. 

The Division should be a good game but it's designed in a way that is extremely frustrating. The kind of frustration that you usually get in competitve multiplayer games when you lose over and over again and you don't get to learn anything from those losses. 

I play games to have fun. The Division is not fun.

The Division provides a solid experience, with its solid, yet not revolutionary gameplay mechanics. What makes the game special is the depiction of a modern, post-apocalyptic New York, which in many ways represent the state of modern day society we face all over the world. The Division will provide you hours upon hours of fantastic gameplay. Just make sure you have your buddies or that you find other players to play with in order to really get the full experience.

The Division is a great game, unfortunately the sequel The Division 2 is not available  on Steam, which is a big mistake by Ubisoft.

There are constantly errors that prevent gameplay. There's no option to play offline, so you HAVE to play online, but it only works if your internet is absurdly good. Very disappointing. Also, the weapons aren't particularly good, you have to empty an entire magazine just to kill someone, which makes it hard. Not fun or challenging hard, just annoying hard.

To start the review , Honestly i love this game , it has a story of about 20-30 hours depending on how much you get carried , could be even 5 hours but hey let me tell you right now , it's not a story game , it's a grinding game, if you know you can grind for hours on end , i'd say get the gold edition on sale, as the online servers are pretty empty now , but don't worry, You can get a good team pretty frequently, and in terms of the Dark Zone and Last Stand expansion (PvP) it's filled with cheaters but sometimes you can find and get a good pvp experience.
that's all i have to say, thank you for reading.

I recently gave this game a 3rd go, I rate this game around 70%, the game has its pros & cons.

+ Game can be playable if you grind side missions and encounters before hopping into main missions.

- Enemies are bullet sponges, if they are 2-3 levels above your level.
- The movement system is disaster.
- Feeling like there's delay when moving.

  Borderlands 2.

Going into this, having never played any sort of Tom Clancy's game before, I expected a Call of Duty like shooter with a "one of the same" kind of story and clunky controls. I was mostly wrong apparently.The story so far is interesting, the objectives are challenging (especially on hard difficulty) and the multiplayer is fun. The graphics are pretty good and the overall feel of the environment will leave you immersed for sure. As a newcomer to the franchise and to tactical shooters in general I still find myself going in balls deep into enemy territory and dying almost instantly with no backup. I like the idea of needing someone to have your back in order to advance to the mission, and so far, even after countless wipes on missions, I have never seen ONE person rage quitting. I expected it to be a lot worse mainly because of the things I had heard about this game from forums and other reviews. Personally, this game was a pleasant surprise and it is definitely worth the buy while on sale.

From the height of the Ubisoft Golden Years, a True Classic.  This game came out towards the close of an era. After taking hits for a few release debacles (Silent Hunter, among others), Ubisoft finally hired some real talent and we got games like Rainbow Six Siege, Ghost Recon: Wildlands, Far Cry 4, and finally the Division. The Division is sort of a super polished 'every thing we have learned about punchy cover based shooters).  There will likely be stuff that some don't like.  But there is not a single mode of this game that isn't compelling if you like a punchy shooter.  
The One thing that does not work for me is the issues I am having with the second party Ubisoft client.  I have been locked out (Multiple times) with accusations I was not using legitimate software. I paid for this game, multiple fucking times and across multiple platforms. And this is AFTER the numerous times I have been burned on shitty or outright aborted launches (Silent Hunter and Flashback ring a bell?).  I can now not even log in.  I am going to try one more reinstall, and then right this has-been company off and wish the Playstation crowd good luck with them.

I basically gave up on this game for the following reasons. 

1) I am maxed out in gear score, got the classifieds i want, and already beat the entire game.

However, the other expansion "Underground" is VERY boring in my opinion, Only thing that is good in the underground is fighting the hunters as you would in survival, But instead of getting survival caches you will be fighting them for classifieds or exotics.

I had put about 700 hours into the game when it released within the first three months and it was one of, if not, the best experience in my gaming history. Once you beat the game you realized that the journey has just begun. I worked so hard to acquire gear and was rewarded. I did stop playing for a while after one of the updates because they nerfed all the gear I worked so hard for but a year later it clearly was for the better. I have returned and many more updates have taken place with tons of new content that was added and from the looks of it there are still a few more updates to go. I was amazed because there are not many games that receive a lot of attention after release. The player base has been at a constant and I wish those who have gotten a wrong impression of the game would give it another shot. I am excited for the future update involving something called the "The Dead Zone" as the trailer that I saw looked like they planned to add zombies or infected people. Thank you Massive.

Pros:

Post apocalypse with only humans with little enemy variety makes for boring gameplay
Movement is super clunky, takes forever to go around corners while in cover
There's very little multiplayer oriented content
No achievements

UI is a gigantic mess it makes no sense at all
Forces you to use unity launcher and having an ubisoft account
The game is online only even in single player
You can rarely get stuck on the environment like a chair or a box and only way to fix is fast travel or login again
The MC cannot jump, crouch, lay prone. 
The game tries to sell you DLC at several points and there's a cash shop

Get it on sale if you like looter shooters. It's not a bad game but definitely nothing to write home about. This could be so much more if instead of making it a cash cow, they had the players' satisfaction as their main aim.

There's just something about the NYC winter that keeps D1 special. The game had gorgeous environment design and will always be one of the best among many, many games.

However,

It has rubbish health system, over-simplify skills and pretty silly late-game combat. (Which kinda improved in D2, except for the last part, the late-game combat in D2 still a bit silly, but that's FPS RPG genre problem in general.)

D1's campaign is saved by the whole game design, your skills are based on research point, which makes you run around NYC to explore, and if you put your heart into the collectibles and stories (Some excellent VA.), the city become lively to look around. Sadly, those liveliness  end the moment you finish collecting them, ironically still way better than D2. D2 is a grindy, busy city with hollow souls.

The best way to play the game is in a party of duo and clearing mission map only in Hard level during campaign. I always go back to D1 with my friend once in a long while, we took our time slowly on every return with new characters, just chilling through.

Late games are pretty meh. You can play some game modes for gears, but you'll lost interest on the grinds very quickly unless it's your thing.

I recommend everyone to buy this game...

I really tried to enjoy this game because there are some great elements to the gameplay, and the story is solid enough. However it is horribly built around needing to be played with teammates even though it makes it seem like it can be played singleplayer all the way through. Unlike most co op games, it doesn't adjust the number of enemies or the difficulty based on how many people are playing. So if you're a lone wolf like myself, the more challenging missions and difficulties in the endgame are nearly impossible and super frustrating. Also often missions just a level or two above your current level are too difficult to complete solo. Overall as an RPG it is terribly balanced in my opinion. In the majority of the game enemies did insane damage, my guns felt like pellet guns (like seriously empyting 25 AR rounds just to kill one enemy??), and possibly the worst thing about this game to me, is how incessantly grindy it is. Like absurdly grindy. I don't feel like going in depth but the grind in this game is tedious, repetitive, and just not very satisfying. If you have a group of friends to play this game with I'm sure it's a whole different experience and much more enjoyable, but don't be tricked like me into thinking this is gonna be a fun game to do solo. Do not recommend.

I'm not gonna lie, when I went to go see the reviews after finishing this game with my friend I realized that this game has a total of mixed reviews. Basically, what im trying to say is that im surprised people still find this game fun after realizing that so much intel that veteran players knew was destroyed and useless. The updates in imo killed this game's spirit causing people to rage more. It still feels the same from console but somewhat more of advantage. I do recommend getting this game but if you're not too much of a lone wolf or just expect a long distance campaign along with the DLCs then don't get it. Why are there no steam achievements? Such a shame. Also, some end-game areas have unpolished movement glitches, now 5 years after launch. smh. Also, requirement to stay always online leaves a bad taste when your network gives problems at the end of a boss fight. 

This is a post apocalyptic cover based looter shooter. Exploring Manhattan in winter is a joy, punishment for not staying in cover is fair, enemies trying to flank you provides a good challenge, the variety of roles is commendable, and most activities earn you sweet goodies.

Expected faster progress through the story, but story missions are difficult if you're underlevelled and playing solo. Solo difficulty was very enjoyable, but requires respecting the recommended levels. The campaign story is pretty lame, but the story of the city, told through echoes and the smaller stories about the people, highlight the best the medium of video games has to offer. Some of the side missions are recycled garbage though.

Very enjoyable, steam achievements would have been nicer. Recommend buying base game on sale, 8/10.

The gameplay is wonky, but practice makes perfect.

A 3rd person cover based looter shooter, in the backdrop of virtual 2020.

Where the government caused all of the factions you are fighting, where only your actions are seen as heroic.

Of course you don't think about it because, you're just following orders.

Where survivors trade a fancy weapons for water.

And using excessive force is always the answer instead of talking your way out.

Everybody is balling until someone goes rogue and shoots you in the back with no apologies.

The best games are when you turn off your brain and shoot anyone who shoots back and/or you can read between the lines and find out what the game is trying to say. There is no right or wrong way to recommend this game, all I know is I had a good time.

I just wish Division 2 was available for purchase here on Steam.

NOTE

Some of you may not be able to launch the game due to missing Microsoft .dll files. Download and install the Microsoft "vcredist_x64.exe" package. If you already have it installed, run the repair option the software allows you to select in order to ensure the required files are installed. Next launch the game via the Steam client and it should launch "UBISOFT CONNECT" which will enable you to play the game successfully.

Hope that helps! : )

Roughly half way done the main story content of The Division, I am playing this title coop with a friend.  It is a enjoyable gameplay experience when it comes to combat and occasionally certain firefights will require coordination with teammates to counter the enemy AI.  Flanking will be useful to catch enemies off guard and get them in a crossfire however the AI can do the same to you.

Most of the "sidequests" consist of the same types of tasks repeatedly, such as defending specific points, picking up and moving items from one place to another, protecting certain people, eliminating specific targets, etc.  It gets a bit tedious after a while but you are not required to finish these assignments.

There are also many items scattered throughout the city to collect which unlock special articles of clothing for your character.  Outside of that, haven't seen any other benefit to collecting them outside of learning more about the game world a bit at a time.  Nice to learn more but tedious as well since there are over 300.

The meat of the story comes from the central missions which usually are in unique areas and advance the main plot.  Like the side missions, most of these can be done at the player's leisure.  I tend to enjoy these the most compared to the optional missions as they feel like new areas.

As of this writing, the DLC modes and the Dark Zone have not been tackled yet.  In general, I would recommend this game if you are looking for a collaborative experience with friends.  Story is so-so and the player's character is generic so this game focuses more on multiplayer, coop or otherwise.  If you have voice chat available that will make the firefights an even better experience in working together.

Note: I had a bug at the beginning which required deactivating IPv6 to connect to Ubisoft's platform.  After the first time, it has connected every time since.  I also turned IPv6 back on and it is fine.

I bought this game during the Summer Sale for $9 without any DLC, and am I weird to say I love this game?

Still to this day, The Division is still a graphically great game, I'm running the game all on High settings and the scenery is just jaw-dropping. I really wish this game had a photo-mode. I'm 5 hours into the game writing this review and for some reason I want to do all the side missions and encounters, something that I rarely do nowadays because in some games it serves no purpose. In this game, it has a purpose so you can upgrade your headquarters. Sure the enemies are bullet spongy but that's what makes this game. If everything was 1 shot kill, then it would have just become another Wildlands or Breakpoint but taking place in New York.

As someone who hates the newer Assassin Creed titles (Origins, Odyssey & Valhalla) for being an RPG title now, I would rather play this MMO-RPG title, a game that's 4 years old than those newer games. And that's very interesting to say since I love the Assassin Creed titles (everything before Syndicate).

I'll be back to update this review after I beat the game.

----

After beating the game, here's my thoughts.

(I'm playing on 'Normal' difficulty)

The Division has 18 main missions. Each district has it's own side missions and encounters that you can gather by going into safe houses along with district bosses that you can defeat. After completing all of the side missions, head back to the safe house to earn a blueprint and XP.

I did most of the side missions and encounters before I started to play the main missions, after that was done I played the main missions and I completed the game in ~ 24 hours and played the last few missions on World Tier 2. To put that into perspective, I completed all the side missions from district levels 5 - 23 and I only had 4 out of the 18 main missions completed. I went to level 25 by just completing each district. Sadly I had to stop at the 24+ districts because I didn't have the Tech wing unlocked so I can't get better weapons to defeat these enemies with Gold health bars.

You can co-op through the entire time or solo the entire time (you just have to be pretty good at the game). I personally did it solo since people in matchmaking are pretty horrible at shooting. With this game not being 1 shot kill like Wildlands, stealth can't be done... sadly so don't try it. I haven't tried out the Dark Zone, I don't think I will. Based on watching other people play it, it's very loot-based where you need to have the best gear and a team before going in. If not, you will lose the fights.

In The Division, you can play however you want, whether it's doing all the side missions first or the main missions first, it's not very linear nor it doesn't hold your hand. If you go under-geared in a higher tier district or Dark Zone, you will get destroyed.

Districts are very repetitive with very similar encounters and side missions, but I don't mind it, though some will dislike the game because of this. Each district adds new scenery which kinda makes it new'ish in a way. As I stated, I enjoyed the game to the point where I did the side missions first (to get the repetitive content out of the way).

The only issue I really have with the game is what whenever I launch the game, it launches in Windowed mode. Pretty annoying, but nothing game breaking. I get fantastic FPS on High settings and I haven't had any server issues.

A lot of people dislike The Division but it's really a great game, I loved every second of it... as you can tell by how many hours I put into it. The Division is definitely a game if FPS gamers that want an MMO-RPG game, they should have this game in their library.

I write this now because I think its my responsibility to tell others that this game is worth your every cent, just for the storytelling. Why I wrote a review after 6 years the game has been released? Because it took me 6 years to finally finish it. Don't get me wrong. This game is great and you don't want to stop playing, but I had other commitments and stuffs and I always made a new character every time I got back into this game, so that's why it took me this long. The one thing that made me think this game is worthwhile is how it tells the story. The story is simple enough but the execution is what made me drawn to it. You gather intels and clues across New York and bit by bit, you connect the pieces to finally know everything that happened inside the city. If you ask me, that's the most satisfying way to find out because it makes you think. It's your choice, agents.

I have nothing but (almost) good things to say about this game, the gameplay is fun and can be kinda repetitive but different enough that you keep coming back for more, furthermore, i like the weapons and the looting aspect. the setting is really good, it takes place in post-apocalyptic New York, where you are part of an organization to bring back peace and order. The graphics are really nice for 2016 and they don't require all that much to run it i run it on high at 60 FPS. I have a Dell optiplex 9010 with a Nvidia 1650 GPU with a 1080p moniter. The clothing you can get is really cool as well, and it is one of my favorite parts of the game. There are microstransactions, but not too serious, and it is only for cosmetics (which i think you can get just by playing the game). So the microtransactions aren't that bad, but if you want to blow $40 on them then go ahead and do that. In my personal opinion I think this game is better with friends to play it, but you don't need them to play it.

Now for the bad(ish) parts: Sometimes interiors don't load in immediately, but i don't mind. When you are walking through the entrance of the base you can only walk (which is just something i don't really like, but isn't that big of a deal). And i have heard there are a lot of cheaters but so far i haven't run into any. and  sometimes when I load in I won't be able to move (I use a controller, which might be why this happens), but i just go into my inventory and click around and then exit and it fixes that.

All in all i don't have too many problems with The Division, its a solid cover-shooter/looter-shooter that is awesome and i don't see myself stopping playing any time soon

I played Tom Clancy's The Division and The Division 2 pre-COVID-19, and playing it now... I realize that if someone were to create the Green Poison scenario, humanity would be doomed. I am going to address some of my favorite and least favorite parts of the game.

Tom Clancy's The Division is perfectly represented by the state of New York presented in game; cold, harsh, unforgiving. Don't expect go into the higher difficulties as a lone player and have a good time.

The stories that this game tells through drones, phones, laptops, and echos is without a doubt my favorite part of the game as a whole. So many stories from people doing day to day business to hearing of why SHD agents went rogue. 

How do you make a simple antagonist faction that is also interesting? The Cleaners. I LOVE these guys. To keep it simple, imagine your local garbage men suited up in hazmat suits, put a giant propane tank on their back, grabbed a couple AKs with a flamethrower strapped to them, and set out to burn the virus out of the city. Obnoxious opinion that nobody asked for: Joe Ferro did nothing wrong.

Survival is regarded as the best part of what the Division has to offer, and I agree. There are a lot of people that say it should have been what the base game should have been like, and that is where I have to disagree. While it is fun, Survival is a very challenging experience.

Underground is probably my favorite part of this game, despite mixed opinions. Having randomly generated missions set for you is really cool.

Resistance in the West Side Pier is a very cool idea. Just wish I could have someone to partner up with so I can get past the virus waves.

The one thing I hate most in this game however, are the Riker tank units. I have no idea who in the development team gave this monster the green light. Let's go over it. Explosive bullets? Check. LMG to keep you suppressed while moving towards you? Check. The reload of their LMG is completed instantly? Yep. Their one weak spot can only be destroyed once and doesn't even do that much damage? UH HUH.

I can guarantee that if you pit a Riker tank vs the final boss of the game, the Riker tank will win and kill you afterwards.

Overall, I give this game 3 Riker tanks out of 10.

[h1] Sword and Board [/h1]

[b] What I Liked [/b]

I really liked I could play with a pistol and a shield.  I played pretty much the entire game with that set up and made it pretty far.  At least, as far as I wanted.  Plus, the story was engaging since I love games that deal with end of the world type stuff.  There is a decent amount of loot, content, and the graphics are still pretty solid.

[b] What I Did Not Like [/b]

If you don't have anyone to play with, it's a bit of a slog.

[b] Why I Stopped Playing [/b]

The Division 2 came out.

[b] Disclaimer [/b]

I have been a gamer for over 30 years.  I tend to play mostly PC games.  I also bounce around between games A LOT.  I may purchase a $60 game and play it for 2 hours or spend $10 on a game and spend 50 hours on it.  Even if I played a game a short time, it does not mean it is bad.  It just means another game caught my attention.  I also complain about flaws in games a lot, even about the littlest of things.  Keep that in mind when reading my reviews.  If I do not have a complaint, then the game must be special!

Due quarentine boredom I decided to give this one a go. I bought around 2018 when it got a major rework but I never had the opportunity to play it. Some annoying problems persists, none are really game breaking but it can annoy you to the core. Most content works anyway and it deserves attention.

[h1]What impresses me the most may not be relevant to you[/h1]

The art and the story are never the main things that lures you to a multiplayer game, any game that has it should be praised as adventurous and risky for the developers, no wonder why it had a lot of trouble during its release, mainly with cheaters. The realism is impressive, the art direction is pretty. Graphics impresses me, sound FX is okay, story is pretty convincing and the story seems awfully realistic. As you're forced to walk on foot most of NY streets, you see a lot of what I'm saying. I've seen photographers taking pics from the windows, people asking for help or giving advice of where to go, body capture is decent, combat animation is satisfying... 

Sometimes you even forget this is an RPG purely based on DPS, in that regard the game is aging pretty well on that is what I'm saying, charming for its category. There is a curious synth-driven music vibing like the 80s I'm not sure if its just an impression. It is particularly realistic during or 2020 pandemic, makes you think too much about people, how easy it is for them to break down and how fragile it really is. I like the cold snow NY setting better than The Division 2 so I stick more with it than the other one.

Sadly, they never did much variations for that. You can help civilians and they'll reward you, but it's just 2 dimensional. You can't interact much and your character is voiceless like most multiplayer. A lot of other things could have been added, like trying to convince/subdue low level enemies scavenging or something. No, you're just a 2D terminator and that's kinda dull for the setting.

Missions are hard and action packed in such a dynamic way, sometimes they're so epic it even reminds me of games like ME2, even [b]Brandon Keener[/b] voice is on the game as ISAC. Missions are always aiming at the sense of urgency, sometimes surprising, it is awesome this way.


[h1]Is this another lone multiplayer?[/h1]

I haven't found people to co-op with me until I reached level 8 in around 12/15 hours of gameplay, but when I finally did it was just awesome. The combat can be pretty damn hard even if your level matches the hostiles (more on that later) and having someone to flow it with you is fairly needed. Made some friends and soon we were creating strategies that the squad (4 max) agreed in cooperating, then we were experiencing the true The Division I heard about these years. Fun is quite endless when you see the result of your strategy at the best of everyone's abilities - sadly it won't last this way.

Do not get your hopes too high because the lasting community in the chat is always slow and dumb and I think I was kinda lucky. It may take you some time for someone to respond your pleas, to find viable individuals on the same situation than you, specially low level and willing to play along. If you find high level players you're doomed to suffer, you'd be thinking that it will be good for you but the enemies level are based on the highest on your team, killing your fun-factor.

You do well to hunt some noobs on Discord groups before embarking, if not, just go alone and take your shot. It is totally doable, for I still find myself going solo from time to time. You can interact and see others in social areas, but there is no way to interact with other players when you're free roaming - unless you go to DZ. Free roam should totally be up to the open world itself, but it isnt, Dark Zones attempts to do that but at the cost of PvP conflicts "rogue agents" I don't recommended in early game. So this way we could bump into each other more often and join the fight. You have a nice organized GUI (the easiest to use I have seen) but the chat is mostly filled with fools and spammers, blocking them does little help preventing it. 

[b]Edited: cheaters[/b] Still are present in the game for 5 years straight. It has gotten better but also hopeless to get clear of those. Matchmaking balance sucks too so its harder to find fun, I wouldn't even bother trying.

[h1]The grinding and the rewards can be punishing[/h1] 

The Division levels up very quickly - your weapons and gear gets outdated fast as a result, when you think you're hitting the spot, nah, it will be over soon. So you can't avoid constant upgrading through the repetition of missions. What you can possibly avoid however, is the Dark Zone, thankfully. DZ is either filled with cheaters or low/high levels, but you can always try to team up to discourage solo bullies. The loot will be random but persistence may actually be rewarding but it is HARD as fakk. Replaying missions on hard-mode is literally Dark Souls with guns meaning you will die a kabillion times no matter how good you perform.

My way to get through that from early levels was to just do side missions and encounters - mostly alone. Eventually, even enemies level 8 were beating me up which meant I was doing something wrong. You NEED the best to keep going, abilities ready and gear always a step ahead. That's no option, it is quite mandatory. You either fall your ass or get ready for a beating. Or worse. You can take like half an hour just to kill 4 hostiles.

On early game, weapons are mostly repetitive, armor barely resembles anything new because they just change the color most of the time when you swap it. Once I could reach level 30 then things started to get interesting. Not just visually, like hardcore tactical veterans like a Tom Clancy's driven blockbuster - even the music and the expansions seems to mutate when you reach 30+ end-game. The end game "ends" abruptly. The farming is not rewarding after score 280+ and you may abandon the game there.

Character creation sucks really hard, (its better on Division 2) just so you can buy something. It isn't expensive but that's not very fair if you have paid for the game already. Some stuff can drop in the world but they're of course extremely rare so don't expect that to happen much. You can gamble, but it isn't straight with money, there is a intermediary called ''encrypted keys'' or random vanity items (no kidding, that's how its called) just to make it look less blatant. No wonder why looter shooter is failing world-wide.

[h1]The combat[/h1]

A.I. is smart no matter the approach. Sometimes intrusive, sometimes dumb, aggressive, intelligent, suicidal, you name it, they're doing it. Some random criminal can be slow and rage driven, but they don't sound nor move the same when you're fighting militia and terrorists. Sometimes they're so good at fighting, your best strategy just won't work and you need to go Rambo like they often do. This is arguably, the hardest gun firing games I have ever played, sometimes it is downright unfair and why not, even a little cheap-stupid.

Moving around looks realistic but sometimes it is just incredibly stupid. I saw countless times vanishing cover commands not showing up, nor to climb, because that particular place looked like you could cover but the system or the codes were missing there. That's incredible stupid and I just don't like the clunky controls sometimes, it gets on my damn nerves. It is beyond belief the devs never fixed it.

I really enjoy this game, the factions, the mechanics, the guns, the aesthetic of the whole thing. It's very fun and quite good. I love post-apocalyptic games but have high expectations for them. Looking back we judged this game VERY unfairly. Sure, there is a lot of Ubisoft related nonsense and there were big problems on launch - but this game got so much support in following years it is essentially in the same zone as No Man's Sky.

That game is great, amazing graphics (especially for the time it was released, if only Ubi didn't shoot themselves in the foot with E3 overhype lies it would be considered a work of art). It's gritty, very dark, very real. Even solo playing is great, you can disregard the multiplayer and enjoy this game alone including endgame (apart from things that obviously need a team, but a LOT of the endgame is soloable).

Game world feels real, sure it is a game not a city simulation but this is the BEST depiction of real life place that feels most realistic in the ENTIRE gaming history.

Gameplay is fun and there is a lot to it, it''s not shallow at all there are things to figure out, discover and experiment for hundreds of hours.

If games released today would be as good as this old game is NOW, we would be giving them 10/10 and praise how well they are made. LOOKING AT YOU ELITE: ODYSSEY you garbage joke of a release.

This game was fun until the main campaign was finished. After that, it's all about the "dead zone" aka the PvP area. This area is overrun with hackers and high-level players actively hunting down and wiping out far lower-level players for little reason other than that they can. You know, the types who can only enjoy a game if they are able to make it unenjoyable for others. You can get it on sale and play the campaign, but there's not much reason to keep it after that. I would suggest instead just finding a Let's Play and watching that for the story.

Note:

Honestly, it's hard to make out how I truly feel about The Division... It is a fun story to play through and you get plenty of exploration, however it seems to me that most of the time you are just doing the same thing. You get players on lower levels popping up a bit in a few areas and higher levels in the safe zones, but you never actually see them in places like the Dark Zone, which is really unfortunate as that is pretty much one of the most fun parts of the game. **Previously in (around about) 2019, there was plenty of experiences that you could get into when playing the game, there was a lot of people hanging around and willing to do missions and even hang out.

As for my personal rating, i'd give it a 7/10, mostly because the exploration and missions are interesting to roam through, that including the collectables.

If you like exploration and just generally going through the game it may be good for you! On the other hand, if you wish to do it for the multiplayer experience of going into the PvP areas and finding people out there, it may not be such a bright idea due to the dying community.

I did actually like the singleplayer styled experience and adventuring throughout the story though, and to be honest, that is pretty much what this game is nowadays.

Good stuff:
- Really addictive third person looter shooter set in a devastated New York city.
- Stupidly detailed world to run around and explore, the devs did an amazing job, every street, building and apartment has so much detail and physics objects you can shoot, it's crazy really. Just stop and look around the locations the fidelity of the graphics is pretty stunning, Light shafts shining through smoke and glass shattering realistically.
- Intense gun fights where you'll have to retreat and take cover behind cars while sparks and partical effects are flying everywhere with loud gun sounds which echo around the streets,
- Smooth, high quality character animations and lots of character customisation.
- Lots to do and unlock, there's always a reason to keep playing if you like the gameplay.
- Play alone or with a group, it's really cool to take part in huge PVE gun fights with other people and everyone gets the same rewards,
- The end game is where it's at. Once you reach level 30 you will start unlocking the best gear in the game which is way more powerful than the guns and armour you'll find at low levels. Guns with unique perks and armour sets wtih abilities and buffs which stack to make you pretty unstoppable.
- The dark zone is the PVP area of the game where you will find powerful loot which other players can kill you for and you can kill them but it's actually more beneficial to work together. That doesn't stop some players though, it can get pretty tense.


The not so good stuff:
- Repetitive to the extreme, all you do is run to a location and shoot stuff but i enjoy that, some people might not.
- Before level 30 you will find only garbage gear but it is sort of an MMO so that's to be expected.
- Some missions are REALLY HARD alone. Enemies can be bullet sponges whereas they will shread your health with a few hits. Don't go into a mission under levelled, not even one level under because you will have a bad time.
- I also have the game on PS4 and the expansions are kind of crap and not many people play them. I don't know what it's like on PC but i won't be buying them on PC.
- PVP IS TRASH.

Lovely graphics for the time, great animation, decent lore, and an amazing atmosphere. I began playing this actively during the CoVid-19 pandemic and I immersed myself in the game deeply.
Leveling, PvP and PvE are decently thought out, the expansions are well worth the money, especially the survival one (I love that one).
On my end, many people still play and so do I.

It's a very fun game but after a while it becomes somewhat repetitive. It is most fun playing with people you know in my opinion. I like it a bit more than the 2nd game so far, I just started playing Division 2.

TL;DR Ubisoft brought an amazing concept to the world, and once again didn't listen to it's fan-base. And so, the game fell to ruin, thanks to lack of anti-cheat and rampant hacking in PvP.

Also, the amount of hours posted does not reflect actual hours played. I owned this game through uPlay before migrating to Steam.

Now, the actual long part:

Surprisingly enough, the PvE is plenty fun and challenging enough, for a while. Typical copy/paste fetch quests, area defense, and assassination targets. The forgettable story is crappily stapled on to the endless grind to reach level 30. After that, there are plenty challenging daily missions and other repeat missions for higher quality loot, which is all fine and dandy until you decide that it's not enough.

Then you go to the Dark Zone, or DZ for short. DZ is the part where they royally messed up. The DZ has it's own currency, it's own ranking system, and it's own rules. To start off, the DZ has it's own ranking system separate from single player. The level cap is much higher, and the quality of loot increases with each level. The trick is, you have to visit the DZ every few single player levels to rank up your DZ rank so you aren't completely out-geared and out-matched by the time you hit rank 30 outside the DZ. Not fun, and not well thought out. Especially considering if you die in the DZ, you lose a few DZ levels.

Second is the currency. Forget all that money you've been earning through your single player experience. DZ only takes DZ credits in exchange for getting DZ quality gear. Only way to get DZ credits is by slaying mobs in the DZ. Should you find yourself dead in the DZ, you lose a portion of your DZ credits, far more than you'd earn in a simple run through the fastest mob routes. So profit is tough, especially if you're under-leveled. Don't let that get you down, because if you want high quality gear without the DZ, there's always the dailies and weeklies you can beat to earn yet ANOTHER type of currency to use back at the home base. But not to buy good weapons, just the blueprints. You gotta craft the weapons, and hope you get the stats and skills you want on it.

Now for the grand scheme. Take the levels, the currency, and add in PvP. PvP is possible in the DZ, but you get "punished" for doing so. Killing players or stealing loot will mark you as a rogue agent for a short duration, will put a bounty on your head, and make you visible to all other players in your vicinity. If you can live through the timer, you get the bounty, if you get killed, your killer gets the bounty. The more players you kill in a short span, the higher the bounty and the longer the timer. Pretty fun and fair for all. Except, it's not. Thanks to a near-non-existant anti-cheat system, the DZ is rife with players using hacks and exploits to simply ruin other's days. Mix that in with trying to earn DZ levels and DZ credits, and your in for a lot of profit loss.

The worst part, after all of that, is Ubisoft doesn't care. Not like it's anything new, but this really takes the cake. Ubisoft, deaf to the aguish and cries of the users, continues on it's merry little path of getting out all it's "Year One" content. Patches, bug fixes, adding in new missions, new currencies that we can't keep track of, new gear, guns, and much, much more, and yet, no anti-cheat. No help for those who thought this game was a much needed change from the pace of rinse-and-repeat First Person Shooters. I can only pray they don't let For Honor fall into the same pit of despair that they have The Division.

(P.S. Hey, Ubisoft, if you're reading this, you should add BattlEye to The Division like you did Siege. It's kinda helping.)

Alright... Sadly I can't write up a review of Tom Clancy's The Division 2 due to it not being on Steam. But yeah lets talk Tom Clancy's The Division.

The Story, back in the early 2000's the U.S. Government ran a simulation of what would happen if the U.S. underwent a biological terror attack. Operation Dark Winter as it was called pretty much showed that well... We'd be pretty screwed. Note I am not going to point at 2020's Covid-19 pandemic that's still on going as of now in 2021. But yeah what they found wasn't pretty. Now over in the Tom Clancy universe this lead the Government to start up a covert group of men and women who in the event of a major attack that could pretty much screw everyone over. In 2015 in the Tom Clancy world on Black Friday a major epidemic breaks out world wide sweeping into just about every major city in the world. Due to this the Government activates those sleeper agents who are part of the Strategic Homeland Division or just 'The Division' to assist emergency responders.

Needless to say the first wave of agents? It didn't go all that well thus you being a second wave agent show up in New York City to find out what the hell is going on.

Alright so gameplay, The Division is a third person cover based RPG looter shooter. Thus combat is for the most part getting behind something and popping out at whatever the hell wants to murder you in NYC. You have three stats in the game, Firearms that up your damage with guns. Stamina your general 'health' and the like. And finally Electronics that will let you do more damage with your skills, heal more with them, last longer, so on. Being a Division Agent you have a number of skills that you can use, everything from Pulse that will let you see enemies around you, Support Stations that can heal over time, Turrets that will attack enemies in range. A Shield that blocks anything firing at you. And note those can be upgraded so if you want the Turret acting as a Flamethrower? Yeah that's a thing.

Really you'll learn the basic gameplay stuff while you go from level 1 to 30. So lets talk the real meat of The Division the end game. When you reach the end game you'll be in 'World Tier 1' and will start to find all sorts of new items to play with from Gear Sets to Exotic Items. When you gather up items you can move yourself to World Tier 2. You have 5 World Tiers with the last being the 'end game' world tier.

You have a number of missions that you can do a repeat with a top 'Legendary' mission mode. You can farm world bosses for loot and they respawn every few hours. High Value Targets that you can pick up and hunt down. Small 'raid' like content called Incursions that have to be done in a group of four. And I should note, Division 1 doesn't have anything 'blocked' behind a content wall. You are not going to have to do an Incursion to get a Gear Set or an exotic item like an Urban MDR. Doing that content will give you more item drops and better chances to get those items. You also have West Side Pier as well, an end game area that offers up a horde mode that has you facing enemies from all of the factions. Still play it however you want, casual, solo, group, everyone can get the same stuff just the harder content gets you everything faster.

There's also the Dark Zone. This is Division's PvEvP area, the idea is it's an area of the City that was walled off and is in general lawless. The DZ has a higher chance of finding good gear, however you have to call in a Chopper to extract any gear you find. Also your fellow Agents can (and will) turn Rogue. This means they can turn around and kill you in order to take your stuff. If you don't like random PvP? Best stay out.

Division 1 also has three DLC game modes. Last Stand is a team based PvEvP mode that has two teams fighting in an area of the Dark Zone. Underground is somewhat rogue like, you'll take missions that will send you into NYC's underground areas and as you do more? You can take modifiers that can change things up somewhat. Finally there's Survival, a game mode that has you leaving all of your uber gear behind as you take a Chopper that into the DZ to find antivirals, that ends up crash landing with you being injured and slowly dying of blood poisoning. Also there's a blizzard moving into the city as well. Thus your goal is to find gear, crafting mats, warm clothing, meds, and make your way to the DZ to find those antivirals and get out before you die. Only you'll also be dealing with the enemy factions and a new group called Hunters who are hunting down Division agents and using the same tools you are using. Also if you are playing on PvP mode? Well it turns into a semi-battle royal as your fellow agents can (and will) be trying to kill you.

I could add in a lot more but well I think the question is do I recommend Division 1. And yes I do, more so when the game is on sale and you can pick it up with all of the DLC. Yeah it doesn't have the player base that it once had as most people moved onto Division 2. However the game is still rather fun, the fact that you can play solo and nothing is locked behind a content wall is a nice bonus. And a game mode like Survival is something even I'll pop in to play now and then. It's worth it just keep in mind it's not as big as it once was.
