Picked up the game again since ppl sayin its better now. After 30 hour of game play I think I'm qualified to say it is still not worth your time. 
TLTR: 
This game can keep you busy the same way as if someone spilled coffee on your shirt and now you spend rest of your day doing laundry. Everything is designed to grind and waste your time. Kind of fun with friends but there are definitely better options out there. 

CONS: 
1. Everything is level gated to hell, fighting higher leveled enemy is almost impossible as they kill you in 0.5 seconds, forcing you to grind over and over in the same area before you can move on. 
2. Missions are boring and repetitive, go here -> fight wave -> collect data/rescue person -> fight a boss that takes about 1000 bullets. Even the "Story" missions are not much beyond this. 
3. Boss/mini boss are nothing but aimbot bullet sponges, they all have the same pattern: shoot -> grenade -> shoot -> reload, making it a marry go round wack a mole, and you are the mole. 
4. AI is brain dead, especially friendly AI, they don't trigger when enemies are 30 metters away, they can't hit anything and do about 0 damage. Enemy AI can hit you with a shotgun across the map through a window. 
5. Map is quite empty, no cool npc you can meet, no dialogue, nothing. No dynamic. All apartments are empty, Civilian have the same behavior. No memorable location or people, waste of NewYork City. All story delivered through generic audiolog that sounds like they used a story generator. 
6. Guns feel the same, no big difference between an AR or AK or even a mp5. 
7. The cosmetic selection is a joke, you get flooded with junk that looks the same, not even the stuff you pay for is interesting. 
8. crafting is grindy, so I need 10 green parts to make a blue part and 10 blue part to make a purple part and 20 purple part to make a gun that doesn't suck? No thanks. I have played 30 hours and only have 1/8 credits to level up one pistol, go figure. 
9. Dark zone enemies are all tanky as the mini bosses, best part, they spawn behind you and two shots you since you dont have cover. making solo impossible. 
10. Other less boring gamemode locked behind DLC and level 30 requirement, which takes you probably 40 hours to reach, no thanks.

Clearly a smarter story setup than people originally thought.  Solid gameplay.  Solid voice acting.  All the loadout mods take some getting used to, but the time to understand it all is well worth it.  Some global events still happen in here, too!  First use of the Snowdrop engine. The Division is a fairly standard looter-shooter set in a non-standard world. When you arrive in New York, things are really bleak, but as you complete missions you see your impact on the city and the people in it.

If you don't enjoy the looter-shooter gameplay loop, you probably won't enjoy The Division, but the shooting is really solid, even if the higher-difficulty enemies tend to get a bit bullet-spongy.

The gadgets spice up combat and make it possible to play a "class" of sorts. You can heal, you can tank, you can go full damage, or find some middle ground between them.

[h1] [i] Semi-MMO Third-person looter shooter with interesting setting [/i] [/h1]

The Division is an open-world looter-shooter set in the world written by Tom Clancy. When I first gave it a try, it seemed like Ubisoft had managed to pump out yet another generic and forgettable game that will quickly fade out. I was pleasantly surprised that I was wrong and as I got deeper into the game's mechanics, I was hooked. The Division certainly isn't a masterpiece or even one of the greatest games ever made and the story is quite disappointing, however, it does what it set out to do pretty well and although it does get repetitive over time, its still worth a try.

[b] [i] Positives [/i] [/b]

+ Graphics and effects
+ Level design
+ Good loot with nice variety
+ Setting inspired by Tom Clancy
+ Length
+ Satisfying endgame
+ Additional content
+ Shooting - the feeling, the feedback and ragdolling of enemies is great
+ Weapon variety 
+ Social features are unobtrusive if you are a solo player, yet do provide nice change of playstyle
+ Collectibles

[b] [i] Negatives [/i] [/b]

- Gets quite repetitive over time
- The story is generic and forgettable
- Bland characters
Very nice looking game but with very shallow gameplay.
Terrible game after the first week of playing. Loaded with hackers shooting through the ground while sitting in the back corner on top of a building.

I must say the game can be fun and you can enjoy the game as far as it brings you, the grind for the gear you want is way to long, but you feel rewared for all you hard work when you get it or complete a mission on higher difficulty.
With the last even with polarization, which ruined the game for alot of people this does pull down the effort you think the developers put into their game. If you have some friends, sure play with them. This game is ok with friends but if you plant to play it solo then spend you money somewhere else.

This game's difficulty base is the worst type you can have. Gun play itself is fine, but enemies as early as 3 hours into this game who's story is rated at 23 hours long are spongey and take like 2 and a half mags for one guy, on a weapon that's rated at 1500 damage. Every mission has like 3 waves of 12 enemies of that difficulty, and those are the basic enemies. Then there's the purple enemies and the yellow enemies. My 2 buddies and I are at least aight gamers and the mission in the mall took us 5 tries. 
     Gameplay itself seems padded by constant run ins with random enemies, the large waves of spongey-ass hostiles and if you have a mission where you have to transport components your movement is slowed to about an eighth of your normal walking speed. That on top of the fact that the movement in this game isnt very great to begin with and you're in a world of "fun."
     You can take cover in this game, which you'll need to do a lot cause enemies with weapons that are rated as weaker than yours take your health down by half in one shot. You go to use that weapon? Frozen peas. When you go to cover, sometimes your character runs out in the open and "hides" behind a pillar while STARING at the enemies. it's inconsistent, sluggish and just straight bad.
     Also, the menus in this game are atrocious. They're complicated, difficult to traverse but hey, they look futuristic right?! This game seems to have taken everything people who play games hate about action games and put it into one: bad UI, sluggish, inconsistent movement, spongey enemies that take forever to kill and a forced-feeling difficulty, and the almost necessity to have friends to do anything, even then it being overly hard. Basically, this game is only difficult because it takes a long timed to do anything.
     There are several good things though, the graphics, sound, and characters are all decent. The story... exists but is kinda confusing early game. Characters are fleshed out well and I definitely enjoyed some of the interactions. Gunplay itself is actually ok, minus the fact that in order to use a scope you need a higher magnification, as 1x scopes are also OTS or Over The Shoulder and there is no option for first person. However the looting is tiring and kind of confusing in itself, and the overall experience between me and my buddies was "wow what a well designed game, I'm having a lot of fun" that obviously being sarcasm.

DON'T BUY!

Sigh, imma be real with everyone here, i've played the division on the following: Xbox 1, ps4 and now pc. After all the hours i've put in, I do... NOT recommend the game, i'll put it like this.
Pro:
The story is nice, a setting where you are like the last hope for the country to keep ahold of its self somewhat after a virus outbreak. The look of the city is damn nice, the characters are enjoyable. Everything storywise is nice. But this ain't a visual novel, its a shooter rpg. Therefore next...
The idea of a 3rd person shooter rpg with this concept is nice, the skills can be useful(clearly, looking at you riot shield)
The co-op is alright, the pvp skirmish is cool, the idea of the Dark Zone as well.

By now you may notice a theme here, ideas, the concept. The division has a great concept... Now its time for the execution... where it all falls apart.
Con:
The execution. Whenever its trying to get to cover, dealing with Ai/players, damage output, loot and more, you'll find that the division may leave you lacking the tools to survive in certain situations. Of course you got your skills, but how does using a 1st aid on overdose to what i call extra health and running at least 1 second to cover and losing your extra health and almost half/half of your health.  A medkit will heal you fully, if you don't get hit. What happens when you have no med kits and skills on recharge? You use your wits and brain, but this game will do whatever it takes to make you suffer for some reason, it's breaks it own rules just cause, you will often have things come out wrong, whether it's trying to roll but instead go to cover, trying to insta a skill with a double tap but only a single tap is registered.  When you fully reload, but need to roll to save your skin it takes that reload away even though the magazine is shown full. 
The health is a joke, the AI is a pain, an elite can wail on you faster than a group of vets no joke.
And PVP is an unbalanced mess, especially in the endgame, you can get wreck very easily while your opponent barely feels it. And then there's the looting, it comes to a point where it feels like you do too much and get little to nothing to show for it. You may grind for hours/days/WEEKS/ god forbid month/s to get the gear you're looking for. One would say go to the DZ, oh yeah let me go in there with all those annoying rogues with hacks, in groups too. Which brings me to this point.

Remember the coop? Yeah playing this game, it seems like that would be the idea for the best way to play it. Don't get me wrong things can be fun in a group, but not everyone wants to play together some want to play by themselves. And this poses a problem for incursions, Legendary missions... Cause those are surrounded on team play and that brings a problem for those who can't find people to play with or can't play with anyone(this is for console players due to requiring online subscription). 

So imma sum this up for everyone here, I don't recommend the division because the execution is not good, the AI is a pain, the PVP is unbalanced, the looting is grind that can be so tiring, the feel for a need of coop instead of playing solo takes away from the experience. The division has a good concept but how they went about it is just not good. Everyone has their own experiences and may have different opinions.

I do plan to update this later. So it may change.

Months have passed since I didn't feel so happy to play a game for a lot of hours in a row. 
I wanted this game so hard since the release date but unluckily the price was too high for my poor wallet.
Now that I've got it I can say that these 10€ I spent to buy The Division are one of the best money I've ever spent.
[b]The Division is an RPG Third Person Shooter, with looting and covering systems, where you are an agent of the "Division" who has been sent to New York after an Outbreak exploded during the Black Friday to help people and to free NYC from bandits, scavengers, killers of various genres. [/b]
There is a "long" story to play alone, with friends or with strangers (I suggest you to start alone but then to play with someone else because missions get gradually harder), and an online mode called "Dark Zone" which is PvE, but even and far more PvP, where you have to find a better equipment and then extract it to proceed in the story or other DLCs. Other players can try to kill you to steal your equipment. The Story Mode and Dark Zone are included in the base game. 
The Season Pass includes:
[b][h1]--> The Survival DLC[/h1]A particular Battle Royale gamemode where you start with nothing and a 1hour countdown which means you have to survive otherwise you'll die, finding a better equipment, proceeding to the Dark Zone and then extracting it (even if you find a good equipment and then you die, you'll be able to transfer it to the story mode.)
[h1]--> The Underground DLC[/h1]Where you can explore NYC's underground to loot better equipments, and join Raids.
[h1]--> The Last Stand DLC[/h1]Which is a new Dark Zone gamemode where you have to conquer and to defend objectives (max 16players) to get a better equipment.[/b]

[b]The game has got quite many gamemodes to be defined "long-lived", it can bring you hours of fun especially with random dudes or friends. I think it's worth a try.[/b]

[b]SUMMARY[/b]

STORY: 8/10
GAMEPLAY: 9,25/10
GRAPHICS: 10/10 - One of the best I've ever seen, even if it had a massive downgrade from E3 2013 trailer.
OPTIMIZATION: 8,5/10
AI: 8,5/10 - Not bad, enemies are sometimes hard to beat even at Normal difficulty.
LONGEVITY: 8,5/10
GAMEMODES: 8/10 - There are only 2 main gamemodes with the base game..and some other modes unlocked after the end-game. Even if Dark Zone, Legendary Missions and Raids can all be long or short depending on if the player likes them or not, i think the full experience of this game can be "tasted" only with the Gold Edition. That's why i give it an 8 and not a 9.

[b][u][h1]FINAL SCORE: 8,75/10 [/h1] [/u] [/b]

This is a very fun game - however it has a few years on it now - so I would recommend getting this on sale with 3 other people, and barreling through the campaign.

The physics and hitpoints are great, the atmosphere works very well, and you will have at least 40-60 hours of fun here.

The only downside are the hackers - thankfully there are less of them now, but in the Dark Zone - they always happen. Which is unfortunate because you have a higher drop rate for some of the more rare items and materials. That is not really the fault of the developers - more a fault of the publisher to not implement anti-cheat tools. (I mean c'mon, just pay for that, Ubisoft...)

On the whole: A great PvE experience - especially with friends.
(Tip - once you hit the 'Embassy' mission late-game - aim for their knees - the armour hitboxes are that detailed in this.)

Played this game for dozens of hours on the console, it only does two things well but those two things are enough to make the game worth playing.


The first thing the game does well is the environmental design. The world map is just utterly gorgeous and has so much detail to it, it feels like a real world and gives the game a very unique sensation to the general atmosphere of playing. The four elements of the environment; winter, the holidays, urban streets and post crisis city mix great together and create a distinct tone to the world.

The other thing the game does very well is the cover shooting gameplay itself. The way the shooting feels, the way the cover mechanics function are all extremely well honed. It handles great and it plays great, in general being very satisfying and it feels complete.


The general structure of the game is a pretty typical waster, lots of pointless fetch quests, collectables and there really are no actual dynamic missions or gameplay it is all just fight your way through the instance until you win. The skill and class system is bare bones and feels totally unfinished, while the game has little actual mechanics or features to the combat beyond the actual shooting itself. There is no real melee system, no dynamic system for the player interacting with the environments, or anything else at all.

The movement is not really tight enough for the player to be able to properly weave through the environment in an emergency, which the game will put the player in, so the player just has to fumble around and hope they do not die if that happens. The dodge button and cover button are the same, yet they are polar functions, so that also makes it difficult to function in critical situations. Your singleplayer world will lag if you do not have a good connection to the servers. In the later areas enemy groups are put so close together in the world that often they will trigger each other even if the player is doing a mission. So the player will get swarmed and camped by enemies they have no idea were nearby because they got pulled in by the mobs being put too close together. Which just means, trial and error learning the enemy locations in order to compensate for them swarming.


From start to finish, all this game is about is just shooting at enemies. Which would normally be awful, if the shooting was not as good as it is here. Even though this honestly is a shell of what a real game should be, the great shooting combined with the fantastic environments actually makes it worth playing in the end.

But not for full price, at all, the on sale price is generally what this game is worth. And even then, it is only worth that price from the combined value of the triple A graphics and the shooter gameplay. 

As a concept this game is still a triple A game, which means it is designed to waste the players time as much as possible and bait them into spending cash on micro transactions and gambling boxes. But unlike other triple A games at least it does some things right, but only two things right.

All you need to know is:

The game is a 8.5/10 until you play the Dark Zone; Where you battle real players and it falls to a 6.5/10.

I am beginning to hate this game due to the rouge players, and that's where the problem sets.

This game has hackers, and losers who take advantage of the rouge position.

So, picture yourself in a typical FPS or TPS game, and you are grouped up with four other friends.  
You guys are running around, dodging bullets, and holding cover, just to grab a bit of fancy loot.
After acquiring the loot, you head for the chopper to make your escape.
Ahead of you, a guy with an equal or less level starts shooting at you.
So, all five of you shoot back.
Yet, somehow, all five of you get deleted and the enemy runs off with 50% health.
All your loot is taken by the rouge player, and your left smashing your keyboard.
After this, and for the next hour, the same thing keeps happening to you, your friends, and other players. 

Eventually, you will hit the world 5 Dark Zone (There are 5 levels of the world: Newbies, Specials, Core, Grinders, and finally Tryhards). At the final tier, all players are thrown into the same map. This means, you could be lvl. 40 and get stomped by a lvl. 94 every day. Which is exactly what happens.

What an interesting game. This is like a traditionally Tom Clancy game mixed with Borderlands. I’m usually more of a Borderlands fan than Tom Clancy, but I like this game more than I usually like either or.

Full stop- the graphics and attention to detail is actually stunning. Like, I wouldn’t expect it from Ubisoft, but it actually doesn’t feel like the world is mostly copy pasted and boring. It’s much more dynamic, with marvelous graphics to supplement. I think the Snowflake engine was actually a big boon here. 

The gameplay itself is fun. It’s mostly tactical/cover 3rd person gun combat mixed with using specialized skills. It can really range in difficulty though, from having an easy single player time, to highly coordinated multiplayer encounters. 

This game really has a lot to offer, the looting pace is really fun, and character armor/weapon/cosmetic customization is enjoyable. 

I recommend this, and I recommend it in addition to its sequel being out. Both are great games.

So I was super late on picking up the Division 1 but I did so right before the release of the Division 2 and after putting close to 500 hours in that, I'd say that gives me a pretty good stand on comparing the two games. Ultimately, I'm going to lean more towards the first game as it plays somewhat superior to the second game, not mechanically so much, but in a way that makes the gameplay loop satisfying and replayable. 

While the missions aren't as cinematic, long, or as diverse as the Division 2's, they're still pretty good and I like them for what they're worth. They're very grounded and not over the top with action packed sets or ludicrous stories. I'm not going to say they're better in pretty much any aspect but I did enjoy them enough. They're all pretty replayable which is nice because in Div2, you either loved a mission or you hated it. For example, I HATED the presidential bunker mission because it dragged on forever and was pretty boring but I loved the American History Museum because it was fun. In Div1, the missions were mostly average but likeable. 

So the Dark Zone in this game is far superior to the ones in the second game. For whatever reason, Massive opted for 3 separate and compressed Dark Zones for what I can only imagine was to force more PvP encounters. This absolutely sucked because you could fast travel to different checkpoints to quickly catch up and not to mention that they have 3 evac area (started with 2) which meant you were almost always being stalked which made getting farmed items a bitch. At least in this one, you could take routes to purposely avoid conflict and sneak your stuff away mostly unbothered. Don't know why they decided to make the Dark Zone in Div2 a mostly PvP affair. It's also what basically killed balance in the second game as in Div1, your build was as strong as you made it. In the Div2, they balanced the PvP so much that it ultimately destroyed the game as exotics were getting nerfed and sets made useless so your builds were gambles as to whether or not they'd be nerfed. I had a super seeker build for PvE that got utterly destroyed and made all my effort for that build worthless. Also, I liked the feel of the massive Dark Zone in Div1 a whole lot more, it felt like this abandoned hell that was just overtaken, the ones in Div2 felt the same way but they just lacked that same feeling.

So the gameplay mechanics are where Div1 shows both an advantage and disadvantage. In the Div2, the gunplay are overall controls were much better, there's absolutely no disputing that. But after all the patches the Div1 got, the devs found the sweet spot, they simplified everything which ultimately made the game much less of a hassle. In the Div2, everything just became so muddled and messy. Div1 gave you your power fantasy and let you feel powerful when you equipped yourself properly while Div2 felt like an eternity of min/maxing which never paid off. In short terms, while they improved the game mechanically, they made everything else so damn messy that it just took away from the fun. While 1-30 in Div1 was awful while the endgame was amazing, it was the exact opposite in Div2.

Now Post Launch support is where these games have a huge difference, we are now at the 2 year mark of Division 2's release and well, the post launch support it has received at this point is abysmal. Summed up by broken and buggy releases, greedy seasons, and an overall lack of community interaction on Massive's part. Div1 delivered a phenomenal turn around with some of the best DLC, specifically Underground, bringing Div1 to the great state it is currently in while Div2 sits in a puddle of disappointment of constant community dissatisfaction from broken promises and undelivered content. They undersold the Div1 and added on with great content later on while the Div2 entirely oversold itself post launch roadmap.

Nitpicks: These are some of my nitpicks on what makes the Div1 a much better game
- Cosmetics are much better looking in this game
- Factions are more grounded in their setting and less kooky than their Div2 counterparts, they belong to their world
- New York has a much better atmosphere than D.C, something about the dark and desolate streets of NY as well as the world feeling more alive
- The builds are simplified so it doesnt feel like you have sit down and calculate your new potential builds
- Base of Operations was SO much better than the white house (screw that alarm) and 2 communities, like with DZ, it just felt like they disjointed your entire BoO and split it into 3 areas while giving much less charm.
- More memorable characters than the Div2, god, this game had much better characters, the ones in the Div2 were just not great
- Facial animations, just look at the difference in the games. They're not perfect here but theyre still better
- The graphics hold up REALLY well for it's age
- More interiors in NY so exploring feels a little more satisfying as every open window and door attracts attention
- Story was pulled off better. While neither game had a great story, Div1 pulled it off better, kept it simple and forward moving while Div2 threw way too much exposition your way.
- Sound design was better, the ambience of walking down the streets down to the gun sounds themselves, for some reason, they made gun sounds in Div2 sound like pop guns.
- More replayable content.
- Much better endgame loop.
- Mostly bug free
- Not riddled with these new "seasons" which were basically designed to make people spend money, in other words, no half-assed battlepasses and no half-assed events with recycled rewards with ridiculous grinds
- Grinding feels much less tedious

Overall, even if the Div2 is a slightly more mechanically better game, the Division 1 has come back to the top simply because the devs mishandled the living hell out of Div2. Hell, Div1 still has a pretty active playerbase so you wont have much issue finding games. They did right by Div1 up until 1.8, the game is in a great state, however, it's like they brought Div1 back from the grave and then gave us the Div2 then slowly pushed that into an early grave.

This is a fun game. I play mostly solo, so this only covers that perspective. I happened into a group a couple times, although not enough to weigh in on PvP or group play.

As usual, Ubi games are rock solid on stability. I've not had a single crash. I own a lot of Ubi games, so I'm used to their launcher and need for an account. Integration with Steam works well enough, so I don't see a reason to ding them for that. Graphics look great as they do for all the Far Cry games. It's kind of funny considering this game came out so many years ago and now Cyberpunk can't even figure itself out years later. I'm running a 1080ti, had settings maxed and didn't experience any frame drops or artifacts. Very pleased with the visuals and smooth game play.

As with all games that have preset actions for characters, such as taking cover, it was a little aggravating at times getting the game to respond to what I wanted it to do. When you take cover, getting up out of cover doesn't always work the way you want, so you might end up doing a roll or some other action. I had a couple deaths due to this, although it wasn't bad enough that I didn't enjoy myself. When you are in the heat of a battle, taking all your little digits off the keyboard and pressing what you are supposed to does work most of the time.

I'm an explorer in these games, so it took me around 50 hours to reach max level. I could have reached max level much quicker. Instead I spent time exploring the city, picking up the phones and random stuff along the way and standing around in the base studying how gear worked. The route to level 30 was going really smooth until around level 20. I noticed a steed change in the difficulty and my outdated gear became a big issue for a while until I got caught up. I had to pace myself a bit until I hit 30 because guys on level could beat the spit out of me quite easily if I wasn't paying attention.

Once at max level (30), the game changed a fair amount and what I thought would likely be the end of the game for me since I'm running solo, turned out to be just as eventful for the most part. While there's a lot of group activity focused missions, there was still a good amount I could do just running around. I'm still running around enjoying my new found over powered weapons. You can change the world difficulty, although after taking the beating from 20 to 30, it feels really good to exact some punishment at world level 0.

I found the game for around $12 with DLC, so I saved a good deal and I'm glad I waited to enjoy this. Well worth the money.

TLDR; buy it for Survival and the Ninjabike backpack (which allows for hybrid builds at endgame)

Gameplay: The original Division gives you a broad variety of options to customize your characters' skills and abilities, and there is a variety of end game content in which to apply those abilities. This is a vastly superior game to the sequel. I have spent a couple hundred hours playing PvE Survival mode, a 1-to-2 run around a 'snowified' version of the map, trying to loot and gear up before the virus timer or NPCs can defeat me. I've never played a game mode within any other game that I've enjoyed more than Division Survival. That is not hyperbole. I recommend that anyone who enjoys shooter games should pick up the gold edition on a flash sale to experience Survival mode.

Graphics, etc: I played hundreds of hours on PS4, and now have discovered that it's an even better game on PC. I just build my PC at a really bad time for GPU prices, so I had to settle for a 5500xt 4GB OC when friends paid significantly less for a 5600/5700 a year or 2 ago, but I'm happy to report that I have yet to experience a lag spike in Division. Lag was the most enduring issue with this game on console. I don't want this to be viewed as a post about which method of gaming is best, because there is plenty to like about console gaming, but Division is running on PC running better than Division 2 runs on PS4. It looks better, it plays smoother, I have no zero complaints so far. If you enjoyed this game on console and like me, now have the opportunity to try it on PC, 10000% you should. It's worth buying it again.

Division 2 is a very polished game, but it lacks the development arc/growing pains that built the original into what it eventually became. Division 1 was very broken at release, especially on PC where players were falling through the map, experiencing flashing lights, etc. The combat went through periods of feeling balanced, then very unbalanced, then eventually landed in a place where it feels good to play with a strong build and chew through enemies quickly, but if you use a bad build, they can do the same to you at higher difficulty levels. The introduction of gear sets and exotics (and eventually improved 'classified' gear sets and the optimization station) gave us the endgame that was originally lacking.

I don't enjoy this game's PvP because players can be very tanky with long time-to-kill, worsened by the spamming of healing and status effect abilities, but this doesn't impact my overall assessment of the game, because I have other games I can turn to for PvP. That said, other players will swear by the Division 1 Dark Zone being one of their best PvP gaming experiences. The DZ did provide a lot of unique moments for me, despite the fact that I was only there to farm vs. NPCs, not fight other players. The objective of extracting your loot and not knowing if your extraction will be disrupted by other players creates an uneasy tension that leads to excitement/relief when you're able to succeed in extracting a special piece of gear.

The only other game that I rank alongside this is Fortnite. I'm sure that some of my love for Division 1 is sentimental at this point; I have so much history with it, and I have grown a lot as a person in the last 5 years, and it was by side for me all of it. I can't guarantee that you'll love it as much as I do, but I promise you it's worth a try if you can get the gold edition for $13.

For the first few hours, The Division creates quite the impression. The abandoned city of New York that features in The Division is spectacular, a technical marvel that is insanely detailed, with some of the best lighting and weather effects in gaming. The clarity of detail can make for almost photoreal scenes. Combined with a good sound design, it makes for an immersive world. The meat and bones of this open world revolves around a solid, but unspectacular cover based shooting and loot collecting loop. Shoot baddies, collect more powerful guns and gear for your agent so you can shoot more enemies using better guns. At first, upgrading your character with ever more powerful weapons is fun and addictive, but a few hours in and you realise nothing really evolves. Enemies stay the same, all the weapons feel the same, the core combat feels the same from hour to hour, resulting in a game which just feels repetitive and bland. Even the dark zone seems boring if you keep playing in it - the only fun thing to do there was to become a rouge agent, and you barely make it out alive, or worse, dead, if you choose that route. It's a shame in my opinion, although those first few hours do feel quite special, leaving the rest boring and a grind to finish hence why I quit after a few hours without finishing it. I just Googled the ending of the game to save myself the trouble of having to grind until the end, and guess what? 
**SPOILER ALERT**: 

~~the final boss is a HELICOPTER. Come on Ubi, I expected better. I had a good 16 hours though to be fair, so thanks for that.~~

Edit 9 Feb. 2021:

Here's your TLDR: DO NOT BUY THIS GAME because you cannot play it consistently for even an HOUR most times without it crashing on you.

And the kicker? Ubisoft is probably saying "no, nothing's wrong with the Division, that's just a bunch of griping gamers" because THEIR OWN TOOL won't send the crash reports to them!

And it's probably nothing wrong with your rig, even one that's old as mine! DX Dialogue is open. It's saying "no problems detected". Hellfire, I play DOA6 on this rig and that game WORKS FINE. Before I abandoned it a month or two ago, I was playing Genshin Impact on this rig with my net connex WITH NARY A HICCUP.

So it's not my rig or even my crappy Philippine connection that's at fault, Ubisoft: it's your bloody infrastructure that's still crap in 2021.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. EVEN ON SALE.

In fact, I should have listened to the people who warned me about Uplay and not plunked money into this game. I thought, "can't be that bad, right? It's an old game. How horrid could Uplay be? I mean, it's not EA."

I'm just playing it because I have to make the PhP I put into this thing and the 40 gig it ate from my bandwith somehow worth it. Even then, given the aggravation I get from the crashes - sometimes with you just STANDING THERE IN A SAFE HOUSE DOING NOTHING - makes me think it maybe isn't worth it. 

Maybe I'll just DL Insurgency. Or reinstall ME2. Or just get my adrenaline fix from Hades.

-------------------- Previous Review Begins here -------------------

This is going to be the first negative review (I think) I am going to make of a game. 

Normally, I don't bother - I mean, if I didn't research a game enough before buying it, why go public and condemn it, right? Age of Information. That stuff should be on me - but I felt I have to do this to warn other people about the problems with this game.

Or maybe any other game from Ubisoft that requires both an Internet connection and UPlay.

And you don't have a fast Net connection and specs that can run, say, CP2077.

The Division is actually a good game. In the currently 9 or so hours I have been ABLE to play the game, the experience has been nothing but stellar. Even at the low settings I play it on (because my rig is old) WHEN I CAN PLAY THE GAME she is still quite an experience.

I have played a good deal of FPSes - Resistance: Fall of Man; Crysis 2; all of the Fallout FPS RPGs; Borderlands 1; the first Metro; the ME trilogy - and only one or two of them can compare to the kind of game experience in even a game as old (in 2021) as The Division.

This is a VERY VERY GOOD GAME.

That requires crappy digital infrastructure from the developer/publisher to play.

Seriously, I have spent more time trying to connect to effing Uplay, consistently getting those MIKE and ROMEO errors when I can easily stream even hi-res videos on my connection.

And when you DO connect, you get dumped by the game for one reason or another. Twice, there was an actual error that prompted the reporting tool but it refused to send because I guess Uplay is being a hard-to-get little bugger.

It's 2021, for God's sake. You'd think they'd fixed the bloody thing  by now.

And if a game is not an MMO, then maybe make it so the bloody thing can run even without a Net connex?

This game is great. Excellent even.

But unless you have an amazing Net connection and great gear, don't buy this. Then again, I checked several forums and people with far, far better gear than I were also reporting problems. Dear Ubisoft,

Stop reminding me that I don't have 3 friends that want to play a game with me at all times. Sometimes I want to be able to play a game alone without the bullet sponging AI destroying me every time I walk into a room. PS, your end game meta sucks. Learn how to make a good looter shooter. Making an enemy able to walk up to you while taking 200 bullets to the head is not making something more challenging, it is just annoying. I don't even want to bother with The Division 2 because you probably won't change anything. Way to make another bad game Ubisoft.
In 2016 it's a game, in 2021 it's possible a reality. 10/10 Leah Betts is the best game developer to exist.

There's nothing strategic about fighting a bullet sponge that is the same level as you, but you're the weakling who can be downed in an instant. Sure you can plan ahead even after a bullshit death, and try to maybe flank, but getting better angles don't do anything. If you can shoot it, it can shoot you and you will die every time. A bullet sponge isn't a fun obstacle. It is tiring, monotonous, and it just feels like lazy game implementation to pad out fights for no reason. Especially if it comes in the form of five dudes and you're only one person, which then the game just says "good fuckin luck bucko." Then you die, respawn, and do it again. Loading a full magazine into someones face will never be fun in my eyes, since the damage intake is so imbalanced for the player, and the fact the enemies just get every single damn angle on you it is infuriating. 
  If anything, I actually think the RPG elements made this game far worse. You have to kill everyone one at a time with one full clip at a time, while they can kill you with ease and not reload at all. So you get somewhat realistic properties applied to you in terms of damage intake, while enemies get funny RPG fantasy damage intake. So the game is stuck some of the worst game structure of wanting to be realistic, but not being realistic when a level number is just tacked onto an enemy. The game doesn't know what it wants to do, and it will be unfair everytime. This comes from a solo perspective, which is a terrible way to play this game. But thankfully none of my friends own this crap.
  I tried. I tried to enjoy its combat and atmosphere, because lets face it. The story is crap. So I tried to let everything else work, and I can't enjoy the stupid combat system. So fuck, what do I do? I don't enjoy it for the rest of my life and write this review out of frustration for trying. 
  There you go. A real stinker of a game. 3/10 stuff like that. Probably better with friends, but I don't count on it. Also this game has loot boxes and premium currency, there's like four different currency types, and I don't support it. Fuck ubisoft.

I bought The Division because a friend and I have been playing, The Division 2, and I really wanted to see how the story line started, in addition to checking out how the game changed one to another.  I am really enjoying the post apocalypse setting that's not filled with zombies.  The creators did a good job of creating a world where a virus has killed a bunch of people and brought the U.S. to its knees (even if it's hitting a little close to home right now; yes, I'm talking to you COVID).  This game explores the worst case scenarios where the government has fallen, large numbers of people are dead, survivors are trying to stay alive, and bad guys are trying to take over.  While it's not impossible to play this game single player, you can tell it was designed to be played with friends.  I found some of the missions to be really challenging starting out because you don't have much in the way of weapons, armor, etc.  The bad guys hit hard.  Sometimes it didn't take more than a couple hits to take my character down.  Don't expect to implement much strategy.  This game is designed for you to get behind something and shoot it out with waves of bad guys.  You are going to pick up a lot of weapons along the way.  It didn't seem too difficult to decide which weapons are the best.  I haven't done much in the way of modding or crafting yet.  On a personal note, I actually found the exact hand gun that I own in real life in this game so I can certify that the weapons really do look like the ones in the real world.  While the map is open world, you will be restricted to areas based on your level.  I think that most people who enjoy realistic environments and simple shooter game will enjoy this one.

The Division, 563.1 hours on this game...I originally had my fill but after a rethink I can't knock the game, it got me through job searching and unemployment back in the day and made winter time strangely immersive, a Christmas game if there ever was one. I've said in a number chat pages and community hubs that New York State was 'massively' under used and The Division 2 shouldn't exist and I still stand by that, for what the game gives main, roaming and endgame options, builds, player community and game time anything from a quick half an hour, to an all day mess about whilst there's film on/ Youtube vids/audio book/your own tunes in the background it's well worth the hours I've put in.

This game is playable at best. The open world aspect is too good for its own good. The open world enemies (who roams around keeping the open world play interesting) is too rampant. As result, they often interfere with the open world missions (encounters). As result, I'm fighting way more enemies than the game intended (as I am fighting both enemies from the mission and also the open world ones), and am more likely to be killed by the open world enemies rather by the encounter enemies during these missions. Moreover, the designers only intended for coop play, the enemies are often too overwhelming for single player. They need to realize that this game will die down after initial release and not too many people will play it, hence not many people available for coop, hence difficulties need to be tweaked. Especially side missions and encounters are meant to complement the main mission, not the other way around. I have to spend way too much effort on  side missions than main missions. Moreover, respawn points are too far from some of the encounters. I often spend more time running to the mission rather than doing the mission. JTF team mates act like completely untrained cowboys, they either converge around me while I'm shooting and obstruct my field of view, or do nothing and let us get flanked; they are useless! This game has so many things that needs to be improved and polished, yet it seems to me Massive is more concerned with getting the appropriate male female ration for various voice roles than with optimizing and polishing the game. Hey Massive, Since pressing space to enter cover, ever thought about pressing space again to get out of cover? Nope, cause you were more concerned with having a certain ratio of female JTF voices and certain ratio of les characters rather than focusing on improving the game.

I think "The Division" is a very good open world shooter that could almost relate to the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020. It has an awesome range of guns to use and many enjoyable missions to play. Some downsides to the game for me include the player movement. I play using keyboard and at first the movement can be annoying, but over time its gotten easier to use, like all skills after practicing. It can be a slow paced game at times, but that helps cope with the tremendous amount of tension when fighting tough enemies. All in all it's a good game.

Quite a lot to do in this game, and endgame content specifically is pretty varied. The stuff leading up to endgame might feel a little bit tedious but there's enough of the main story content to keep it from being boring. 

The only real problems I have at 84 hours of playtime is that one of the activities is pretty much impossible to do because it is pvp matchmaking and nobody else is doing it so I've never been able to get into a match. This is made more annoying by the fact that there's a quest marker to do said activity, and it will not go away until you've actually gone into a match which you will likely not be able to do. Also global events haven't really been a thing for a while which is unfortunate and I have no idea if or when they would come back.

Other than that though, I very much enjoy the game. Gameplay is engaging with all the different gadgets and abilities and character builds through gear, and although the story isn't particularly compelling I found that it didn't detract from my experience very much since I didn't really go in expecting much there. The setting is also very nice with New York stuck in a state of ruin during Christmas time, which is oddly beautiful. To put it into numbers, I think I would give it an 8/10.

played this on console and pc, abused the underground "glitch" to get high-end gear on a low level character. ran around the Dark Zone, did the missions. over all, i liked the gameplay. now, i wouldn't advise doing pvp events solo, but you can. they game is still fun to play! even more entertaining with friends! if you happen to be running around on solo the game does rapidly lose its entertainment. i am speaking from MY experience though, i cannot speak for anyone else. i still log in from time to time and hunt players in the darkzone. i still buy the game for friends to play before they get the Div2. mainly so i do not have to play 20Questions on who is who and why they do what they do. the building of gear sets has a bit of a learning curve. but it isnt terrible! with the age of the game there are PLENTY of guides and "how to" for anything and everything in this game. i guess my only major complaint is only having a handful of character slots. other than that it is all hunky dory.

So if any reviews are older than about September 2016, feel free to ignore them. At launch the overall scaling and endgame loot and balance were very bad. After the launch of Underground but before the launch of Survival, they undertook a massive rebalance that went a long way towards making this a very enjoyable game, and continued that through the 1.8 patch, and added a new PvE area in the northwest of the map and a lot of Dark Zone north of the original map.

The loot and build possibilities are great, Survival remains one of my favorite game modes of anything ever, and considering this game is now older and the price is either low or extremely low (I think sometimes you can get the entire game, DLC and all for about $10) this is very worth picking up if you like loot based games and/or tactical shooting. Lots of depth if you want to explore it, but enough value to the tactical side that if you just maintain some basic build points you can get through a solid open world and campaign missions arc that I've enjoyed playing through several times now. At $20 it's a very good deal. At $10 it's an absolute steal for the time you can sink, and if you know any friends who didn't play it before, everything after the Brooklyn intro mission can be run with a 4-player group (intro must be run solo AFAIK)

It is an OK looter-shooter but must know that there aren't many players  left in this game.
Doing story missions, side quests, walking around new york may be fun.
Endgame gear (classified sets) grinding will be tough - Requires activities involving a party of 4 such as raids (incursions) and wave defenses (resistance). 
Global events do help solo players farm endgame gears but they happen occasionally.

Massive distrust in pvp - this game was once manipulate-able with cheat engine and so many working hacks from China still exists up to this date. If you get killed in pvp zone you are never sure if you got outskilled/better build or cheated. 

Survival DLC is fun and worth - It's a rogue-like race to extraction starting from 0 and you farm your gears to way out. PVE and PVP mode both exists so that new players can learn in PVE mode and more experienced players can compete in PVP mode. Almost no hacks in survival mode and time to kill is much shorter so pvp is actually more fun than regular  darkzone pvp.

Other dlc's aren't really worth mentioning. Like I said above, not many players in this game.

Overall don't take any less than 65~70% off deal including dlcs. Gold edition unnecessary.
Main game + Survival dlc would be good enough

Quite a good game, though TCTD2 is better in terms of controls. If you feel like running the first part of the story before/after 2d one - grab it.

Edit: However if you've played TCTD2 before TCTD be prepared that it is more difficult compared to the 2d one: the drop rates are lower for uncommon items, chests are met not as often as in TCTD2 and survival in general is harder during combats 1 vs 3+. I'd say that in TCTD they've made the bet on co-op rather than single player. Also some items work differently compared to TCTD2. As an example of such difference we can use special ammo: here you pick it up and can use it when needed but it only lasts 30s meanwhile in TCTD2 when you pick up special ammo it becomes main ammo for your currently chosen weapon (at the moment of pickup) and lasts until you use up all the 30 rounds of it. Also different grenade types (frag, smoke, flash etc.) are available from the start in TCTD you just need to find them, meanwhile in TCTD2 they are given later on in the game if at all.

All in all both games are very good in my opinion and I enjoy the opportunity to walk around the districts and inside some buildings just observing how things are there, where I've never been before IRL.

Edit 3o/XII/2o2o

At first I had my doubts, and having read various reviews about "bullet sponges" I fell for it and didn't buy.  But, I decided to take a look.  I'm really glad I did.  At time of writing I'm LVL 9, haven't got the best gear and I don't really care.  My opinion, as long as you don't try to go for the toughest enemies, try and clear the biggest locations, get the best gear, you can have a very good game experience.

The Division has a great story, a feeling that at one end your doing your part to rectify the devastation that has hit New York, where the civilians really appreciate what your doing (some don't, and I don't think you can shoot them in the ass to get the point across), the other leaving you with a sense of utter frustration as you see civilians stumble and die in the street from either the conditions or the virus.  So you keep plugging on, and you know you have to.

So yes I really recommend getting this game.  There seems like lots to do, lots to achieve and a worthy goal to aim for.  I read somewhere that, as long as your "ahead of the map", which I think means as your level grows, stick around in the initial levels and don't venture further that your gear is capable of.  You will lose that bullet sponge feeling.  Try to engage your targets at range, and head shots do make a difference.  Your weapons and gear feel real, you get that sense of carrying lots of tech as you trudge up the street.  I really like the ISAC system, your friendly A.I ally providing you with real time tactical data while your on your mission.  Feels nice and technical.  And one of the best game soundtracks I've heard.

So join up, do your part and help save New York.  Let's face it, most disaster movies and games seem to have that poor city either decimated by a virus, aliens, zombies.. you name it.  Let's help it out one... more... time.

Have a great day!

[i]For a game i spent over 497 hrs in I think I should review it. You know i see so many reviews on steam with only one to twenty hrs in the game then some one thinks they should review it, To me and this is just my opinion that's wasting peoples time' that's why most if not all my reviews have over 100 hrs in the game. But i am old school my interest in computers and computers games goes all the way back to 1983, on a side note if any one who reads this review goes all the way back to then add me as a friend us old school need to stick together. Anyway on we go, The Division when it came out i had a i7 4790k and a GTX 970 GPU and for the most part the game ran very well on high setting and as for modern CPU,s and GPU,s like 20s or 30s cards you should have no problems running it on ultra settings. The story is very engrossing from start to finish i cant say much more than that as i don't want to spoil it for you. As a RPG you can spend hours just on your character alone. The missions and side missions are very varied with very good pacing, Its one of them with this game you can roll on your own or with friends. I've had some people say the games repetitive, People like that need learn how to play a RPG its not GTA 5' but you and i both know they will not be told. As for game play its up there with some of the best game play in any RPG out there even now, I mean you got the snow in New York at night in a fire fight from hell, enemies left and right with heavy fog every where. The thing i can remember the most is just getting lost round the city at night and getting in some mad fire fights some mad stuff going off that's what i will always take away from the The Division. The Dev's up keep of the game what with updates and balancing is simply amazing work. If you have never played The Division then you should give it a go then move on to the division 2 and that's simply amazing with over 785 hrs in that and still rolling. Hope my opinions don't upset anyone, But then i cant remember a day when peoples opinions didn't upset anyone.[/i]

I've barely been able to play the game due to a bug in the ubisoft connect launcher. I already owned the base game on UCL when I bought it again with all dlc on steam, the connect feature bugged out.

Ubisoft came the rescue with their first reply within 12 hours of me posting my issue, and within a few days the issue was sorted.

For a now 4-5 year old game from a Triple A company with much bigger, better and newer titles to worry about, let alone the sequel, the customer support given to me took my breath away. Normally it would take over a month for me to get a fix, for that alone out of pure respect I give a positive review for a game I haven't even played.

I heard the game was really good anyways. Hence why I bought it lol.

Thank you Ubisoft Support.

Hint: if you having an issue where you can continue to linking your content from steam to your ubisoft account, just press tab until you have "continue" highlighted, then you can press enter to make it work as normal. Basically the mouseless way of pressing continue.

Nice Game

CPU - i7 4790k
GPU - nvidia 2070 Super

Game uses 100% CPU at random times until BSOD.
Game never uses more than 25% of GPU.
Trying to switch from windowed-fullscreen to fullscreen freezes the game, have to force quit in Task Manager.
Game is old, broken, never optimized, never fixed, basically abandoned.  I may have to refund it.  Screw Ubisoft.

*update 1*
Scoured the internet for help.  Says I have to go into Task Manager and:
Set Priority: LOW
Set Affinity: uncheck some CPU cores
Video Options: Disable DX12, reboot, set to fullscreen, turn DX12 back on, reboot, until it finally sticks without crashing.  

Now I get to try to play the game after owning it for 80 minutes.

*update 2*
Had to look up how to swap shoulders.  No keybind in-game.  Internet says you have to Aim Down Sights and THEN press the Run key (default Shift).  I love console ports.

The Division is a superb start to a new franchise and an experience that will leave you on the edge of your seat!

The Division is a beautiful and addictive looter shooter, with a gameplay loop that keeps on giving.You can choose to group with friends or matchmake with strangers for a cooperative experience.As you level up, new gear, weapons, mods, and cosmetic attire are acquired at a healthy rate, providing consistently improving stats and options for style of play.The progression and player customization systems are notable highlights.The hook that the brings fun to The Division's shooting, co-op play, and world is the RPG element. While leveling up, everything that drops has worth. Gear, weapons, and mods can be equipped if they're an improvement, sold for credits to buy other items, or broken down into materials for crafting.The Dark Zone is a high-stakes, high-anxiety multiplayer experience where you never know if the person standing next to you has your back … or is just waiting to stab you in it.

I've taken three swings at this game on PC and Xbox over the years.  Most recently, I picked it up again on PC and played through to the end game before writing this review.

I'm friendly to this sort of over-the-shoulder presentation, other than when the camera fails and I can't see my target but only my own back. ;-)  I'm a play-the-story and run-all-the-side-quests kind of completionist.  If you're not, then some of my commentary won't be as useful.  Stipulating that, there's LOTS to complete in this game and that's very fulfilling.

I like the leveling in the game and found, personally, that running all the side quests and maybe replaying some of the mission content on a harder level let me level up my character "ahead of the map".  This let me spend more time enjoying engagements and running the map rather than worrying about dying all the time. I'm not a Dark Souls fan for this very reason.  Again, Your Mileage May Vary.

I find the combat model to be solid, predictable, crisp.  You need a decent graphics card and plenty of RAM to keep the model feeling crisp.  This is a shoot-from-cover game.  No toe-to-toe, hack-and-slash battles here.  On the PC keyboard, movement control in battle, ESPECIALLY while retreating, can be hit-or-miss (please pardon the pun).  My greatest frustrations in the game have been trying to correctly control the keyboard while in retreat.  I often have troubles with the move out of cover walking instead of running, missing the next cover point, or landing on a cover point that is still exposed and having to force the character around the corner.  Lots of dying there.  This may be because I suck at keyboard control.  Could be.  I don't recall having this much trouble in similar situations on the Xbox, which suggests either failing memory or finding the controller easier to navigate than the keyboard in those scenarios.  YMMV.

Interactions with the world are pretty reliable with some minor annoyance from some items that are in field-of-view aren't recognized as actionable. Usually this happens when I'm standing too close to the item.  Not a big deal, but it breaks the flow when you're moving quickly around the map.

I'm VERY happy with the gearing improvements that come at Level 30 as you enter end-game.  I immediately picked up a series of great high-end gear that changed game play for the better.  I was really worried about being tough enough for end-game and wasn't looking forward to the anticipated gear-grind that one sees in, say, Destiny or most RPGs.

Which brings me to the Dead Zone.  I've hated the Dead Zone in the past.  It's just too damn hard.  Yeah, great reward from great risk and all that.  I get it.  But going back and forth between the story line and the Dead Zone never worked for me.  I hit it a couple times coming up through the ranks this play through and it was better than I remembered.  I first journeyed in around L19.  Given the end-game gear and my wildly-improved toughness, I'm ready to give it another try.

Ultimately, this is a really good game.  I enjoyed playing through The Division 2, which I never end-gamed, either.  But this is a solid franchise that provides many hours of enjoyment even for a fairly conservative battle-at-a-distance sort of game play.  And it's an adrenaline rush when you have a skilled run pushing against enemies.  Highly recommended.

UPDATE 11/2020 /// CURRENT PATCH 1.8.3 released 8/2018
2000+ hours and still going.
Honestly one of the best games out there. 
+++Pros+++
+Unique 3rd person RPG,

+current day setting, 

+amazing map and locations that tell a story (unlike Division 2), 

+B A L A N C E (Unlike Division 2), 

+O P T I M I Z A T I O N (Unlike Division 2 even after TU12 it won't be Balanced so, no point in optimization), 

+Great DLC, Underground and Survival are must-haves. Buy the Season pass though if you love the game.

+Game runs well too, just turn down Volumetric Fog if the gas grenades eat your FPS. 4 core optimization. 

+ORIGINAL DarkZone with ORIGINAL Gear Sets, 

+S Y N E R G Y (Unlike Division 2), 

+Challenging yet balanced PVE that feels rewarding and fun to play in the end game.

+Legendary missions are really cool, 

+If you like to help new players, this is a great game that is complex and loot focused, a lot of players need help, and it's (sometimes) easy enough to help them a fair bit.

+Game is on Uplay and EGS so Steam Charts only ever could tell 30% of the player base, it's popular in Europe.

+PVP against players who aren't cheaters can be super fun.

+STILL Global Events happening, 2 in December 2020! 

+++ #Division1forever #Division1AintDead

---Cons---
-Terrible "guides" on youtube featuring incomplete info and very bad advice. The more views a video has, the worse it is.

-Game has cheaters in PVP. It will make you rage.

-Ubisoft literally couldn't care less about hackers and cheaters ruining their product, or about cases of public shaming and online abuse. They are the worst in the business, hands down the laziest AAA publisher out there. 

-Chinese VPN players for some reason polluting our regional server in USA (Toronto CA Ubi Server)

-That's right, ALL of NA, CA, and even Mexico + South America on ONE Ubi Server in Canada...Weird.

-Chinese players have a culture of hacking and cheating to gain an advantage, since in their opinion, if you can't be caught then you are stupid not to use cheats. They VPN to America since we have less cheaters, and wreck us. They spam chat until it's unusable and even have boosting businesses built on this game, which.... in total is pretty damn disgusting. 

-No Language specific chat channels and many hidden chat commands that players don't know about such as "Ignore", right click names in chat for a small list.

-Hit registration and net code is not on a competitive level, you can't take this game too seriously, even if there weren't cheaters. 

-Even if people don't cheat there are some annoying glitches like the High Firearms D3 glitch some people in the DZ still use. Macros can be used for weird stuff like no recoil and skill proxy throw distance, making the game kind of weird for those who don't know about this BS.

-Sometimes annoying bugs and glitches (like most good games)

The best 2020 simulator on market, but instead of a normal citizen you play as an agent with a cool watch and get to loot everything and kill everyone you don't like. After killing some flamethrower guy, prison escapees and PMC weirdos, don't forget to also enter the shitshow that is the Dark Zone where everything went fubar and players get to kill each other.

Pros:
-especially immersive due to recent events
-HUD is well designed and looks nice
-Plenty of weapons to choose from
-Campaign is alright for an open world game
-most possible gear builds are viable in game and can actually do something
-the Dark Zone experience, although not always pleasant, is definitely worth trying
-Cool Watch that does everything for you, except farming
Cons:
-DLCs suck, Survival is an exception
-online playing only, and sometimes your shots won't be registered by the server, This may kill you when you are in some high tier endgame locations
-Dark Zone is a shitshow
-heavy grind and most things are rng based
-most guys in endgame can tank 100ish~ shots from an endgame machine gun with their faces, this being the main problem since some of these guys can stun lock you once in your proximity and melee you to death. Group up with others to make this less of a problem
-I really want to play Division 2 on steam

Conclusion: Good game, wait for sale, best with friends

I literally spent 90 hours in 2 weeks on this game when I first started seriously playing it. So much stuff to do, massive grind, normal PvE gets boring at some point but the Dark Zone never loses of its charm and is literally the sole reason this game exists at this point. The Dark Zone (DZ) is at this point an Among Us shooter. You go in, mask on, geared like Rambo and you fck people up or you get fcked. You can easily find people to either hang out with or kill once you know the map a little bit. 

One thing which made me fall in love with this game, SO MUCH FREEDOM. You walk around the streets, you fight some NPC idiots, you chill for a bit, then new enemies. There's so much stuff to do. 
Personally the most satisfying thing which happens is when I arrive into a gang war, some NPC idiots against some other NPC idiots and enjoy the view, chill, shoot at the low hp ones to get the kill exp, and resume the chilling.

Sets are a hassle to learn at first but there aren't too many, I've basically memorized them all at this point and I've got all the 4 pieces sets obtained. Meta weapons basically consist of assault rifles and SMGs. My personal preference is to have a sniper rifle, very good against tanky af elites and bosses. 
Check out guides or w/e you can find about weak points if you're new, they do help tremendously and can turn the tide of a firefight in PvE. 

ALSO (he didn't pay me for this) CHECK OUT WIDDZ ON YOUTUBE MY LEARNING CURVE WENT THROUGH THE ROOF AFTER LOOKING AT LIKE 10 VIDEOS

Anyway, this game is better than The Division 2, and I don't see myself getting massively bored of it to the point of uninstalling it anytime soon. 

Is it worth 20 bucks ? Hard to say. Less ? Instabuy.

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38888018-United-Critics/] Please follow [b]United Critics[/b] for quality reviews[/url]

[h1]The Division Review[/h1]

The Division stands out differently from all other games. It’s not just a game, it’s a whole feeling. It provides everything that an excellent title should have. A brilliantly detailed and vast map, a lot of customizations, challenging enemies, re-playability, multiplayer, and a smart split of PVP and PVE regions makes the game a masterpiece and counts as a new-gen game. Color schemes and combat mechanics are all amazing. The number and level of enemies depend upon your lobby size, making it ideally challenging with friends. Don’t wait and enter the streets of New York to establish peace and order. 

[h1][b]Gameplay:[/b][/h1]
The scene portrays a pandemic in New York City that gave origin to many riot groups and gangs that are not co-operating with the officials. As an agent, your job is to restrict any illegal activity or inhumane actions. Establishing peace during a pandemic is a challenging task, that’s why division agents are recruited. Every segment of the map holds its side missions, crates, dossier, and encounters. Your gameplay experience will determine according to the customizations you configure, gears you loot, or missions you select. Firing feels super smooth irrespective of the gun you use. Authentic guns make the combat super intense. Pretty amazing to use a Vector with its incredible RPM, or finding that power punch M44. It doesn’t end here as you can even have 30+ weapon talents that add bonuses to your weapon. 

Variation in enemies is always a crucial part of a game, and division has a good variety in style and difficulty of combat. Some of them will die quickly, while some are built like tanks and will require loads of ammo magazines. As you can’t jump in the division series, so only specific objects are climbable. There are no vehicles, so you will have to travel on foot, but a lot of encounters with enemies can happen, so either select that or use fast travel on safe zones by completing their respective missions. According to your party size, the number of enemies change, which keeps the game difficulty balanced and fun.  Your primary objective is to establish a Base of Operations (or BOO), where you can meet other players and unlock three wings – Tech Wing, Medical Wing, and Security Wing. It broadens up the gameplay hours by a lot, personal favorite missions as they are unique, and each upgrade can provide one or more Perks, Skills, or Talents for the player, as well as making cosmetic changes to the wing and the base overall.

[h1][b]Graphics:[/b][/h1]
Hands down to the best realistic graphics that you will encounter in an open-world game. They are not bland nor too shiny, making it a perfect balance. The moment you enter the map, you will see gorgeous detailing and an impressive design. Every structure you see on the map can exist in the actual world, making it a great game to have a realistic experience. The snowy atmosphere is a delight to the eyes. Glass reflections and sun glares are all amazingly done. You will be surprised to see the amount of detailing done on the inner and outer parts of the map. Small detailing like tiny logos on machines, torn pages on the ground, graffitis, pianos, and photo frames in houses. Probably the only game with so much text on the screen and still no interruption on screen as it blends perfectly. The orange tint for the interactive menus feels so good. And all these detailing on a huge map! 

[h1][b]Main Pros and Cons:[/b][/h1]

[b]Pros-[/b]
[list]
    [*]Great overall game.
    [*]Broad gameplay.
    [*]Supports multiplayer. 
    [*]Astonishing graphics and in-depth detailing.
    [*]Story feels real.
    [*]Impressive way of supporting PVE and PVP playstyles.
    [*]Various gear customization.
    [*]Easy to learn controls.
    [*]Good looking attire and skins.
    [*]Aim shoulder swap.
[/list]

[b]Cons-[/b]
[list]
    [*]It might feel challenging for a lot of player base because some of the enemies require a lot of bullets.
    [*]Stutter and crash issues on minimum rigs.
    [*]NPC allies are dumb.
    [*]Dark zone has hacker problem.
[/list]

[h1][b]Tips to new players:[/b][/h1]
Only play single-player if you are ready to grind and face a big wave on enemies. An effective agent depends a lot on his gear. So instead of sticking to one type of gear set, change them while leveling up. You can add mods to specific equipment that will help you in combats. Focus more on wing missions as they unlock several weapon talents and perks. The most basic and effective gear set is to use high damage sniper, high rpm rifle with a big mag, and a good firepower pistol. If you are struggling with knowing where the enemies are, use tactical scanner ability that can be unlocked by the medical wing, this will highlight all enemies on the radar. 

[h1][b] Miscellaneous Information:[/b][/h1]

[b]Dossier-[/b]
Along with the story missions, there are several side tasks that award you extra items. 
[list]
[*]Division Shields - Shields are a collection of twelve collectibles that reward players for completing challenges throughout the game. Earning a Shield will reward the player with a shield cache that contains a selection of valuable items and currency bundles. They also give rewards that you can redeem in division 2.
[*]Commendations- These are specific general and combat challenges that reward you cosmetic cypher fragments which can be used to buy 3 random premium cosmetic items from the premium vendor.
[*]Evidence- A unique way to gather information that helps you to figure out what is really going on in New York.
[*]Field Data- It can be categorized into six categories: Survival Guidebook, Phone Recordings, Incident Reports, Crashed Drones, Missing Agents, Echos, and each one has different missions and rewards.
[*]Expansions- Visit underground to collect audio journals and urbex albums for extra rewards.
[/list]

[b]Loadouts-[/b]
The game has the option to make six loadouts that you can switch anytime according to the combat. 

[b]Crafting-[/b]
You can use electronic parts, fabrics, weapon parts, and tools to craft better mods and gear.

[h1] Honest Rating:[/h1]
Division not only slays the graphics scene but also stays firm in the gameplay aspect. There is a lot of stuff to do in the game, making it high hour grinding game. Select your gameplay according to PVE or PVP preference. Remarkable in-game UI and multi-player options make it a perfect pick to play with friends. Highly recommended game, even without a sale.

So good the guns feel real. The visceral RPG elements blend together well with the shooting elements. Each gear piece is unique, from it's helmets, braces, padding, armor, and weapons. It's incredibly stat based and talent based, and you can build and form your character in a lot of ways. It's more of an RPG than a shooter, and that's what I was looking for. For an RPG game, I'd give it an 80%, as a video game 60%, and as a shooter 80%. It's a progression game, from the player statistics, the gear which you can fine tune, to the skills, talents, and the way you can choose how to form the base camps. Overall, I like this game better than it's sequel, which is a PvP game, whereas this is a PvE game. I can see how this game isn't for some people, because it's mainly an RPG, and some play it as a shooter. 
[h1]Bottom line: stats are the main course and guns are sides.[/h1]
Suspiciously fits right into 2020. Get it cheap on a sale and you'll see what I mean!

I'm really impressed by how bad this game is (lol). I phrase it this way because it has the appearance of a AAA title, but really just fails on extreme basics. I write this from the perspective of someone that has been gaming for about 30 years, everything from super hardcore sims to casual side-scrollers.

The failings are in basic mechanics:

--The tutorial system likes to flash something at you very briefly, then permanently disappear before you have a chance to actually read it.
--The menu system is bewilderingly complicated. There are tabs upon tabs upon tabs, organized in a seemingly random way. It really blows my mind how a design factor like this could be overlooked.
--There is no pause. I can see why a rogue-like game or a purely multiplayer would do this, but in theory this is a single-player game with MP elements. The fact that there is no separation between SP and MP is actually a hindrance. I don't have any interest in multiplayer, ever...but I can't pause the freakin' game.
--On that note, even if I accept I can't pause it, and instead go to one of the safe areas so I can take a phone call or something IRL, it ends my game with no announcement and kicks me to the main menu. This occurs after only a few minutes of inactivity. Apparently I'm supposed to keep flailing around at all times or I'm punished. A simple "do you wish to leave and SAVE YOUR PROGRESS" would be nice. Note: I am talking about an actual game mechanic, not a bug.
--It doesn't tell you that certain actions in a mission are part of a larger objective, and if you leave the game at that point, you will have to repeat that entire @*$&% story arc. I quit at one point and literally had to redo about 30 mins of gameplay.
--And when you have to repeat anything, due to leaving the game or getting killed, you will have to listen to the entire radio transmission history again and again, each time you respawn. I'm trying this mission for the 7th time, I don't need to be briefed...AGAIN.
--And why am I trying this mission for the 7th time? Because the cover system is laughably terrible. I'm rolling no wait I'm going into cover no wait I'm sticking to this wall no I'm trying to get *off* this wall no I'm trying to go around the corner no I'm trying to move to the next piece of cover but no I've left cover for no apparent reason now I'm dead again. I don't what type of player likes this system. There are plenty of games that handle "sticky cover" fine...this one, not so much.
--Enemies frequently shoot through objects and kill me when I'm behind solid cover. Maybe it's just through some impossible 1-pixel-wide tear in the time-space continuum...but how they're able to do this is invisible to the player. This happens a lot. One enemy, downrange, I'm crouched behind a metal crate, and something just one-shots me in the face. Not fun. Again - basics.
--What is with all the floating GUI overlays in the world? I can see why Deus Ex would do this, because he's a cybernetically-enhanced guy with AR goggles. But why is my GPS position, my objective, my waypoint to the objective, the sub-waypoints, etc all overlaid on virtually every surface? It really breaks immersion and it's really friggin annoying. Ideally I should see one overlay - the objective, and then have to consult the map for more detail (like literally every other game in existence). I just want all those cheesy lines to go away lol.
--Missions are reeaaallly repetitive. I'm only 9 hours in, and I feel like I've seen it all. Same hooded-sweatshirt guys saying the same lines over and over. I'm just...bored.

It's a bummer to be so negative as I generally don't leave reviews like this...but this game has really basic design/mechanic problems. Oy.
