**Update as of 12/25/17**

I sidelined this game for quite a while in hopes that when I finally decided to pick it up again there would be plenty to do.

After patch 1.8  I decided to hop on again and see what has been added and changed and I was extremely disappointed. There have been several purchasable DLC's and major update since the last time I played,  But I find myself doing the exact same things that I was doing when the game was first launched.

Grind for gear so you can grind for gear so you can grind for gear.

You are fighting the exact same enemies the use the exact same tactics the only thing that has changed is that you are fighting them in different locations on the map.

When I think "mmorpg"  I think of games like World of Warcraft, Everquest, etc.  The common theme being that there is a reason for all of your grinding, that reason being end game content/bosses that you are working towards defeating. Defeating those final bosses in a raid is what the entire PVE aspect of the game is about. The gear and rewards you get for killing those bosses just a bonus.

In The Division, gear is literally everything. The entire game is simply grinding for gear and there is really nothing special about that gear. The end game simply revolves around you upgrading the stats on your gear so you can continue to farm more gear, which eventually just becomes useless junk because reaching the maximum available item level doesn't take very much time at all.

This game was marketed as an MMORPG/tactical shooter and I feel like it has failed bringing us either of those.

I had about a week's worth of enjoyment from this game when it was first released, but I don't see any reason to play it anymore.

3/10 overall.

Ubisoft was daring with The Division, they attempted to create something new and original - a co-op TPS with RPG elements that is kind of like an MMO. It was an interesting blend of genres that, with a heavy marketing push, ended up paying off financially for Ubisoft and creating a successful new franchise.

The story revolves around a post-apocalyptic New York after the city has been put in quarantine due to deadly pandemic. Sounds familiar? It is only a few steps away from the current events, so it can definitely help with the game immersion. :) Although the New York City is well designed and the attention to detail is fantastic, it can be a bit stale always experiencing snowy environment.

When it comes to gameplay, it will either make or break the game for you. It involves moving cover to cover, using different weapons and skills, and constantly replacing weapons and gear with better rolled stats. The main complaint people had with this game when it first came out was the “bullet sponginess” of enemies: “They are human enemies yet they take so many bullets - Me cannot compute!” This is intentional design of the game and there really is no gameplay issue with it. Besides, if you are using a rifle or marksman rifle and go for headshots, enemies are really easy to kill. An issue that I do have with the game though is the difficulty curve. If you do all the side missions along the way, you become very overpowered and the game provides no real challenge later on. Another well-known main problem is the lack of the end game content. After you finish the story there is really nothing else to do but the Dark Zone, a PvP/PvE part of the game. For this zone you really need to have the proper gear and teammates, because if you don’t, you will get wrecked by people who have both and know what they’re doing. The Dark Zone was not the most appealing part of the game to me and I'm not sure how active is nowadays.

If you treat this game like a campaign/story experience you will not be disappointed. If you are able to get 3 more friends to play this with, the game becomes even better. The difficulty scales significantly and it is much more fun to coordinate and experience the game with a group. For the end game content I would suggest focusing on The Division 2, as it has much more to offer.

Tom Clancy’s The Division™ Review

Something great that just fell short of true greatness.

Some key points that this game offers:
1.	Authentic Open World
2.	RPG meets Realism
3.	Tactical Gameplay
4.	Brilliant Story line

READ THE FULL REVIEW HERE:
https://mgrgaming.co.za/tom-clancys-the-division-review/

MGR Gaming’s Conclusions:
Spoilers Ahead:

As far as Tom Clancy games go, this is a brilliant new Gameworld. Even though this is the first one where weapon damage is less realistic than the others. It still gives you that fantastic Tom Clancy experience.

The game paints a very visual and vivid picture of how bad things have gotten, as services failed things piled up and the situation got much worse. It paints a very realistic picture of what such an event or any world level catastrophic event could cause. 

The gameplay is both good and bad. The enemies really are “bullet sponges” and that isn’t just due to the game being an RPG; The games combat mechanics really need some balancing. The end result isn’t really that rewarding, to be honest. For an RPG one would expect the DPS to be comprised of some unique modifiers and other contributors, unfortunately, that is not the case here. It basically comes down to finding gear with better stats, and no unique modifiers. It is quite difficult to accurately measure your combat strength and prowess due to how the system was set up, further bringing down the ‘wow factor’ here.

The above does bring the overall long-term joy down that the game offers, especially when it comes down to end game grinding and playing, however, I am hopeful that a future patch will rebalance this.

The gameplay is fun and rather memorable; however, it also gets lonely quite fast. There are, unfortunately, no random occurrences or even scripted occurrences for you to come across whilst exploring Manhattan. There is the odd chance that you will run into some JTF troops randomly patrolling the streets or engaging enemies. That however is it, which is disappointing, especially since this is considered an Open World MMO. One would expect there to be plenty more to see and do.

The Dark Zone is a rather unique aspect. You get to explore a brand new zone that is ready to face you. Enemies scaled to your level and to make matters even more challenging, rogue agents. You will meet fellow agents whilst exploring the Dark Zone, and things can go either way. They might aid you or they might attack, kill, and rob you of your hard earned loot. 
The Division has a lot of potential and it is fun as is. It can be better for sure, once a few updates fix the current problems that exist and perhaps add some new features.

One of my favourite shooter games, The Division hits differently after COVID-19 - especially as we are approaching fall and winter again. The game has very pretty graphics, and not just environmentally (although I definitely love the look of the game). The sounds are very nice and 𝘤𝘳𝘪𝘴𝘱, especially with the guns. The guns in general are very pleasant to use, with customisation and options. The storyline is captivating enough to make you want to continue. And the exploration is a lot more enjoyable with friends.
However, I cannot say the game is perfect because it does have quite a bit of flaws and time has not always been kind. The most important thing is that the enemies are pure bullet sponges; they take so much more to kill than you, and there is a lot of grinding you need to do in order to feel like it's 'fair.' This makes it very hard or unfun for solo players who don't like grinding, especially if you go into the Dark Zone (which is a PVE area that has succumbed to hackers and the most elite players as most players left the game years or months ago). The Dark Zone is an optional PVE area, but it is a big area for gaining better weapons fast; so if you're scared of the online play from hackers, not liking PVP, etc. then you'll find 1/3 of the map unusable. Another smaller thing though is that gameplay is repetitive as the missions don't change. 
In general though, I do recommend the game because I had a lot of fun when I first played, and I log in every now and again for a quick game. However I'm very comfortable with solo play, I'm okay with grinding, and I'm not a big PVP type, so if you are 𝘕𝘖𝘛 like me then I cannot recommend the game.

ABSOLUTELY ONE OF THE WORST MENU INTERFACES I HAVE EVER HAD TO DEAL WITH. I am a IT technician, I know how computers work. I just spent hours just simply trying to get the flipping game to work. It wont let you delete old profiles, wont go into full screen mode when you set it to that, you have to play the game with the stupid windows bar at the bottom of the screen because for some reason it wont go away, when you shoot at enemies you have to unload a million bullets into them just to drop them, even if they are head shots. CMON, ARE YOU SERIOUS? YOU GUYS SPENT ALL THIS TIME MAKING THIS GAME BUT COULDNT INCLUDE THESE SIMPLE THINGS? This is my second try at playing this game and i havent even been able to play for because i can figure out how to restart game and all the other various problems. I am reminded now adsactly why i quit trying to play this game a couple years ago, because everything is screwed up. what a waste of my time. IM SOOO IRRITATED.2nd Part of REVIEW: So, after spending a day figuring out how to find all the secrets out about how to delete an old profile, to create a new one, and i worked on the full screen/window bar problem and it started working, and then did a whole bunch of research about what all the different little numbers on the huds mean and other mechanics of the technical aspects of the game, I finally was able to start playing again and this is what i have to say about it.ABSOLOUTLY BEAUTIFUL. THE GAME IS ABSOLOUTLY BREATHTAKINGLY FLIPPING BEAUTIFUL. I thank you guys for taking so much time out to make such an impressive environment, all the detail, the whole experience, is worth all the pain of what I had to go through to get there. I came all the way back here to fix this review because you guys deserve it. You did an amazing job. I also happen to think I am an above average FPS player, and i want to mention a few things about the gunplay etc. I appreciate that you spent alot of time with the different customizations options for us to toggle at our liking of the weapons. I also, appreciate that after upgrading the weapons and figuring out how to use the scopes properly so that i could turn it into a fps appropriatly when needed. Honestly, I love how i can kind of choose between 1st and 3rd person view to an extent. I had to place my zoom button somewhere easily accessible so that it would leave me with a seamless experience when in a firefight. And, honestly, i like it. I like that i can change between the two views. Def deepens the visuals and experience. As for the AI. A+. The tactical movements of the AI were well done. As, for the sponge issue with the bullets. That should be fixed please. I cant stand that. I do understand that it is needed for more unexperienced players. But, honestly, screw them. lol. How are they supposed to learn huh? Just kidding. No, but serious, can we at least have a hardcore setting to eliminate that issue for those that need that type of gunplay? I am not expecting changes of course to this since its so old, but, maybe for future games you make? Also, very happy with the way you set up the communication aspect for the players in group management. Communication is everything. THANK YOU FOR MAKING SUCH AN AMAZING GAME. AMEN.

Imagine playing a game where the backstory of your character is that you are a part of a specialized branch of the government that responds to national crisis. Like a counter terrorist group, the national guard, the fbi, or cia? Nope. Something else. Okay.. But your day job could of been like a fire fighter, medical personnel, a civil engineer, a tech specialist, or some kind of emergency service profession. Anything where your day job doesn’t end with a pile of dead people. Cool. 

Now the game world has this really bad flu that has ripped through it and your job is to help rebuild it while taking care of some baddies and loose ends. Oh you mean covid? Kinda like that, wear your mask and wash your damn hands. Still with me here, right?

The rest of the game is kicking in doors and killing everything, even the dog that looked at you side ways on the street. No negotiations, no arrests, no saving wounded or starving people, no rebuilding anything. Wait, you said we were emergency service professions not soldiers? You are right!! And you also fight professional soldiers in the game. So Its like getting stuck in bizarro world of bat sh*t ideas? Correct.

The gun play seems perfect until about mid game, than bullet sponge ruins the remainder of the “core experience”. Take out this boss in 15-30 head shots.... wait what? Yay its realistic, he is bamf. *vomits* 

Your character is stronger than the plague that wiped out the city. As you gun down hundreds upon thousands of rioters, looters, ex prisoners. Wait? I thought we saved people? Nah man Violence solves everything right?

Some characters act completely different than what is written about them in the games own archives; i.e some one is a level headed professional mercenary but their npc dialogue and what they actually does is totally a 180 boss fight. “What a twist” screams M night!

[i]The Division[/i] é um jogo com um gênero [b]"Hibrido"[/b] que trás um enredo com alguns personagens, e modos, habilidades, armas, classes e diversas outras coisas, deixando o jogo hibrido nesse sentido, pois não se encaixa em nenhum dos gêneros, no inicio ele já é surpreendente, trás a principio [b]Gráficos[/b] incríveis com diversos detalhes, uma iluminação forte e destacável, tendo apenas alguns defeitos no desempenho que a depende do Hardware tem quer ter uma configuração especifica para não excede o limite ou esquenta muito o PC ou Notebook. Além desse ponto, o jogo tem uma ótimos [b]Efeitos Sonoros[/b] adaptável ao ambiente que são um tanto variável, também apresenta uma HUD incrível, que é o ponto mais marcante no jogo é sua [b]Interface[/b] que principalmente para época um tanto inovadora, trazendo uma experiência um tanto quanto "Profunda".

A [b]Historia[/b] é uma coisa simples de se entender, mais não é tão simplória, o jogo deixa ao jogadores mais interessados, pontos pelo mapa com fragmentos da historia para buscar, não sendo a principal mais não afetará em nada se não fazer-la é apenas um recurso opcional. O jogo deixa extremamente direto quais são os objetivos e como busca-lo, o mapa em questão tem uma [b]"Legenda de MAPA"[/b] um tanto quanto detalhada para os objetivos, tendo [u](Missões Principais, Secundarias e as Terciarias)[/u] tendo como a principal a única com fragmentos da historia, as outras como forma de explorar e obter recursos.

Mas a parte mais interessante do jogo que é que o [b]"Final"[/b] dele é o inicio do jogo, quando você chegar no final na ultima missão que é liberada no Nível 30 do personagem, após o player finalizar o mapa abre novas possibilidades, no estilo de [b]MMORPG[/b] dos jogos de Sandbox o The Division seguir o mesmo raciocínio, novas missões, o estilo de classificação mudar é basicamente um estilo de jogo diferente, deixando o jogo ainda mais interessante e com novas possibilidades para explorar. Além desses aspectos no jogo existe um [u]estilo/modo[/u] de PVP, que é uma Zona que se encontrar que chama-se [u]DarkZone[/u] é uma área especifica onde tem outro estilo de Rank apenas naquela área com objetivos e formas de lotear diferente, podendo [b]"Cooperar"[/b] ou até mesmo[/b]"Roubar" de outros players. Em geral é um PVP com seus objetivos.. Fora estes modos tem os das DLC's que eu não obtive.

Em geral é um jogo que tem muito a oferece aos players, uma profundidade de conteúdo incrível, com diversas possibilidades e horas para jogar tanto Solo quanto em Grupo. Mas nem tudo é flores, o jogo possuir seus pequenos defeitos, [b](Sim, pequenos)[/b] tem bugs que ao avança do game, ficam mais flexível de serem acessados, não que sejam extremamente notáveis ou até atrapalhem a um ponto extremo, são alguns que dão para aturar e não deixam o jogo impossibilitado, vale ressaltar novamente a todos o cuidado na hora de configurar os gráficos, pois Eu mesmo tive uma certa dificuldade pois o jogo, vem mal configurado nesse aspecto, aconselho a ver alguns vídeo, se sentir que o Hardware está esquentando demais sem necessidade. Pois no jogo é presente um Drop significativo de FPS, forçando o Hardware a utilizar uma quantidade de desempenho que a principio não é necessário. Bom, aproveitem o jogo que ele é incrível demais.

After years I'm glad to say: This game is still horrendously bland and boring. 

2 enemy factions (both just variations between thug and thug with flamethrower) which will both bore you 2 hours in. Only difference is whether or not they have a flammable canister strapped to their back. They'll do nothing to make the story more immersive and they only come in a few variants (generic gunman, melee dude, engi placing turrets, sniper and heavy gunner). Bosses are just the same with bigger healthbars. They're still just bland bullet sponges and that's all you'll end up doing aside from PvP, which always ends up just being a simple match of "who has the biggest numbers".

And for some reason they have yet to figure out what a PC is. The controls are very clearly not meant for PC and the person in charge of assigning keybinds but have been having a stroke. Duck behind cover defaults to spacebar. Jump, of all bloody things, defaults to ctrl. Forward roll defaults to double-tapping ctrl. Shift is sprint, but shift is also the button for changing the third person camera from looking over the right shoulder to the left shoulder and vice versa. The map doesn't seem to notice that there's a mouse, no click-and-drag options exist and you move it with freaking WASD. Scrolling doesn't even seem to register when zooming. Every interaction is a damn hold-to-confirm action even when you're in a hurry. Inventory has a bunch of dumb keybinds that could have just been a right-click drop-down menu. But no, that'd be too much effort in a cheap PC port. These devs don't care about their users. They shoved their button mapping over to some default keybinds by a guy who never played a PC game in his life and figured that'd be it. 

If the game was any good, I'd forgive such a lazy PC port. Hell, I love NieR: Automata despite having only played its PC port and that one had a lot of similar issues. But this is a bloody shooter. Shooters are best played on PC thanks to mouse control being more accurate than a controller could ever allow. Yet controls feel sluggish while running away from enemies that can 2-hit you while you can only hope to kill them on your 5th magazine because of their dumb bullet-sponge design. 

Free is the only correct price-point for this lame snoozefest of a game. And even then there's better things you could do with your time.

So The Division 1 is free on Uplay and I would recommend getting it and playing through the story. This game has one of the most beautiful and atmospheric setting based of off New York City. It is a very accurate replica of New York City. Broken cars, civilians trying to survive, dogs wandering around the devastated streets, gangs patrolling the area, make the setting feel alive and so immersive. 

In terms of gameplay/gunplay, you will find lots of loot as it is a looter shooter. You will spend a lot of time in your inventory experimenting different gun attachments and armor. If you do not like the idea of this, the game will bore you towards the end. Enemies feel like bullet sponges but the updates make the enemies bearable.

[b]The Division[/b] - [i]An uninspired looter shooter.[/i]

Note: Free to claim on Uplay until September 8th

[h3]Introduction[/h3]
Let me just start off by saying [b]IF[/b] I pre-ordered this, I would be [b]severely[/b] disappointed. The Division Is a looter shooter with RPG elements. It's set in the visually stunning New York City after a disease brings the country to its knees. You - The Division - are your ordinary folk tasked with bringing order back into NYC after those events (By shooting people). That's all I got really from around 16 hours of game play.

[h3]Story and gameplay[/h3]
The story is not interesting enough to engage me. The premise has potential but it's poorly executed - much like the gameplay. Now This is an RPG which means you will get slaughtered if enemies are higher level than you. I can accept this. What I can't accept is that enemies are really bullet spongy, even at your level. This has never been fun, so I don't know why devs keep doing it.  Having to empty a mag to kill a single enemy feels very sluggish and unenjoyable. The only time gun play felt good was when enemies where much lower level, and I could drop them within 5 or 6 rounds. It's also a looter shooter and the guns all feel the same. It's not meant to feel like that.  Sounds are also lack luster. They aren't horrid but they are lame enough to notice.

[h3]Neworking[/h3]
Bad gunplay is exaggerated by the fact that there are no local servers and an online connection is required to play, even solo. Now this might not be an issue for everyone, but it was for me. Having AI enemies rubberband around and teleport closer to you when their primary weapon of choice is a fire axe that can drop you in a couple hits, it's pretty irritating. Certain sound effects are also tied to latency like, TF? I have played games with no local severs, but the networking in this game is kinda [b]really[/b] bad. It's unfortunate because the devs cared more about DRM than player experience. This could have been mostly mitigated should they have just had local play. There is no P2P/listen server support in this. Playing online was just messy and there could have been some fun to be had if playing with friends.

[h3]Monetized[/h3]
Now It wouldn't be an Ubisoft title if it wasn't monetized to hell and back. It's all here - Season Pass, DLC, In-game microtransactions, lootboxes, all that crap. This was surprisingly hard to find too. Now most if not all of it is cosmetic but cosmetics in this game are kinda lame. That's coming from someone who loves customisation. Pretty sure I saw a hat you can buy for 5 USD. Like Really? At that point I could go out and buy a hat for myself IRL.

[h3]Final experience[/h3]
I thought I'd have one last push on the game. So I booted it up ran a KM, died, respawned a KM away, ran back, died again, realised It was a really high level area, ran some more, got into the central hub, I was told to interact with a terminal, but at the terminal I was told to talk to someone. So I ran around for 15 minutes looking for them. [i]That doesn't sound like a lot but you run around for 15 minutes looking for where to go.[/i] So I left came and came back turns out the character didn't spawn in? I still couldn't interact with them so I watched a Youtube tutorial and they interacted with them, while I couldn't. Nah This wasn't worth it. It Didn't tell me who I had to interact with, I just had to spam [i]E[/i] on everything and hope for the best. This was the final nail in the coffin. This wasn't fun. 

[h3]Positve notes and twocents[/h3]
Now the game DOES look good, its visually stunning in some areas. It feels like a believable setting and place. There are some really cool things like micro destruction on glass, bullets create holes in like in siege. When in cover your character is in cover and moves over an open door they will close the door. Things like that. The game is really nice for some cool screenshots, but it's a hassle to turn off the HUD and there is no dedicated photo mode. I bought this game for around $5 and honestly I don't know if I'd pay more unless you really know this is the game for you, and you know what you're getting in to. I'm not saying  you can't have fun with The Division but there are games out there that do The Division so much better. It just feels like It has no soul, a husk. Apparently some of the DLC is fun like survival but I don't own it so I can't say anything more than that.

[b]TL;DR:[/b] [i]This is a collation of my thoughts, before I uninstall it. I'd Rather have the HDD space than the potential for nice looking screenshots. It's uninspired, clunky to some regard, and gameplay is ruined by bullet spongy enemies, bad networking, and an always online DRM. Monetization is very egregious, also an in-game hat that costs $5. Save your money, and go buy yourself an IRL fedora instead.[/i]

The best part of The Division might actually be its UI. It's been a while since I've seen an user interface this slick - The diegetic panels hanging in thin air sell the feeling of modern urban warfare more convincingly than a dozen of imaginary gadgets and beam weapons ever could.

Or maybe the best part is the post-catastrophic New York itself. A sizable chunk of a city ravaged by a weaponized virus has been meticulously created, and it looks and feels absolutely spot on. There are small details and nice touches everywhere, and exploring the alleys, stores and subways is constantly rewarded with little snippets of information that reveal the plight of the individuals caught up in increasingly dire circumstances.

The game doesn't shy away from its heavy subject matter. I'd say the worldview of The Division is surprisingly dour for a high-profile AAA blockbuster. The somber tone is disrupted only by the side mission voiceovers which try to add a dash of humor to the game, ending up sticking out like a sore thumb.

The environment tells a much better story than the main plotline, which is mostly concerned about shutting down various factions operating in the city and providing the players with more fodder to chew through. The shoot & loot gameplay of The Division manages to stay smooth and engaging although the enemy variation is minimal: Shooting guns just feels right, which is weird considering you'll usually have to unload a whole clip for a single bad guy to give up the ghost.

Moment-to-moment tactics never rise into a big role when playing alone, but jumping into a small group brings up the nuances of engagements better, with actual flanking moves and planning required, especially on the higher difficulty levels.

Praise must also be heaped upon the Snowdrop Engine, which is one of the most impressive pieces of graphical technology for the current generation. It might not be the fanciest engine, but the vistas it manages to consistently pull off are certainly impressive. Sound is not quite as great, and there's a lot of repetition in the audio that is somewhat jarring.

Anyhow, I quite enjoyed my time with The Division, playing both alone and in a group. The game nails the tempo of individual firefights, but more importantly it understands the value of quiet moments as well. Jogging along the deserted streets, just exploring and taking in the views remains my favorite thing in the game.

The Division is a solid cover-based loot shooter. It doesn't really bring anything new to the table; It just polishes an existing formula to a pleasing sheen. I think it's easily better than Borderlands, for example. Maybe that's because I found the subject matter way more compelling. It's a Tom Clancy game with the usual Tom Clancy gun/military/technology worship toned down. This post-apocalyptic world proved to be more interesting than anything Fallout 4 had to offer.

The game is OK for what it is, with plenty of content, but it's overpriced at the moment now that Division 2 is out, making the game harder to match-make in Division 1, and somewhat boring to play solo.

Aspects of the game are more linear and confining than one would expect in a looter shooter with an open-worldish feel. There's plenty of gear and character customization, and the visuals are really good. On the downside, movement can be janky, and the default keybinds are unorthodox and confusing. The shooting is also decidedly softcore; it sometimes feels like you have to empty two clips straight into a tango's baseball cap to down him. I'm not asking for a mil-sim in a looter shooter, but for a game that keeps prompting you to duck, take cover, and act tactically, the shooting is much closer to Call of Duty than CS:GO.

Worth picking up when it's on sale or if you get a discount coupon

What is The Division about?

A modified version of Smallpox has spread throughout New York during Black Friday and has forced the government to quarantine new york given the immense amount of victims. The USA president activates Directive 51 which consists in activating sleeping agents of an "unnamed" Division to send them in the quarantine zone to assist, maintain order and investigate the reasons of the outbreak. This was called the first wave as they went missing. Here comes the Second wave of The Division. Here starts the game: you're the second wave! The story is very simple yet intriguing, but DO NOT EXPECT CUTSCENES or stuff like that, the whole story is more like a pretext for the game itself, but if you enjoy the game you can find all crumbs and pieces of story through secondary missions, collectibles and endgame content. With them I've been able to get a bigger picture of the situation from multiple points of view, though it's not fundamental. And no, it doesn't require my playtime for that.


GRAPHIC. Engine And Artistic aspects.

Despite the Downgrade scandal, The Division still shows a marvelous New York with Massive's very own Snowdrop Engine. The biggest visual strength of the game is not about the variety of models (because it's pretty poor under that aspect, both for your own character and for your enemies), but in the game's world: a believable recreation of New York recreated with well known places and buildings but the biggest positive note lies in the immense amount of care for small details: some snowy roads might look the same as some buildings are quite common, but there are abandoned cars, buses or garbage truck, rubbish, animals and any sort of tracks that will make you think there was life there until a week ago, or more. Such as pile of bodybags. Or worse. Besides this gruesome example, you will notice an immense care for details that will require a bit of horsepower from your system to fully enjoy them.


GAMEPLAY. How does it work?

Let's start with the basics: you can play with up to 4 friends cooperatively. The game is a third person shooter full of RPG mechanics. So you go around and shoot in third person view, you loot enemies for armor parts or weapons, scavenge bags and backpacks looking for crafting elements or items that will give you small buffs (Healing factor, status immunity). All of this while you raise you character level to maximum cap of 30 and unlock passive and active abilities. The game is full of side missions, Encounters, Incursion (difficult wave-based missions) collectibles and main missions. Once you're done with the main missions and reach level 30 you reach the "endgame" that unlocks higher difficulties and world tiers (another way to increase the whole world difficulty), which will reward you with higher class items, rarest and unique items (if you're lucky) while you will face tougher enemies. Way tougher enemies. It will unlock also the ability to enjoy global events which consists in particular bonus paired with malus that change the gameplay increasing fun. They usually run for a week once a month and they advertise them via twitter. There's much more to say about all mechanics but Steam has its limits so suffice to say there's more to this, including PvP, Dark Zone, and so on.
Still better than The Division 2...

Since the final update for the game is out I am changing my review to suit the current state of the game. 

The division is one of the best games I have ever played, the story is decent and the game play is cover based with some non cover based mechanics. A lot of people argue that if you are not a hardcore player then the game is boring and tedious. I was not a hardcore player and only played a lot until I beat the campaign in patch 1.5, after that I bought the DLCs and played a few games of each (if you want more context on the DLCs check out my review of the season pass.) I played one campaign by myself and even bought 3 of my friends this game. I beat the game with 2 of them and never did with the 3rd. This game is a great game to play with friends, it has build diversity and even pvp that takes more skill then just aiming well. The game has 3 main build paths, Firepower, Toughness and Skill power. Firepower relates to the amount of damage you do to your enemy, Toughness relates to how much health you have and Skill power relates to how much healing or damage your skills do. There are over 14 unique gear sets that all have different functions with specific perks that make them better depending on if you want to be a sniper, tank, healer, dps and more. 


PVP in the division. PVP in this game is highly reliant on reaction time and good builds. Many people argue that having a god build is required to win in PVP but that is not correct and bias. The game rewards you for being the better player in most instances. If you and a guy are shooting eachother and you can shock nade him he is disabled for a few seconds giving you the advantage, being a smarter player is essential for surviving in PVP. The main place you will encounter other players where you can fight is in the Dark Zone, in here it is PVE and PVP, this is one of the places to get some of the best loot after beating the campaign. To get loot you have to clear landmarks which have difficult enemies that drop on average 3 pieces of gear. The max amount of things you can carry in the Dark Zone is 9, after reaching the limit you have to go to an extraction point and extract the loot which fending off enemies that are trying to stop you. Other players can find and kill you at any time, but this requires them to go ROGUE, which pits them against all other players. If you kill them you get xp and they are forced into a 30 second+ respawn screen. After extracting the loot will be in your stash at any checkpoint or in the Base of Operations. 

The last main aspect of the game is Incursions, these are "raid like" encounters where you fight many named and elite enemies. This usually requires at least 2 players, but if you are good enough its possible to solo it. Matchmaking is very possible and in fact is encouraged. I don't have much else to say about the game if you want to know more about the game there is a youtuber who had amazing guilds on the division here is a video example on the Dark Zone and how its more skill then builds. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PAn60lX8Stc

I purchased this game at a discount and I'm not sure I got a good deal.

Graphics are nice.  Environmental conditions are nice though those who developed probably only thinks it snows in NYC during the winter holiday.  Rain doesn't exist.

Weapons are good.  Each have a different feel so you need to find which one works for you.

Help/tutorial is a joke.  The hints do not stay up long enough for you to read it entirely and you have a good chance of missing them since they pop up at some inappropriate times.

Trying to using consumables in combat is cumbersome in the middle of combat.  At the beginning or just before you initiate, no issue.

Missions do not scale properly.  Bad guys can spot you very quickly when you are behind cover or they know where you are at as they enter the combat area before they engage in combat with you.  Fighting overwhelming odds can be exhilarating but when those numbers are 10-14 at one time, it is too lopsided.  

The JTF npcs are more of hindrance than help.  They have ran in front of me and stood there blocking my line of sight or ducked behind cover where I was at and nudged me enough to throw off my aim or just put me out far enough to get hit by the bad guys.

Some environmental situations are horrible in third person.  Hard to see anything through a tree that has leaves on it during the winter (and I thought the leaves of trees in NYC fell off in the winter).

If you want to enjoy the game, play it with someone else, it might improve the enjoyment but it is not that enjoyable playing this solo.

The leveling is okay, and trying out different constructions is fun, then it’s fun for a while to maximize the gear, then run out of steam at the same time, and then get stuck due to lack of things.
You need more maps where you can set it to the highest level if you just replay the same thing over and over again with useless loot drops and get to the point where you just can’t do it anymore, this game has actually stopped you from buying Ghost Recon, so you have to go for it.

Playing the upcoming TU10 patch on the test server at the moment that either saves this game or kills it, but according to the records of the participants, I feel like it’s over, but until it gets to the boredom stage, it’s worth the sale price if is on offer

[h1] I love Tom Clancy's The Division!  [/h1]

[i] I have 3500h in Tom Clancy's The Division unfortunately that is on PS4, before I could afford my own PC, I also have 300h on my little brothers Xbox one, since I sold my PS4 to get more money towards my PC build, but 2017 I got my own PC, but got right in to Tom Clancy's The Division 2 in 2019, just got Tom Clancy's The Division on steam during the sale since I loved the game I wanted to replay it on PC. [/i]

[u] Now on to the game review: [/u]

[b] Pros: [/b]
[b] + [/b] Very good story and alot of lore
[b] + [/b] Very good graphics for a game from 2016
[b] + [/b] Alot of replayability and grinding (After all the updates and DLC)
[b] + [/b] Good PVP, but requires alot of learning of the gear system to perform in PVP

[b] Cons: [/b]
[b] - [/b] Unfortunately it did not live up to the hype from E3
[b] - [/b] Not alot of players in lower tier (Since The Division 2 has released and have alot more players)
[b] - [/b] The GPS system in the game can be kinda "buggy" saying to go one way that is blocked or something is in the way so you have to find your own way.


[b] Summary: [/b]

Very solid game after a bad period during the release and the first half year. 
But it has a very good story and lore alot to dig in too.
The game has a very unique gear and weapon system for moding your weapons and gear to make a build perform to what you want. Now there is alot of replayability after alot of free updates and some DLCs.

[b] I highly recommend playing this game if you like lootershooters or third-person shooters. [/b]

It is a fun loot shooter with motivating mechanics. 

Pros:
- good  weapon handling (it's fun to shoot, different guns handle differently)
- nice graphics
- interesting setting (many iconic NYC buildings are included and are part of missions)
- the story missions are well done; there is some variety and the scenery changes a lot, including very iconic buildings like the UN building or NY main station
- trying to level up your character, gear, and base is motivating; you always want to keep going

Cons:
- some missions are repetitive (especially the side missions and encounters, which you have to do to upgrade your base); the medical encounters are the worst where you have to find stuff without any direction in sometimes very large areas - frustrating! And it is the same thing every time!
- some people criticize the "story", but I don't agree - as you play the game you uncover things like the origin of the virus, background of the various fanctions etc. which is interesting - but I would have liked more (especially the videos are well done)
good very good

They got the environment right.  I'll give them that.

The weapons feel great.  Sound design is on point.  Enemy NPC AI isn't too shabby, though their tactics really cause one to ask who the hell talked this poor sap into charging into a gun battle with an axe.  I don't really get a suicide-bomber vibe out of these gangs, and as a result, these melee fighters felt out of place.  The friendly NPC can be annoying.  It's like, "Hey, civvy, here's an idea - you're walking upright.  Pick up a gun and get out there.  Or shut up.  I'm not particular as to which.  But stuff the fawning compliments.  I'm not your savior ..."  

Maybe I'm being to critical; the story thus far feels pretty engaging ...  and I should preface my criticism with this:  I only played solo, though I do realize it is 'geared' towards co-op.  

But there are little things about this game that are so bloody [i]stupid[/i].  The enemies are still bullet sponges, though to a less extent than at first release, as I understand.  The whole gameplay aspect of these mindless morons charging at you in a gun battle with a bat, absorbing shot after shot as they charge.   [i]Stupid[/i].   There are maybe five types of "encounters" or "Side missions", and they basically mimic each other:  Fight for an objective, take objective and perform some game mechanic with the environment (Place supplies in storage, fix comms at location X, gather virus data, etc), then defend said objective for X number of minutes.  Rinse and repeat.  Once you've taken a couple of sectors, the only difference with upper levels, as far as I can tell, is the number of bullets the enemies can take.  Weapons barely scale with the enemies I was facing, so every encounter outside of the random 2-3 enemies on the streets, were a BLOODY CHORE to deal with. 
No thanks.

Didn't bother much with the Dark Zone.  My few adventures in, I only encountered NPC and always seemed outgunned and way under in hitpoints.

Saving loadouts overtop other loadouts, because no matter what loadout you were working on, when you overwrite that loadout, your always back on the alpha loadout unless you re-selected the one you were working on.  I quit this game on level 15, almost halfway content wise, after having accidentally saved yet another Bravo or Charlie loadout over my Alpha.  The whole inventory and skill system is cumbersome as all hell, and you know what?  I just don't care enough anymore to fix them again.  

More often than not I'm cursing at the shear absurdity of the situations Ubisoft built into this game, so the thought of putting effort back into reassembling my overwritten loadout so I can .. do what?  Hate it some more?  If the weapon is truly scaling to the character level, then enemies that can survive two 7.62mm rounds to the head should be a rare thing, not the average, no matter what the level.

Firefights were difficult in that often the player character would get stuck on walls.  You get this grenade indicator casting a red shadow all over you as it ticks off, and your character is banging the wall as you try to move out of cover to another location.  Wow, what a cool feature.

It's too bad.  Infuriating UI and, at times, absurd enemies made this game more irritation than fun, and me all the more irritated that I had to deal with easily fixable nonsense to enjoy the fantastic environment.   I cannot in good conscience recommend it.  Gonna try Div2.  I hear they fixed a lot of these things, and I got the game dirt cheap.  Might even get to log in today.

awesome game ,

A beautiful game with an incredible level of details and quite realistic behavior of enemies. Set in fallen NYC after pandemic of mysterious virus. Despite the fact it is mainly co-op shooter, I am not into online aspects of the game at all. As a single-player experience it is still fairly good, though.
In-game menus are nicely crafted, but they are not the most convenient ones and unfortunately you need to use them a lot, since the game is throwing stuff on you constantly and an equipment upgrading is a key to survival. 
I love the way the movement of the player was designed. I love the atmosphere the game creates. I dislike bullet sponginess of enemies, which breaks realism and sometimes deprives gunfights of fun. But the biggest disadvantage of Division, in my opinion, is its placement in the loot shooter category, whereas it would be an incredible chance to build a RPG on game’s assets. Maybe one day… 
Worth playing anyway!

Tom clancy's the disappointment (I like that name) is a post apocalyptic game where you (the agent and the other players) are activated as second wave division agents to save the new york city. You are gonna come across rogue agents(first wave agents and aaron keener) in the story and pvp zone.

Pros :
+Noice soundtracks (especially west side pier battle ones and precinct siege)
+Loads of character customizations
+High Tech Gadgets
+Snow (Man it really is damn good to immerse myself in the game)
+Atmospheric Surroundings
+Dialogues of enemies (especially rikers dialogue "fookin idiot" I love the way how it is to be said by them)
+Aaron keener (Rogue agent and underrated villian but noice personality)
+Loads of customizations for guns and gadgets too ( you can make any builds out of it)
+ 4 players can be played together (including you)
+AIs are smart (They can flank you and can use tactics to fook you up)
+Incursions and some hardcore legendary missions (these ones are tough but you will need to coordinate with your teammates to complete)
+Cover based tactical shooter (You cant just shoot em up by just aiming at their heads and out of cover)
+Fast travel
+Hunters (First wave agents or rogue agents whose outfits are fookin awesome.They look like modern military killers)
+Global events (These are the events which are only for limited time and can be occured again after a few months or so.In these events there are some modifiers on a mission in which you will have to grind for points in order to get yourself a reward.There are some exclusive rewards for completing)
+Masks ( I love goddamn masks because they make me look like a goddamn scary character and heroic thats why I envy hunters)

Cons :
-PVP is fooked up Dark zone( hackers and end game players are everywhere and some of the best gears can be looted in there)
-Bullet sponges ( enemies pve enemies are bullet sponges because massive fooked it up this game. you will have to shoot too many times to kill an enemy especially in higher level difficulties)
-Server problems (Sometimes there's a server problem like delta error)
-In order to learn story you will have to get collectibles ( or you can just watch in youtube)
-Builds are too much of the work (RNG can fook up your builds. I mean you will have to grind for the gears for which to make yourself a build and its too much of the hassle because RNG is shite)
-There are less players playin the game (Mostly they are playin end game contents)
-No vehicles ( You will have to rely on your running to get to the area you wanted to go)
-No melee weapons (Only hunters have it. They are brutal and cruel)
-Bugs ( There are some bugs one example is when you die and when other player revives you it just doesnt register)
-This game is mainly for cooperating and coordination (Missions are designed in such a way that it can be only done in with the help of teammates. Still there are some youtubers who did it in solo)
-No stealth

Still this game is one of my favourites because I mainly did go for storyline especially aaron keener( his story is continued in tom clancy the disappointment 2). It was the first project of massive ( they are mainly known for strategy games) but ubishit just threw it on their faces thats why the game is such in shitty condition right now.

The game itself is very good, but the optimization problems and the lack of support from Ubisoft is the main reason why I am not recommending purchase it at least for PC.

I faced a lot of frame drops issues despite I tried many possible solutions from YouTube and another sources the issue persisted. 

I requested support from Ubisoft but they are trying to blame my hardware about this issue, but I have many demanding games like Shadow of Mordor, Project Cars, Max Payne 3 and others that runs smoother without issues with my actual hardware therefore I am requesting a total refund.

Take in mind the frame drops issue, and if you think I am the only one facing it I suggest you check in YouTube the tons of videos reporting this.

Update: After an enough amount of time searching for a solution, even I wrote to Ubisoft tech support but I got an empty answer. Finally I get the solution by myself, does not matter if the game request at least 8 GB of RAM, the sad news are that you need at least 12 GB (minimum), and totally recommended 16 GB. I think this is due to the huge data the game needs to load, in order to bring you the amazing New York city, screen elements and all the things that make this game an excellent game (in graphics terms).

[b]Marketing. Done. Right.[/b]

Not [u]at all[/u] the epic open-world RPG experience they advertised it to be. Not. At. All.

[h1] Long Review Ahead [/h1]

First, and to get it out of the way, bugs and crashes are everywhere. There hasn't been a single session where I haven't had a CTD. Not THAT frequent, like others have experienced, but still there and annoying. Also, classic U-Play sh*tty "Delta" errors kicking you off the game for no reason. Classic U-Play issues - won't comment more on that.


[h1] The Problems [/h1]

[b][u]1. Character Creation:[/u][/b] Expect to see clones of your character EVERYWHERE. This is perhaps the MOST limited character creation I have seen in an RPG. Whether male or female, you get to choose between 5 preset faces, 5 hairstyles, a few ugly neck tattoos, and, worst of all, accessories. Yes, accessories. Instead of accessories (such as glasses) being in-game gear, they are considered a part of character creation. It's unbelievable how they made such a development decision. That means that if you choose any type of accessory for your character, for example sun-glasses, you have to stick with them forever. You can't take them off. Ugly face-paint included. It's simply ridiculous. (Don't be surprised if they ask you to pay for a character remake in the future).

[b][u]2. Missions:[/u][/b] Boring and repetitive. There are no more than 12 main missions lasting 15 minutes to 1 hour each to complete on hard, depending on the group. That's the real gameplay. Everything else advertised as "side-missions" is plain bull*shit. These side-missions are 4 missions recycling themselves all over the map. Worst part is that they are not exactly "side" since in order to level up and unlock abilities, you actually have to spam them. Also, they are the unimaginative missions you would expect and have seen in every RPG: rescue the hostages, activate the water supply, defend/hold the area, capture the stronghold. These recycle themselves all over the map and become a chore after finishing them for the second time. IF these unnecessary grinding missions didn't exist - the actual gameplay would be 5 hours tops with the Main Missions.

[b][u]3. AI and NPCs: [/u][/b] Disgusting. I have encountered 5 or maybe 6 different models of enemies throughout the whole game, all named Alex for some reason ([i]"They got/killed Alex!"[/i]). It's basically the usual hoodie/thug model, a stormtrooper model, and a fat boss model. Sometimes you see these weird snipers with a cape that came straight out of a Lord of the Rings movie. It's impossible to distinguish between the different enemy "factions." Only reason you can tell a Cleaner from one of the other guys [i](yes, that's how bad the story is: I don't even know their name)[/i] is the flamethrowers they have.
[b]-[/b]Civilian NPCs engaging in the same 3 behaviours (silly fighting betwen each other, limbing, coughing and dying) all over the map. Also they run like stupid in the middle of gun fights.
[b]-[/b]Store Clerks in the Base of Operations spamming "Come closer" "I have the best deals" all the time even when remotely close to them - simply annoying and shows how no testing went behind the game.

[b][u]4. Difficulty:[/u][/b] A joke. No real mechanics or skills needed to beat anything on hard since the game is a cheat on high difficulties. That is, enemies, other than being even more spongy, are also suicide-crazed shotgun wielders. They just charge at you from behind and 1-shot you without even seeing them (let's not forget the ridiculous spawning out of thin-air - especially in the Dark Zone). Further, you also get these annoying snipers poking their little spongy head behind cover. If you are found off-cover for 1 sec, you get insta killed out of nowhere, forcing you to spam in-and-out of cover between their shots in order to stay alive. Fights against sniper-bosses are an irritating 2-hour long peek-and-shoot game where being out of cover for an extra second means death. It goes like this: Enemy pokes head out quickly to shoot | you have a chance to shoot 2-3 bullets first that do almost no damage before being shot at | you return behind cover ASAP. If you don't, you die with 1 shot. And repeat for 1 and a half hours.

[b][u]5. Map:[/u][/b] Quite small. Taking under consideration that 1/3 of it is the Dark Zone, the rest is divided in small areas that only seem large because you are forced to jog/walk around the map. Copy-pasted apartment interiors/exteriors are all over the place. Every part on NY feels the same, however, overall [u]graphics:[/u] They are good for a 2016 title - ruined by a bad story.

[b][u]6. Story:[/u][/b] Boring, characterless, unmemorable, rushed, and confusing. Stuff don't make sense, although that's to be expected since you get spammed with all that information since the very beggining. [b]You walk around while getting audio feedback on what to do, then you somehow trigger another side-mission on the map and the old audio stops and a new character starts talking and telling you stuff. It's a huge confusion.[/b] No logic. Characters are all forgetable and generic. It's just rushed.

[b][u]6b. LITERALLY NO END GAME.[/u][/b] All you get is a daily mission that has you repeat a mission you've already done and endless grinding to do in the DZ to get slightly better gear. 

[b][u]7. Dark Zone: [/u][/b] As far as I can tell, the DZ punishes rogue agents so harshly that nobody actually goes rogue and kills others. Once I got jumped by 3 rogue agents, got behind cover and killed them all. All other instances were friendly/cautious people helping. Worst part about the DZ is how enemies spawn behind you out of nowhere, making a solo extraction almost impossible.

[b][u]8. Money milking: [/u][/b] Game is barely 2 weeks out and I just found out they are already selling clothing on the U-Play store for 4-GBP (5 euro?) each. And guess what. Gold Edition owners don't get sh*t for free. [u]EDIT[/u] - Pre-order people were screwed badly: All pre-order "EXCLUSIVES" are now given away for money to anyone. Way to go GreedSoft.

[b][u]9. The icing on the cake:[/u][/b] Since the release of the Closed Beta I expressed my negative opinions of the game on the Steam Forums. Long story short, I got banned by an Ubisoft moderator. After contacting Steam since it seemed like a hate-ban, a Steam representative actually investigated the issue and told me that he wouldn't have issued a ban since [u]I didn't[/u] violate any agreements, asking me to contact Ubisoft because he can't do anything about it. Of course, before contacting Ubisoft, I asked the Ubi-moderator in the appeal section as to what did I do wrong, never to get a reply for him, making me threaten him that I will contact Ubisoft if he keeps ignoring me. After I got no reply, I contacted Ubisoft and after days of waiting, they somehow reached and scolded the Ubisoft Steam Moderator who, in the end, let the ban remain as is. After the ban was over, I returned to the forums and asked a question, only to receive another ban for "trolling" from a 1 month old post regarding the Beta on the EXACT same thread he issued the last ban! So, he bans me RIGHT after the last ban ends again for a second time. Apparently, the guy got mad at me for contacting his employers and decided to ban me again, without replying in my second appeal and without explaining the reason, other than writing "trolling" as an excuse. If you are seeing this, this is why you are and always will be stuck in this dead-end job.


I can go on and on, but I am out of characters left. Forgettable, flawed, and mediocre.[b] It's clearly evident how "The Division" turned out to be just a really really good marketing job. Expected, since all we got until the very last minute were actor trailers, a limited Beta, and no actual gameplay footage. [/b]

I enjoyed it, even more fun with least 1 co-op buddy. I played about 594 hrs as a solo player and other 50 in co-op. By time i got to that point i was playing challenge and incursions solo and my co-op buddy struggled to even play hard lol.  It's a great game lots of weapons and stuff to collect and different build types for your char by time I got to 300hrs I had every armor set synergies sweet weapons had some really great setups. 

i was about to reinstall it (2-29-2020 last played 9-5-2019) and caught the division 2 on sale on ubisoft store for $2.99, so I said oh yea! I'll buy and play it now. I haven't played yet but soon literally just got it. This is a solid place for a new comer to start though "The Division 1". So buy it and sink some hours killing looters and gang bosses. i never liked the dark zone PvP stuff, I played it a little but i felt was just a gank fest not really my cup of tea. 

Some of you guys might like that sorta thing to each their own. Yes i highly recommend this version. IDK bout 2nd one yet we'll see. There is a reviewer on here some where says you might like this if you like ghost recon or splinter cell but it is nothing like either one of them not even the slightest in mechanics. It is more like "mass effect's" cover combat also the active combat skills. 

Char load outs, weapon stats and mechanics, mods, passive skill setups and types outfit system and account boundness of cosmetics remind me more like that of  the free to play game from trion called "Defiance". If you have ever played both games I mentioned, you'll see a huge resemblance to both. Definitely the Defiance resemblances.

Take note:
If you plan on just soloing, just get underground and maybe survival DLC. Personally, it wasn't what i was into. (the survival) I played underground the most and the other DLC contents are best for pvp. Outfits and weapon packs might not be worth it to you, just depends what type of person you are. 

You can't use the custom weapons end game (they are max level of 4 and can't be upgraded just special non changeable skinned weapons for noobs) you really only need 1 char in this game. (though 2+ help you collect division tech and phoenix credits more quickly, need this stuff to upgrade weapons at level 30) 1 char can do everything and any cosmetic item unlocked is account shared. 

DLC weapons only good till bout level 6 after that they are useless. You can loot weapons just as good and better as dlc weapons. DLC armor same deal. Some of the weapon skins you'll probably not use lol You'll find a lot better in game unless you just want to look like a fool with christmas wrapped guns..... The outfits themselves they alright, I use snow camo and urban camo a lot on my char to be more role play like, so get them if you want the cosmetic options. 

You'll unlock a lot in game regardless. I'd recommend them on sale, because it is just cosmetics wont change anything. The camo wont hide you to the AI or anyone in a PvP zone because you got a big a55 name over your head lol and AI once they spot you they hunt you down.  So cosmetic items are one those things some people like the options and some people really don't give a sh*t right? Like I said you'll unlock a crap ton in game even without the DLC.

As with most Ubisoft games, I fail to see the reason behind the vitriol. I came into [i]Tom Clancy’s The Division[/i] expecting a solid, open world third-person shooter with light RPG mechanics and some novel online functionality. I have gotten just that. Am I missing something here?

My first impressions: some of the most fluent cover shooting I've experienced since [i]Spec Ops: The Line[/i] and post-pandemic New York is as beautiful to wander as it is haunting, wonderfully immersive in its appropriate desolation.

[i]The Division[/i] is absolutely gorgeous to look at and surprisingly well-optimized out of the box; one of only three games out of hundreds I've been unable to max out on my current configuration, I average a solid 30 frames with a custom blend ranging between the high and ultra presets which, for me, is both impressive (for a two year-old notebook—ASUS ROG G750JZ) and appropriate given the technical depth presented here.

Character creation is OKAY. Not good, not bad, but OKAY. It's serviceable. Personally I don't find the player models anywhere near as ugly as people have made them out to be. If anything I find my agent to be rather adorable—an everyday woman on the job.

The plot is, for the most part, relatively unexplored and welcome territory for the medium. Storytelling, however, has been threadbare, so if that's a personal concern then this may not be the one you're looking for; [i]The Division[/i] is gameplay-centric to its core. I think most everyone will be impressed by the opening cinematic, though!

Really enjoying the original score, too; the menu and combat themes are perfectly fitting.

There's been much hot air over server issues. Let me put this into perspective: they were back up by the time my preload was finished unpacking, something nearly unprecedented for a game with significant online functionality.

Overall, [i]Tom Clancy’s The Division[/i] has been a fabulous addition to my Steam library, everything I wanted and then some. Is it a revolution in game design? Hardly, but for those of you with proper expectations in mind, I struggle to think of any genuine alternatives.

Oh Division, how much i love you.

- The Division is by far not only my favorite Tom Clancey's game, but also one of, if not my favorite single player game of all time. This game is not far all gamers, and i totally understand that, but that being said, I would like to go over the reasons I have such high praise for it. 

- The Division is a third person shooter, set in the futuristic world of New York, where a deadly virus has erupted causing mayhem and chaos throughout the city. You play as a Division agent, a first responder that deal with threats the the average civilian and tries to help with regaining order from a multitude of factions and different enemy groups. This game has a wide variety of different RPG elements such as skill trees, different class mods, and builds that can enhance certain playstyles. These aspects alone make the game very enjoyable for me, but there are a few other things that really sell it. 

- Can this game be bland at some times, yes. There is not a wide variety of different types of enemies, as well as most missions feeling quite linear, however the overall idea and look of the game is beyond breathtaking. I love being able to approach the game in any manor i want, you can go balls to the wall and just run into conflict, you can play it stealthy, you can use gadgets and manipulate the arenas to your advantage. This game does not offer much of a challenge, which i know can be a turn off for many players, but the atmosphere and customization that this glorious third person shooter offer, it is a movie like adventure with very solid gun play as well as an intriguing story. 

- I also very much appreciate the mulitplayer aspect of this game. Ubisoft could of really made this a single player game only (which is how i played the majority of it) but playing with friends is also a blast, and the dark zone is a very cool concept that gives the players an interesting challenge in an effort to get better gear for their personal kits.

PS - I have played the Division 2 as well, but it is not on steam so i can't write a review for that title. I do prefer the second game as i feel like they bumped up the difficulty as well as adding some new fun mechanics, and the updated graphics only enhance the experience for the player. I have more hours in 2 as well and love the DLCs that they keep pumping out.

The Division is sorely missing a sense of urgency--no, not from a story perspective, but from a gameplay one. 

Enemies are largely the same, except for their levels. Hit a wall of enemies too difficult to handle? Casually walk back through the streets to scoop up a few extra missions so you can come back and fight the exact same enemies you have been fighting, but with higher numbers.

There is nothing here that causes you to feel like you NEED to do anything differently. 
Sure they might have grenades to move you from cover, but you have a limitless healing box. The environment is almost NEVER an issue, presumably because sub zero temperatures mean nothing when you have a parka and a scarf. 
Oh, and that irradiated building? Well, as long as you have the right level(?) of gas mask you'll be fine. 

There's no sense of urgency whatsoever. 

TLDR: Just wander around until your numbers are high enough to wander around somewhere else.

It's an okay cover shooter and especially enjoyable if you're interested in looting gameplay but combat can get frustrating against bosses and high level enemies who are just bullet sponges. Often fights are lost because you run out of ammo, not because you made mistakes. The skills system is well realised at least and you can customise it to a decent degree to make a build that works for you. The variety of weapons and their modification is also appreciated, though you'll rarely hang onto weapons for long as better ones always come along eventually. The setting is my favourite part of this game, it's beautiful, full of detail and really sells the premise well, the NPCs, the story and all the padding isn't very good but if you want a post-apocalyptic mindless shooter it's great. The Darkzone is either going to be something you play the game exclusively for or something you ignore all together, it's both frustrating and incredibly fun, comparible to Modern Warfare's Blood Money mode but 3 years earlier.

What a pleasant surprise. When The Division first released way back in 2016 I was highly skeptical about whether it would be a game I would personally have an interest in. Visually it was amazing, but game play wise it looked very co-op heavy which I'm not a fan of. I held off buying until now, and have been very happy with this game so far! 

I only have a few hours at the time of typing this review, but I feel confident I can give an accurate impression on a game that I've been skeptical about for so long. First the pros: 

1.) There's a lot of content here. Lots of different activities and missions to sink your teeth into. 

2.) The graphics are top notch. Performance wise everything runs smoothly, I've yet to encounter any bugs or glitches. New York has never looked nicer, in a post apocalyptic sense at least (sorry Crysis 3).

3.) The controls are fantastic. A cover based shooter is never too complicated to play, but I found it very easy to jump into the game and learn the ropes very quickly. A complicated set of controls and game play sometimes turns me off playing a game.

4.) But what I'm most pleased about is the option to play alone and how it doesn't impact the PVE elements as much as I originally thought at pre-release. Co-op is seamless and players can drop in and out depending on what you prefer.

There is a story, but the game play definitely takes centre stage here. There's a lot of focus on completing missions and looting enemies and locations. It doesn't feel overdone, or repetitive so far.

Con-wise I can only find a few minor personal gripes:

1.) Scopes are not very effective. While other attachments genuinely add something to each weapon, the scopes barely make any difference to zoom/aim. Having a bigger difference between each of the scope types would make for more interesting combat.

2.) Killing every "shady looking person" doesn't feel very immersive as a Division agent. We're supposed to be protecting people and yet I feel like a murdering lunatic sometimes when I'm shooting at anyone who has a red enemy indicator above their head. It would be nice if we had the option to detain and or scare off looters/rioters. From an immersion standpoint at least.

Overall I'm very happy with The Division, and think it's a great game worth playing if you have any interest in RPG's or cover based shooters in general. This is my first impressions review of The Division, so it's subject to change and or additions!

Amazing Game

EDIT:  I just wanted to say that it's a rare thing, but maybe not so much these days, where the first game is better than the second.  I'm actually downloading to play this game again after having spent over 500 hours in the Division 2, and I have to say, the first game has better features and gameplay all around. 

So I was one of those guys when this game came out that refused to play it.  "Oh look, another microtransaction game from Ubi-Shat, imagine my shock."  Well, let me set your mind at ease about the microtransactions in this title.  They are purely for cosmetic items and in absolutely no way affect the gameplay.  This is not a "pay to win" type microtransaction game.  

Glad we got that out of the way, so lets talk about the actual nuts and bolts of the game.

===================
GRAPHICS  10/10
===================
Amazing.  The maxed out graphics are stellar, and without a doubt, some of the best work I've seen in the genre, especially given that the title was cross developed for our console brothers.  It's getting to be more and more rare that a developer takes the time to allow us on the PC to harness the full potential of our hardware, especially on these cross platform titles.  New York City is lovingly rendered, in its glorious post apocalyptic splendor.  Everything down to the most minute details.

===================
GAMEPLAY 7/10
===================
Alright, so I have to admit that I really love this game so I'm probably being a bit generous with my ratings here.  However, I am going to tell you straight out that I knocked the rating down to a 7 when I originally wrote this section as a 9/10 based on the simple fact that the PVP is abhorently awful, and in some cases, it is forced upon you.  I have never appreciated games where I couldn't "opt out" of pvp and "opt in" when I wanted to do it.  Yeah, tell me about realism and all that nonsense, but I'm playing a video game.  If I wanted realism I'd just go hang out in the actual Bronx and get my permadeath there.  

To go into more detail, effectively you build your character to fullfil certain standard MMORPG roles, healer, tank, DPS.  And a 4th role, PVP humper.  I kid you not there is gear specifically designed to help you be a better greifer.  And while that may appeal to some, it effectively means that when you are in the "Dark zone" area as a PVE class trying to do the PVE content in that area you may very well find yourself being murdered and griefed by people with such friendly and clearly not getting off on it handles like "ISmellYourFear18" and "CannibalFrank".  Seriously though, there are a certain kind of people who do that sort of thing, and with Ubi balls deep into the development of other titles at the end of the lifespan of this game, there is virtually no enforcement of anti-cheat rules.  Without exaggeration here, if you see a person bypass the 10 second "going rogue" timer to instantly attack you from inside your own group, or see someone able to "blink" around the combat area, literally moving instantaneously and becoming an imposible to hit target, that's not even fun, that's just blatant cheating, and tends to drive people who might otherwise be interested in some casual PVP away.

That said however, the PVE content is a lot of fun, assuming you don't find yourself wandering around in the Dark Zone on a saturday afternoon, or any day during the summer break.  The insurrections are unique experiences which create a challenge, the missions themselves are interesting enough, the storylines and side missions you are to use to level up are creative and varied.  Some say that the game is a bullet sponge, and it can be.  The trick is to keep upgrading your gear and to not attempt challenges too far above said gear, or you're going to feel like you're trying to dig your way to china using only a broken spork while you chip away at those insane health bars.

===================
PERFORMANCE 10/10
===================
So this game will run on anything at least quasi-modern.  Got a 4th gen i5, with a 600 series Nvidia graphics card an 8GB of ram?  You can expect around 35 frames if you kill everything to minimum.  It's going to look like microwaved dog crap but it will run at a playable framerate, and you will be able to enjoy the game with your friends.  As mentioned in the above Graphics section, it scales dramatically between those minimum and maximum settings. 

With regard to bugs, I have not experienced a single crash in the insane amount of hours I have spent on this game.  

===================
FINAL THOUGHTS
===================
While at the time of this review the game is effectively dead, with most of the new players being ones who were pulled in an effort to get the perks you can attain for The Division 2, there are enough old guard still around to get content done, and even pugging isn't terrible when you do it during a Global Event, which happen every few weeks.  As you can find this game around the net for under 10 bucks, it's well worth the price of admission, and if you've been looking at the sequel, there are nifty things you can earn for your characters in that game at this point.

Finally playing through The Division during the CoVid-19 pandemic almost felt eerie at times (like, [i]how did they know all this in advance[/i]? :) ). I generally enjoyed the game a lot just playing through the story missions and exploring the world (all maps 100% explored except Dark Zone). Some of the activities get a little repetitive but I still found it a lot of fun to explore every district and to see the sights. 

The game has some awesome ambience. UbiSoft did a great job on bringing the world to life. The graphics (4K ultra) still hold up to this day. There is an amazing level of detail in the world, NPCs who go by their own schedules, NPCs who comment on your mission (successes) and even small details in the environment like flocks of seagulls at the Hudson piers while the city center is populated by common pigeons.
I almost completely skipped the DZ, the gear grind and the DLC which is multiplayer/survival focused additional grind.

The game (which is "meant to be" played in coop, I guess) was actually quite challenging all the way up to level 30 and then it suddenly became a complete cakewalk when I could finally use those juicy high level items I got from a loot cache at the start of the game. However, in spite of always being a little over-leveled it was like playing a modern FPS on 'hard' up to level 30.

All in all I really enjoyed my 45 hours with the game and I'm looking forward to The Division 2 which I have already tested (beta, free weekend), bought and started a character but it will have to wait a bit as I need a change of scenery first.

P.S.: The technical stability (DX12) is a bit hit and miss. I had a few (maybe two or three) game sessions around mid game with quite a lot of crashes (once per hour or so) and then many prolonged game sessions towards the end with absolutely zero crashes. On a whole it was not too irritating so I did not switch back to DX11.

Cons:

• Gameplay and balance:
Game not has been made with solo-play style in mind, and so in middle of the game is huge difficulty wall if you play alone. You need to farm levels and loot to progress, it quickly become almost as boring as washing dishes. And even with all of the efforts you made, you get almost instantly killed by spawning waves of mobs.
Only way to get around this is to grind, and gring, and grind, and grind. It's not fun.

I really like the atmosphere of this game, and amount of work that has been made to produce such a game is tremendous. Huge applause for team that made this game, but I cannot honestly recommend it to anyone.

I've seen and heard a lot of different reviews about this game. After playing it for myself, I have to say that it is extremly entertaining and fun. I am new to this game, but I just had to write this review while the impression is fresh. I was lucky enough to find a friendly group of players that helped me to get started and it was a hell of a lot fun. I still have a lot to learn, I am still trying to understand some of the features but I do hope that this game will keep me entertained for at least 30 hours and since I paid only 9.99 euro instead od 49.99, I wouldn't be mad if it was any less. Overall, the game is fun, I like the concept, it is not difficult to get started and the graphics are stunning. There are some problems like clumsy stealth mechanics  but you get used to it. The Division is a game that I would recommend to anyone.

Update:
After playing The Division for 40 more hours I just wanted to update this review since I gained some experience in this game. 
For being one of the most controversial games of 2016, I was, and still am, amazed by how good this game is. It is easy to pick it up and you get the basic idea about it in a first few hours of gameplay but some game mechanics and "secrets" are scaterd throughout the game which keeps it interesting. Leveling system gives the player sense of accomplishment even after finishing the main story and getting ready for "grind" stage of the game. 
Graphics in this game, even on the lowest settings, are still pretty nice and the scenery of destroyed New York is pretty amazing. I've heard a lot of people saying that it get's boring and everything starts looking the same but it's the city that we're talking about, you can't make the impossible. 
Characters can sometimes feel empty and forced but there are enough good conversatins that make you forgive the rest.
Gameplay, as I mentioned in the beginning, is interesting even after finishing the main story since the game is practicly only beginning. Dark Zone, Underground (DLC), Search and Destroy, PvP and events are still waiting for you. Grinding part is also fun and can feel repetative sometimes but it remains fun even after 30+ hours. 

After all, I still highly recommend this experience to anyone willing to spend a bit more for the game from 2016 but I asure you, you won't feel sorry.
