The scenario is about NY City felt into chaos, because of a virus outbreak. Due to Corona virus crisis, it was a surprisingly good time for me to start playing this game. 

The environment is fantastic, including beautiful graphics and details. You will meet people on street, fighting for food or dying sick in front of you!

Of course, this is an open world action game with RPG characteristics. It is not a pure single-player game and requires you to be online, even on single player mode. Did I mention that you cannot cheat? Yeap… keep that in mind!

You can fast-travel to your unlocked safe houses and from each one to another, but you cannot drive vehicles. This is getting tiresome when you must reach a destination, located far away from your closest safe location.

The NPC's AI of both enemies and friendly forces is pretty good in combat. Besides, they roam without being particularly observant for threats. In most cases, they will not act if they are not get hit or you get too close to them.

Finally, this is "The Division", not Arma 3! You may have to hit an ordinary target 2 or 3 times on head -- based on your character's level and equipment -- in order to kill him.

I pre-ordered the gold edition of this game and played it from the day it came out until I realized the Dark Zone was a load of garbage. This was when the Dark Zone was the "endgame content" so of course I tossed it to the side. Luckily with the gold edition, I was guaranteed every DLC that would release for it, and I'm glad I did that.

The main story isn't that bad honestly, it's a situation that is wild enough to be fiction and realistic enough to wonder when it's going to happen. The gameplay itself actually takes a while if you have the people and are willing to actually play the game in more of a story driven way. I can't imagine there's too many people going into the Dark Zone anymore with the massive amount of scaling issues that Ubisoft never thought to look into, but for anyone that wants to actually enjoy the game the main missions are huge cinematic pieces, the side missions get grindy but have a knack for world building, and all the collectibles tell a story from someone's perspective.

The expansion packs are what really keep the game interesting though, they actually add some content after the game has been beat and it's all said and done, which really adds to the value of the experience you're actually investing money into. Overall, if you're here for a competitive shooter, you've come to the wrong spot. If you're willing to sit through dialog and learn how Manhattan could be brought to it's knees, welcome aboard. Now if you'll excuse me, time for another runthrough.

As a resident of New York, I only bought this game to find out where the safe houses are going to be when they blow the bridges because of Covid-19.

Seriously though, I never played this game when it was first released. I have played The Division 2, and I bought this game recently as 'a prequel' to that just to understand the story and what I missed jumping straight to 2. And honestly, I love the atmosphere of this game so much better than 2. NYC gone to hell during Christmas! The weather effects, the lighting and the attention to detail of NYC is amazing. I actually found the building I worked in and the garage I park at in game.

So how do these two games compare and is the original game still worth getting?
The answer is yes.
The second game definitely improves on some of the aspects of the original, as well as adds more features and game-play. It seems the 2nd game is getting more of the love since they just released an expansion for it as well as moved to a seasonal 'Battle Pass' system in-game. And finding groups for the harder missions in 1 is a bit tough since I think most of the community has moved over to 2, which forces you to have to solo through most stuff, which is doable but rough sometimes.
BUT..
This game has more soul. Maybe because I'm a native NY'er, but D.C. ( which the 2nd game takes place in during the summer) can't compete with what they created in NYC during the winter. The 2nd games NYC expansion kinda fell short for me because I don't think it captured what they created in the first game.

I still recommend this game, the atmosphere they created is great. You really feel like your running through Manhattan.

If you're reading these reviews because you're on the fence about something you've heard about this game, maybe I can clear things up. The single-player experience (story, detail of world models, atmosphere, music) is great. In addition, this is one of those games where there's no shortage of people on the internet gushing over the incredible amount of detail, and rightly so. The work put in is apparent and beautiful. The progression of rebuilding a base of operations to serve the remaining Manhattan public was a great choice of backdrop to tie the segmented nature of the main story together.
The AI can be buggy and strange, but it saved my ass (unsaved game time) in a major way once. Movement control can feel clunky, but after some time you'll likely not care [strike]due the quality of the experience,[/strike] exept sometimes during fights.
To take the pain off of your character model blocking a portion of your screen, ubisoft has provided many cosmetic options sure to please even the most dedicated sims/elder scrolls fan.
Regarding pvp, I saw two comments on [url=https://www.reddit.com/r/thedivision/comments/7merer/troll_rogues_in_dz/]reddit[/url] that I thought described it well:

One of the best MMORPGs on the market right now. Impressive world design with a lot of details. Ubisoft totally nailed post-pandemic semi-apocalyptic setting. Amount of voice acting lines, artwork, in-game content etc. is just impressive. Well thought progression system and a lot of events for replayability. Most of the negative reviewers who call the game repetitive and grindy don't realize that this is an RPG first. This is not a linear FPS with a distinct endgame. You grind levels just like in any other MMORPG and fight against stronger enemies. There is a learning curve to the gameplay, but 'singleplayer' story does well to get even completely new players into the genre. Even if you are not into MMORPG, game is totally worth it to play through the story and explore the streets of post-pandemic NYC.

- 20th April 2016

So after 386 hours on Record, I mustered up the courage to finally write a review of Tom Clancy's: The Division and I, unfortunately, have to say No.

Please note this is mostly from personal experience and opinions.

Tom Clancy's: The Division is a very fun game, It has some really good RPG elements a relatively good amount of content and from the date of this review, It's still expanding with new content and patches being released.

It has very fun combat and shooting mechanics, a very good cover system a decent variety of skills and very entertaining PVP.
The new Incursions that have been recently are relatively entertaining and can prove a challenge but it can get really repetitive and annoyingly sometimes, it's also the best way to get some really good items now.
It was a very entertaining game for the most part, especially when you got a group of 4 friends with you.

However the game's story is completely unmemorable and outright boring as-well-as short, you can pretty much beat the main story and reach level 30 in about 8 hours.

The game has boring characters and barely any cutscenes explaining the story.

Most of the story is told by dialogue that comes on while playing the game and half the time you're trying to shoot enemies to even pay attention.

But the game's main issue that I had a hard time with is the stupid RNG system!
The best way to obtain strong weapons and armour is by crafting and ever since the latest Incursion DLC, crafting has been made slightly more difficult but added more and stronger crafting recipes.
They also made it so finding High-End items easier.
(Even though what you find tend to be complete Garbage.)
However, even though you can craft good items, you still have to pray for the game's Random Number Generator to give you an item with decent stats.

The game is grindy.
I placed nearly 386 hours in this, more than most of my friends and people I've met in the game and due to my bad Luck, I watched as those friends got lucky with Really good weapons and became superior than me, whilst no matter what I did I never had the same luck and fell behind.
I never felt like I was making progress no matter how hard I tried.

The game also has a severe problem with cheaters in the Dark Zone (PVP Area)
The game has no anti-cheat, You can use Cheat Engine and give yourself unlimited ammo and you'll never be caught unless you get reported or recorded and exposed and even then you'll only get a 3-day ban for your first offence.

The game is also riddled with bugs and glitches, though some have already been polished there are still a lot of nonsense going on.

In the Incursions there is a glitch which allows you to complete the challenging difficulty with ease and get the best possible loot.
The developers mentioned that people who exploited this glitch will receive a punishment.
Do I agree with this? No.
As someone who has done this glitch, the items I've obtained from this glitch were mediocre, to say the least, and even If I were to receive any punishment for this, I wouldn't care as I stopped playing the game anyway.

What I find strange is that when the game initially got released there was a glitch which would let you farm the same NPC over and over again "The Bullet King"
When the glitch got fixed, nobody got punished, the developers admitted it was their fault and even made a joke about the glitched NPC.
Why are they punishing players for their mistakes now?

The developers need to fix their priorities.
Let's punish players for abusing a glitch which we didn't fix on our unpolished game, but let's not do anything about the hackers roaming wildly in the Dark Zone.

I like this game, however, it needs to be fixed, It needs to do a better job to deal with cheaters, it needs to be polished and most certainly needs changes.

At the moment, I don't recommend this game because of the current issues which ruin the experience.
However, there is still a whole year of content coming out soon and when they get released, chances are I will return to try the game out again and update my review.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------

- 19th April 2020

It has been 4 years since the initial review of this game, it has had very little improvement.

I understand that The Division 2 was officially released as of last year, however, there are still plenty of people still purchasing and playing the original game.

The new features and expansions are incredibly dull and uninteresting, I was highly hopeful that this game, in particular, would've seen improvements and it did, but very few.

If you're still interested in anything related to Tom Clancy's: The Division, you might as well give this one a skip and go straight to the sequel.

Whilst a lot of the mechanics have not changed at all, it's a definite improvement in comparison to the first.
Even 4 years later I still love the atmosphere and ambience of this game, and the gameplay and mechanics are pretty good too.

General View:   
In my opinion, this is a great game, i am quite enjoying the Resistance mode currently, and its fun to team up with a group of friends. 

Story View:
The story is good enough i mute my discord call to hear what the cinematics are saying, some of the missions can be a bit tedious, but overall it was pretty well done

World View:
Honestly, probably one of the best looking games ive had the pleasure to play. sure it got downgraded a bit from showcase at e3, but it runs quite nicely. The attention to small detail makes or breaks games, and this one, was done correctly 

Gunplay View:
Nothing much to say here, guns feel good, sound good, and look good. one or two weapons have ridiculous recoil, but nothing too unmanageable.

Cover Mechanics View:
EVERY ONCE IN AWHILE it ticks me off going into cover again when i dont want it to, but for the most part, I do enjoy the cover mechanics, the animations are pretty smooth. sometimes you climb up on top of cars instead of taking cover and die on top of a car :^)

With an amount of time that I have "Played" (played meaning grinding and wising I could just shoot myself) I can say this game is just plain Horrible. Lets start with the story, its doesn't exist, the main idea you get is the fact its a virus that was man made, and use to spread. After that all the missions are just looking at factions and fighting them. Speaking of the factions, you got bandits, cleaners, rikers, and a PMC. You would assume each would act different, but nope, they all act the same minus the fact that they have different explosives on their back. Cleaners have explosive canisters on their back or hips, and use flames to clean, Rikers have bags and hip pouches that can explode, the bandits have bags that explode, and the PMC has ammo on the back that explode when shot enough, see the similarities? Gun play is ok, not amazing but not bad, and the cover to cover fighting is alright. The true problem with combat is the fact that staying above level on enemies at a normal pace will cause you to have an uphill battle. They can soak bullets up, but you can barely take one bump without your character falling over needing help. Youll need to be at least 4-5 levels above them to be able to fight them more easily. The base upgrading can be nice to get you new gadgets and perks, and even talents, each being useful (some better than others). Finally you got the Dark zone, being the most fun with it (as long as you have real gear.) the fighting feels fair, and the loot drops are much better than youll see normally. So at the end of the day if you want to grind in an unfair, and generic shooter, and you dont mind wanting to take a drill bit to your weenis, then please go on ahead and play this game, if you like not wasting your life away like I do then stay the hell away from this game.

I'd rather go through testicular torsion than replay this game again. It's awful. The story lacks any kind of substance, the gunplay is average at best and just awful at worst, the enemies are the same after early levels and they just zone in on one player and ignore the other players, even if another player is directly next to them. The AI acts as either a Navy Seal, or a grandma playing CS:GO for the first time. Zero situational awareness

There are around 14 or so story missions and a large number of side missions. Unfortunately the direction Ubi chose for this game was quantity over quality. The side missions suck. Many of the side missions feel the same and do not add to the story or make you feel like what you did was actually worth it. The story and missions is a massive let down and makes this game a grind to play. 

The customization had potential, but almost any and all cosmetic items you find and loot are very dull colors. Throughout the entire game, I only found 4 items that were not a neutral color, and of the 4 items I did find, they were all very dark. The other few things I did enjoy about this game were the different upgrades you could make to the wings in the main safe house. You could unlock perks and upgrades to use during combat, but this is a pretty standard thing for games of this genre. Also the weapon modifications were somewhat cool, but they never really felt like they made much of a difference. 

I have yet to play the dark zone and I have very little interest to, but I have heard from some that the dark zone is pretty cool. 

Overall, this is a very meh to just plain bad game. At times it was decent, but most other times it was a chore. I really wouldn't recommend playing this. I'd give it a 3/10 in my opinion

It is very hard to give this game a negative review. The open world is wonderfully crafted, in some almost loving detail, and the open world is just absolutely wonderfully done. The details, from signs to the accent of the voice acting is just wonderful. The idea itself is great, and with the current events the scenario is almost a prophecy.

The problem is the gameplay. It's neither a true single player game, nor is it a true MMO. You could play single, but the constant up-leveling forces you to upgrade and change your gear constantly. So you hunt for gear, with the best being in the PvP area of the game, which is separate from the one where the story progresses. So you get the push in the form of a not-so-subtle hint that you have to play multi-player PvE or PvP, the latter leading to a faster progression. If you don't, the game will become very grindy and somewhat repetitive. 

It's somewhat bewildering that this gorgeous environment was used for this type of gameplay. I want to see the whole of the environment, so I keep playing along, but it feels like a chore at time.

First review at 4 Hours playtime: 
The game itself is nice and interesting apart from the glitches and bugs. Even though I'm running on low settings, I see textures not loading properly in-game and sometimes inventory items not loading. The game is unplayable for me as even the enemies don't spawn until I'm very close to them and the game doesn't even let me sprint to cover when it happens. Another bug I found was the audio lagging. I don't hear enemy gunfire or grenades blowing up during a fight, and after the fight when everyone is dead and I'm looting the area then only I hear all those sounds. So terrible.

Edit at 28 hours:
So I tried to resolve above issues by trying several combinations of settings and managed to reduce the bugs by around 70%.
-Disabled Steam and Uplay in-game overlay
-Disabled VOIP in game settings
-Disabled DX12 Renderer
I'm still running on low graphic settings but the game anyway looks fine and most importantly, it runs fine. I'm glad I'm finally having fun and now I can recommend it.

The Division is completely engaging with a rich story, amazing visuals, and action that immediately immerse you into that world.

I'm not usually into shooter games but The Division captivated me by it's game mechanics and astounding story line. At first I was hesitant to purchase this game but I relented due to the constant prodding from my friends. I truly enjoyed the game mechanics with it's well balanced approach to assault capability, defense, and speed.
Replay value is off the charts. I own this game for Xbox One AND PC.

I would recommend this if not for the fact that it is always online and most of the time I have to start and close the game a couple of times to even be able to connect or the game can just halt in the middle of a firefight because ubisofts servers are not available at the moment. It is great. All this despite the fact that I do and want to play solo. Other players are just an annoyance and there is absolutely no reason this needs to be always online. 

It is a shame because the game is actually very fun as soon as you get past the very jarring experience of the enemies being complete bullet sponges, which looks and feels quite weird when everything else looks realistic. This is possible to get around somewhat by focusing on maximizing damage at the expense of health etc. 

Some other pros and cons:

Pros: 

- Extremely pretty graphics and environments with clutter and objects littering everywhere
- Very good and smooth animations
- Very intuitive, smooth and good traversal, something Ubisoft should have props for and perhaps they are the best in the field when it comes to this
- Fun, meaningful and useful upgrades and abilities
- The fun factor is quite high, the game is very fun to play overall
- Music is very scarce, but the little ambient music that kicks in sometimes in calm moments is really really good and gives a great sense of atmosphere. I usually mute all music in the Far Cry games so I wish they could take the sound design from here over to Far Cry.

Cons:

- Always online
- Other players running around like headless chickens (like in all games) with ugly name plates above their heads ruining immersion even more
- "Global Events" that add ridiculous overpowered modifiers that are impossible to turn off. You will just have to quit playing the days the events run if you don't want to play with the modifiers on, very good implementation that. 
- Some of the most idiotic "design" choices I have seen in a game. I am trying to solo the Incursion missions, which are extremely hard and granted made for several people, but I find it fun to try to do it myself and I did finish some, but one of them you need to push two buttons at the same time, which is impossible solo. So you can start the mission, but you can't finish it. Very good design there.
- Repeating lines and events for NPC:s making the world feel quite fake and like some kind of theater set
- Very bad map design and extremely annoying how it changes angle as you open or close it to disorient you even more
- Every bad guy seem to be named Alex for some reason
- There is like 5 different NPC faces, making them feel even more like clones and actors
- Quite heavy and icky vibes of forced diversity and "strong womanz" stuff, making the game feel even less realistic, believable and grounded in reality
- Very uneven and sometimes horrible voice acting and writing and attempts at "humor" that just feels quite pathetic. The game is quite uneven in many aspects to be honest, being completely fantastic in some areas (like the sense of detail in the environments and graphics) and feeling very rushed in others (like the repeating dialogue), almost like there is no single passionate director behind the game that is driving a coherent vision and not letting obvious huge flaws slip through in an otherwise insanely polished product, a problem that is quite common in many Ubisoft games and gives a vibe of a game that is "factory made" in some aspects. 
- Loot boxes

All in all I would say the game is still fun, and I would recommend it if not for the always online

In 2001, "Ghost Recon" predicted that Russia would invade Georgia in 2008, which they did.

Now in his grave, series robbed of its emphasis on speculative military fiction and given "Assassin's Creed" gameplay, Tom's name still carries a predictive capacity even when the gameplay is sorely lacking from Ubisoft's involvement.

Tom Clancy's "New York 2020"
